question_text: A research group wants to assess the safety and toxicity profile of a new drug. A clinical trial is conducted with 20 volunteers to estimate the maximum tolerated dose and monitor the apparent toxicity of the drug. The study design is best described as which of the following phases of a clinical trial?
content_preview: A research group wants to assess the safety and toxicity profile of a new drug. A clinical trial is conducted with 20 volunteers to estimate the maximum tolerated dose and monitor the apparent toxicity of the drug. The study design is best described as which of the following phases of a clinical trial?
hint: This phase aims to determine the safety, toxicity, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics of a drug.
learning_objective: Recall the objectives of different phases of clinical trials.

answers.explanation_why: Phase II trials are the first trials that evaluate drug efficacy among a small group of patients with the disease of interest. The drug dosing of a phase II trial would be based on the toxicity and side effect profile developed by the research group.

Phase III trials generally require large numbers of volunteers taking part in a randomized control trial rather than the small number of volunteers studied here. Moreover, the primary goal of a phase III trial is to evaluate drug efficacy against the “gold standard” treatment rather than to study the safety, toxicity, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics of a drug.
Phase 0 trials are meant to assess the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of a drug in a small group of healthy volunteer patients. Phase 0 trials do not assess safety or toxicity.

Phase IV trials are long-term “surveillance” trials. Often commenced and continued even after FDA approval, phase IV trials are meant to identify the long-term risks of drug treatment beyond those discovered during initial trials. Phase IV trials involve thousands of patients, many more than the small group of healthy volunteers included in the study here.

Phase V trials are conducted after drug approval to compare data on drug efficacy gathered from the community with the results of previous clinical studies. These studies involve large sample sizes, in contrast to the study here.

Following the initial evaluation of the drug to assess for its pharmacodynamic and pharmacokinetic properties (phase 0 trial), phase I clinical trials assess drug safety and determine tolerable drug dosages. The results of phase I trials are used to organize trials with a larger sample size that assess drug efficacy (phase II trials and phase III trials).

See “Clinical trial phases” table.

question_text: A group of investigators who are studying individuals infected with Trypanosoma cruzi is evaluating the ELISA absorbance cutoff value of serum samples for diagnosis of infection. The previous cutoff point is found to be too high, and the researchers decide to lower the threshold by 15%. Which of the following outcomes is most likely to result from this decision?
content_preview: A group of investigators who are studying individuals infected with Trypanosoma cruzi is evaluating the ELISA absorbance cutoff value of serum samples for diagnosis of infection. The previous cutoff point is found to be too high, and the researchers decide to lower the threshold by 15%. Which of the following outcomes is most likely to result from this decision?
hint: Lowering the cutoff value for this test will lead to a decrease in false negative results and an increase in false positive results.
learning_objective: Recall the effects of changing the threshold on diagnostic test performance.

answers.explanation_why:
The negative predictive value (NPV) of a test is the likelihood that an individual with a negative test result does not have the condition that is being tested. NPV is calculated as TN/(TN + FN). For this test, the ELISA absorbance value must meet or exceed a specified threshold to establish a diagnosis of Trypanosoma cruzi infection. Lowering the threshold of this test will lead to a decreased number of negative test results among infected individuals (i.e., a decrease in false negative results). If the test produces fewer false negative results, then its NPV will increase (i.e., a negative test result is more likely to reflect that the individual does not have the infection).

Lowering the threshold for this test will also result in increased sensitivity, decreased specificity, and decreased positive predictive value.

images.title: Cutoff value of an optimal screening test
images.description:
Graph showing the sensitivity and specificity of a diagnostic test in a group of individuals, some with the disease and some without (blue: negative test result; red: positive test result)- True negative (TN): a negative test result in an individual who does not have the disease
- True positive (TP): a positive test result in an individual who has the disease
- False negative (FN): a negative test result in an individual who has the disease
- False positive (FP): a positive test result in an individual who does not have the diseaseThe cutoff value (i.e., the threshold at which a test is considered positive or negative) determines the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive value of a test. A test is considered ideal for screening when its cutoff value balances the FP and FN rates, as depicted here.

answers.explanation_why: A true positive result is a positive test result in an individual who has the condition that is being tested. For this test, the ELISA absorbance value must meet or exceed a specified threshold to establish a diagnosis of Trypanosoma cruzi infection. Lowering the threshold of this test will lead to an increased number of positive test results among infected individuals (i.e., an increase in true positive results).

Sensitivity is calculated as 1 – FN rate. For this test, the ELISA absorbance value must meet or exceed a specified threshold to establish a diagnosis of Trypanosoma cruzi infection. Lowering the threshold of this test will lead to a decreased number of negative test results among infected individuals (i.e., a decrease in false negative results). If the test produces fewer false negative results, then its sensitivity will increase, not decrease.

A true negative result is a negative test result in an individual who does not have the condition that is being tested. For this test, the ELISA absorbance value must meet or exceed a specified threshold to establish a diagnosis of Trypanosoma cruzi infection. Lowering the threshold of this test will lead to a decreased number of negative test results among uninfected individuals (i.e., a decrease, not increase, in true negative results).

The positive predictive value (PPV) of a test is the likelihood that an individual with a positive test result has the condition that is being tested. PPV is calculated as TP/(TP + FP). For this test, the ELISA absorbance value must meet or exceed a specified threshold to establish a diagnosis of Trypanosoma cruzi infection. Lowering the threshold of this test will lead to an increased number of positive test results among uninfected individuals (i.e., an increase in false positive results). If the test produces more false positive results, then its PPV will decrease, not increase.

Specificity is calculated as 1 – FP rate. For this test, the ELISA absorbance value must meet or exceed a specified threshold to establish a diagnosis of Trypanosoma cruzi infection. Lowering the threshold of this test will lead to an increased number of positive test results among uninfected individuals (i.e., an increase in false positive results). If the test produces more false positive results, then its specificity will decrease, not increase.

question_text: A geriatrics investigator is evaluating the consistency of Alzheimer dementia diagnoses based on clinical symptoms. Patients with known chart diagnoses of Alzheimer dementia were evaluated by multiple physicians during a fixed time interval. Each evaluator was blinded to the others' assessments. The extent to which the diagnosis by one physician was replicated by another clinician examining the same patient is best described by which of the following terms?
content_preview: A geriatrics investigator is evaluating the consistency of Alzheimer dementia diagnoses based on clinical symptoms. Patients with known chart diagnoses of Alzheimer dementia were evaluated by multiple physicians during a fixed time interval. Each evaluator was blinded to the others' assessments. The extent to which the diagnosis by one physician was replicated by another clinician examining the same patient is best described by which of the following terms?
hint: The investigator wants to assess whether the diagnosis of Alzheimer dementia based on the clinical presentation produces reliable results.
learning_objective: Recall the definition of precision in the context of diagnostic test evaluation.

answers.explanation_why: Validity describes how well the results of a test reflect what it was originally developed to measure. Rather than interrogating the validity of the Alzheimer evaluation by comparing it to other diagnostic modalities, this investigator is interested in whether repeated measures would result in the same diagnosis.

Specificity refers to the ability of a specific test (e.g., Alzheimer evaluation) to correctly identify those who do not have a certain disease. As there are no standard values for this study group offered here, no conclusions about specificity can be drawn.

Predictive value reflects the likelihood that an individual who tests positive for a disease actually has the disease (positive predictive value) or the likelihood that an individual who tests negative for a disease is truly disease-free (negative predictive value). Here the investigator is instead interested if repeated measures by different examiners would yield the same result, which is assessing a different test characteristic.

Independent, repeated measurements assess a test's precision, or how reproducible the Alzheimer diagnosis is. In this case, interrater reliability is used to measure precision (e.g., a high interrater reliability means that the test yields similar results when performed by different examiners). A precise tool will have a low rate of random error and a high rate of consistency in spite of the variability between individual evaluators.

Sensitivity refers to the ability of a specific test (e.g., Alzheimer evaluation) to correctly identify those who have a certain disease (e.g., Alzheimer disease). As there are no standard values for this study group offered here, no conclusions about sensitivity can be drawn.

question_text: A group of investigators is studying the association between a fire retardant chemical used on furniture and interstitial lung disease. They use hospital records to identify 50 people who have been diagnosed with interstitial lung disease. They also identify a group of 50 people without interstitial lung disease who are matched in age and geographic location to those with the disease. The participants' exposure to the chemical is assessed by surveys and home visits. Which of the following best describes this study design?
content_preview: A group of investigators is studying the association between a fire retardant chemical used on furniture and interstitial lung disease. They use hospital records to identify 50 people who have been diagnosed with interstitial lung disease. They also identify a group of 50 people without interstitial lung disease who are matched in age and geographic location to those with the disease. The participants' exposure to the chemical is assessed by surveys and home visits. Which of the following best describes this study design?
hint: This study identifies groups of people with and without the disease of interest, and then compares the presence of risk factors between these two groups.
learning_objective: Recall characteristics of a case-control study design.

answers.explanation_why: In case-control studies, researchers select patients with (cases) and without the outcome of interest (control group). In this study, the outcome of interest is interstitial lung disease. This study design allows odds ratios to be determined, i.e. the odds of developing interstitial lung disease dependent on exposure to the fire retardant chemical. Case-control studies are retrospective studies and are prone to recall bias.

images.title: Temporal aspects of different study types
images.description: Cross-sectional studies (prevalence studies, snapshot studies) are used to determine the prevalence of exposure (e.g., a risk factor) and outcome (e.g., disease) at a specific point in time.Case-control studies are used to determine whether an exposure that happened in the past is associated with a present outcome. Researchers begin by selecting patients with the disease (cases) and individuals without the disease (controls). The two groups are then compared with regard to exposure to a risk factor in the past.In prospective cohort studies, participants are divided into an exposed (e.g., to a risk factor) and an unexposed group and then followed over the course of time to determine whether there is a difference in the rate of outcome (disease) between the two groups.Retrospective cohort studies begin after the exposure and outcome of interest have already occurred. Medical records previously collected about the participants are compared to determine whether there was a difference in the rate at which the exposed and unexposed groups developed the outcome of interest in the past.In experimental studies, researchers introduce an intervention and study its effects.Randomized controlled trials aim to determine the possible effect of a specific intervention on a given population. People are randomly allocated into an intervention and control group and monitored over the course of time for outcomes of interest.

answers.explanation_why: Cross-sectional studies analyze data from a representative subset of a population at a specific point in time and can be used to determine prevalence or risk factors for a disease. Because this study design selects individuals based on the presence of a disease, it is not representative of the population, and therefore, not a cross-sectional study.

Case series are a series of reports on similar cases of a disease or exposure (i.e., to a drug). Unlike the study described here, case series do not use a matched comparative group (i.e., control group) in their design.

For retrospective cohort studies individuals are selected based on exposure and then it is observed if these individuals developed a specific disease. Because this study selected patients based on their known outcomes, it is not a cohort study.

In a randomized controlled trial, participants are prospectively selected and randomly assigned to control or treatment groups. Because this study retroactively selects participants and does not have an intervention of interest, it is not a randomized controlled trial.

question_text: A rheumatologist is evaluating the long-term risk of venous thromboembolism in patients with newly diagnosed rheumatoid arthritis by comparing two retrospective cohort studies. In study A, the hazard ratio for venous thromboembolism was found to be 1.7 with a 95% confidence interval of 0.89–2.9. Study B identified a hazard ratio for venous thromboembolism of 1.6 with a 95% confidence interval of 1.1–2.5. Which of the following statements about the reported association in these studies is most accurate?
content_preview: A rheumatologist is evaluating the long-term risk of venous thromboembolism in patients with newly diagnosed rheumatoid arthritis by comparing two retrospective cohort studies. In study A, the hazard ratio for venous thromboembolism was found to be 1.7 with a 95% confidence interval of 0.89–2.9. Study B identified a hazard ratio for venous thromboembolism of 1.6 with a 95% confidence interval of 1.1–2.5. Which of the following statements about the reported association in these studies is most accurate?
hint: A hazard ratio (HR) equal to 1.0 means there is no difference in the long-term VTE risk between the rheumatoid arthritis and control groups.
learning_objective: Interpret hazard ratios and their confidence intervals to infer p-value significance.

answers.content: The results of study B are less likely to be accurate than the results of study A.
answers.explanation_why: Accuracy refers to how well a study reflects the truth of the association between the variables of interest. It is impossible to make a statement about this study's accuracy without information regarding its methodology (e.g., inclusion/exclusion criteria, randomization strategy, group demographics), which would allow sources of systematic error to be properly evaluated.

answers.content: The HR of study B is less likely to be statistically significant than the HR of study A.
answers.explanation_why: Because the 95% confidence interval of the HR excludes 1.0 for study B but includes 1.0 for study A, it can be concluded that the HR for study B is statistically significant, while the HR for study A is not.

answers.content: Study A likely had a larger sample size than study B.
answers.explanation_why: Assuming that all aspects of study design remain the same, a larger sample size (n) will decrease standard deviation, which results in a narrower confidence interval. Since study B has a narrower confidence interval than study A, it can be inferred that study B in fact had a larger sample size than study A. However, because no other information about the study populations is provided, it cannot be definitively concluded that this is the case.

answers.content: The p-value of study A is likely larger than the p-value of study B.
answers.explanation_why: The 95% confidence interval of the HR for study A includes 1.0 and therefore is not statistically significant (p-value > 0.05). In contrast, the 95% confidence interval of the HR for study B does not include 1.0 and therefore is statistically significant (p-value < 0.05). Although the exact p-values are not given here, we can use this significance criterion to infer that (p-value of study B) < 0.05 < (p-value of study A).

answers.content: The power of study B is likely smaller than the power of study A.
answers.explanation_why: Statistical power is increased by several factors, including large sample size, a large magnitude of effect between groups, increased precision of measurement, and the stringency of the statistical significance criterion chosen for the study (a p-value of 0.03 will fulfill a significance criterion of p < 0.05 before a significance criterion of p < 0.01). Because study B's 95% confidence interval of the HR excludes 1.0, this study had sufficient statistical power to detect a difference between the groups. In contrast, study A's 95% confidence interval of the HR includes 1.0; study A is therefore less powerful than study B.

question_text: A group of investigators is evaluating the efficacy of intranasal ketamine in decreasing acute suicidality in teenagers admitted to inpatient psychiatric units. They conducted a pilot study in which 15 participants were randomized to receive intranasal ketamine while 15 participants were randomized to receive a placebo. With the level of significance fixed at 5%, the investigators ultimately found no statistically significant difference in suicidality between the intervention and control groups after 30 days of follow-up. They suspect inadequate statistical power. Assuming the investigators intend to keep the level of significance at 5%, which of the following changes would be most effective to increase the statistical power?
content_preview: A group of investigators is evaluating the efficacy of intranasal ketamine in decreasing acute suicidality in teenagers admitted to inpatient psychiatric units. They conducted a pilot study in which 15 participants were randomized to receive intranasal ketamine while 15 participants were randomized to receive a placebo. With the level of significance fixed at 5%, the investigators ultimately found no statistically significant difference in suicidality between the intervention and control groups after 30 days of follow-up. They suspect inadequate statistical power. Assuming the investigators intend to keep the level of significance at 5%, which of the following changes would be most effective to increase the statistical power?
hint: Statistical power is the probability that a study will detect a true difference (i.e., rejecting the null hypothesis when the alternative hypothesis is true).
learning_objective: Recall factors that affect statistical power.

answers.explanation_why: Decreasing α (otherwise known as the type I error rate) is an aspect of experiment design that is intended to offset the risk of concluding that an effect or difference exists when there is, in fact, no effect or difference. The α is set by the researcher, with the most traditional value being 0.05. These researchers also used 0.05 (i.e., 5%) as the significance threshold. Changing this value will have no direct effect on the statistical power of the experiment.

Decreasing the sample size will cause a reduction in statistical power. A smaller sample is more subject to the effects of random chance, so the probability of committing a type II error will necessarily increase in this condition.

answers.content: Decrease the type II error rate
answers.explanation_why: Decreasing the type II error rate (symbolized as β) reduces the chance of accepting a false null hypothesis and rejecting a viable alternative hypothesis. Reducing β can be achieved by increasing the sample size in the study or by making more precise measurements of the outcome of interest. Either of these two actions will directly increase the statistical power. In mathematical terms, power = 1 – β so it easily follows that reducing β will lead to increased statistical power.
Beta, or the probability of a type II error, is the complement of power (power = 1 – β). Increasing β would cause a decrease in statistical power, the opposite of the desired effect.

answers.content: Increase the type I error rate
answers.explanation_why: Increasing the type I error rate (also known as alpha), will have no direct effect on the statistical power. Alpha is the significance level that is chosen by the researcher. In this experiment, it has been set at 0.05 (i.e., 5%), which is the most common threshold for this value.

question_text: An investigator is studying the relationship between suicide and unemployment using data from a national health registry that encompasses 10,000 people who died by suicide, as well as 100,000 matched controls. The investigator finds that unemployment was associated with an increased risk of death by suicide (odds ratio = 3.02; p < 0.001). Among patients with a significant psychiatric history, there was no relationship between suicide and unemployment (p = 0.282). Likewise, no relationship was found between the two variables among patients without a psychiatric history (p = 0.32). These results are best explained by which of the following?
content_preview: An investigator is studying the relationship between suicide and unemployment using data from a national health registry that encompasses 10,000 people who died by suicide, as well as 100,000 matched controls. The investigator finds that unemployment was associated with an increased risk of death by suicide (odds ratio = 3.02; p < 0.001). Among patients with a significant psychiatric history, there was no relationship between suicide and unemployment (p = 0.282). Likewise, no relationship was found between the two variables among patients without a psychiatric history (p = 0.32). These results are best explained by which of the following?
hint: Upon stratifying for psychiatric history, the relationship between suicide and unemployment has changed such that it is no longer significant for both groups.
learning_objective: Interpret the effect of stratification on study results, and recall the concept of confounding.

answers.explanation_why: In epidemiology, matching is a study design method to reduce bias due to confounding. It is often used in case-control studies, as it is used here, to control for known confounders. Matching does not explain why the association between suicide and unemployment was no longer significant in the stratified analysis.

Selection bias occurs if the study population does not reflect the target population. For example, it could have occurred here if the study had only recruited participants who owned firearms but then applied the results to a population where the prevalence of gun ownership was low. Selection bias does not explain why the association between suicide and unemployment was no longer significant in the stratified analysis.

Observer bias occurs when the measurement of a variable is influenced by the experimenter's knowledge or expectations; there is no evidence to suggest that the different odds ratios from the crude analysis and the stratified analysis were influenced by the experimenter.

Effect modification occurs when the relationship between an exposure and an outcome differs in the presence and absence of a third variable. When a stratified analysis is conducted, the stratum-specific effects will be different from each other. Here, the stratum-specific effects are the same: there was no relationship between suicide and unemployment in the group with a psychiatric history or the group without a psychiatric history.

Stratification is an analytical tool in which a group is divided into subgroups to determine if a relationship that is true for the entire group holds within each of the subgroups. It is the technique that was used here to determine that the crude analysis odds ratios differed from the stratum-specific odds ratios. However, stratification does not explain why odds ratios differed.

Confounding may occur when the relationship between an exposure and an outcome is distorted by the effect of a third variable that has an association with both the exposure and the outcome. Here, the crude analysis showed a significant relationship between suicide and unemployment. However, when the sample was stratified by psychiatric history, there was no relationship between suicide and unemployment in the group with a psychiatric history or the group without a psychiatric history. Because a psychiatric history is associated with both unemployment and suicide, it is a potential confounder that may account for the observed results in the crude analysis.

To minimize confounding during study design, stratification, randomization, and/or matching can be used. Good study design includes anticipating potential confounders.

question_text: A graduate student in public health is conducting a study on population health and is comparing different demographic models. He is particularly interested in investigating health care interventions in societies with the demographic distribution shown. Which of the following measures is most likely to ensure a healthy demographic transition in this population?
content_preview: A graduate student in public health is conducting a study on population health and is comparing different demographic models. He is particularly interested in investigating health care interventions in societies with the demographic distribution shown. Which of the following measures is most likely to ensure a healthy demographic transition in this population?
hint: The illustration shows an expansive pyramid, reflecting a youthful population with high birth rates and low life expectancy.
learning_objective: Recognize an expansive demographic pyramid, and choose the most effective public health measure to ensure a healthy demographic transition.

answers.content: Invest in workplace health and safety measures
answers.explanation_why: Investing in workplace health and safety measures would have an impact on populations in which a large proportion of individuals are employed, i.e., those with a significant middle-aged population. However, this population is predominantly youthful, with a large proportion of individuals under the age of 20. Investing in workplace health and safety measures would, therefore, impact only a small proportion of the population.

Investing in interventions for children such as childhood immunization programs is most likely to ensure a healthy demographic transition in a youthful population. The goal of healthy demographic transitions is to lower death rates, lower birth rates, and ensure a healthy aging population. In the given population, the majority of individuals are young. Consequently, interventions that reduce child mortality and reproduction (e.g., by improving access to contraceptives) are likely to have a positive impact on the demographic distribution.

images.title: Expansive population pyramid
images.description: This population pyramid has a wide base, which indicates a greater proportion of individuals in younger age categories than in older age categories.This distribution reflects a population with high birth rates and low life expectancy, which indicates rapid population growth.

answers.content: Invest in type II diabetes research programs
answers.explanation_why: Investing in type II diabetes research would be beneficial in populations with a significant middle-aged and elderly population. However, this population is predominantly youthful, with the majority of individuals under the age of 20. In individuals under the age of 20, type II diabetes is rare. Investing in diabetes research would therefore not benefit a large proportion of the population.

images.title: Constrictive population pyramid
images.description: This population pyramid has a narrowed base, indicating a smaller proportion of individuals in the younger age categories relative to those in older categories.This distribution reflects a population with a low birth rate and high life expectancy, which indicates zero population growth or population decline.

answers.content: Invest in prostate cancer screening programs
answers.explanation_why: Investing in prostate cancer screening programs might lower the death rate of elderly men and would therefore be beneficial in communities with a significant elderly population. However, this population is predominantly youthful, with the majority of individuals under the age of 20. Investing in prostate cancer screening programs would therefore not benefit a large proportion of the population.

images.title: Constrictive population pyramid
images.description: This population pyramid has a narrowed base, indicating a smaller proportion of individuals in the younger age categories relative to those in older categories.This distribution reflects a population with a low birth rate and high life expectancy, which indicates zero population growth or population decline.

answers.explanation_why: Investing in long-term care facilities would be beneficial in communities with a significant elderly population. However, this population is predominantly youthful, with the majority of individuals under the age of 20. Investing in long-term care facilities would therefore not benefit a large proportion of the population.

question_text:
High-quality afterschool programming during childhood promotes long-term adult mental health
Background
High-quality afterschool programming in children has been found to improve standardized test scores, dropout rates, and college attendance. The APPLE (Afterschool Programming for Psychiatric Long-term Endpoints) study seeks to examine the effect of such programs on long-term adult mental health.
Design, Setting, and Participants
Socioeconomically disadvantaged children ages 5–10 were recruited for this study. Participants with a history of intellectual/developmental disability or existing psychiatric illness were excluded. Eligible families were identified by screening government social service agencies in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, and of all qualified families who were invited to participate in free afterschool enrichment activities for their children, 320 children were enrolled. The socioeconomic characteristics of study participants were found to be similar to those of the population being studied.
160 children were randomly assigned to free afterschool enrichment activities and 160 to a waiting list that served as a control; the parents of 12 children declined participation after their children were randomly assigned to the control group. Of the 83 children participating in the study's 20-year follow-up, 62 were in the treatment group and 21 were in the control group.
Interventions
The intervention involved free afterschool programming for the first three years of the study. The programming lasted three hours per day and was held five days per week, consisting of an hour of creative problem-based math/reading instruction supplemented with two hours of music, art, and athletic group activities. Children in the control group were placed on the waiting list for the intervention.
Main Outcomes and Measures
Data on the incidence of common DSM 5-validated mental health conditions was collected at the study's 20-year follow-up evaluation and confirmed by chart review.
Results
Table - Association of major depression, ADHD, bipolar disorder, and psychotic disorder at 20-year follow-up of participants who received afterschool enrichment during childhood*.
*Adjusted for income and family history of psychiatric illness.

Source of funding: Wisconsin Children's Mental Health Foundation, National Early Childhood Education Coalition

An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for a well-child examination at a clinic for low-income residents. Although her son's elementary school offers free afterschool programming, her son has not been interested in attending. The son's maternal grandmother has schizophrenia. The mother is inquiring about the benefits of afterschool programming and asks for the physician's input. Based on the study results, which of the following statements best addresses the mother's question?

Major Depressive Disorder Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder Relative Risk (95% CI) P -value Relative Risk (95% CI) P -value Control 1.0 [reference] -- 1.0 [reference] -- Afterschool Enrichment 0.69 (0.59–0.87) < 0.001 0.80 (0.74–0.92) 0.02 Bipolar Disorder (I or II) without Psychosis Any Psychotic Disorder Relative Risk (95% CI) P -value Relative Risk (95% CI) P -value Control 1.0 [reference] -- 1.0 [reference] -- Afterschool Enrichment 0.64 (0.59–1.35) 0.34 0.84 (0.51–1.23) 0.22 Conclusions This study highlights the potential of high-quality afterschool programming during childhood in promoting long-term adult mental health. Although her son's elementary school offers free afterschool programming, her son has not been interested in attending. The son's maternal grandmother has schizophrenia. The mother is inquiring about the benefits of afterschool programming and asks for the physician's input. Based on the study results, which of the following statements best addresses the mother's question?
hint: The abstract describes a randomized, controlled trial (RCT). Results from RCTs only apply to individuals with baseline and clinical characteristics similar to those of the population enrolled in the study and may not be generalizable to other populations. With this in mind, take a look at the relative risk and p-values in the table.
learning_objective: Interpret relative risks and their significance in randomized controlled trials.

answers.content: High-quality afterschool programming has a greater effect on reducing ADHD risk in adulthood than major depressive disorder risk.
answers.explanation_why: The relative risk for the development of major depressive disorder among those in the afterschool programming group is 0.69, i.e., the investigated intervention produces a 31% risk reduction compared to the control treatment. The risk ratio for the development of ADHD among those in the afterschool programming group is 0.80, which means that the investigated intervention produces a 20% risk reduction compared to the control treatment. This indicates that afterschool programming has a greater effect on reducing the risk of depression (31%) than of ADHD (20%).

answers.content: The patient's family history of psychiatric illness prevents conclusions from being drawn from the study.
answers.explanation_why: While this patient has a strong family history of psychiatric disorder, his family history does not have an effect on the ability to draw conclusions from the study about a population. The abstract notes that the analysis adjusted for family history of income and psychiatric illness, suggesting that the researchers did not draw any conclusions about the effect of family history of mental illness (or interaction between family history and afterschool programming).

answers.content: High-quality afterschool programming for low-income 8-year-olds correlates with a decreased bipolar disorder risk in adulthood.
answers.explanation_why: Although at first glance it may appear that children who receive afterschool programming may have a decreased risk of developing bipolar disorder (with a relative risk of 0.64), this finding was not statistically significant because the p-value is 0.34 and the confidence interval includes 1.0. This suggests that the observed difference is likely due to random error.

answers.content: High-quality afterschool programming should be free of charge for low-income children to improve adult mental health.
answers.explanation_why: Although a policymaker may use the findings of this study to make an argument for increasing access to high-quality afterschool programming, this conclusion cannot be drawn from the study.

answers.content: High-quality afterschool programming for low-income 8-year-olds correlates with decreased ADHD risk in adulthood.
answers.explanation_why: The relative risk is a statistical measure used in clinical trials to compare the effect of an intervention on an outcome between two groups over time. A relative risk >1 indicates increased risk, and a relative risk <1 indicates decreased risk in the intervention group compared to the control group. For example, in a clinical trial comparing a new treatment to a placebo, a relative risk of 0.80 for a particular outcome suggests that the risk of experiencing the outcome is 20% (1-0.80) lower in the treatment group compared to the group receiving the placebo.

question_text:
High-quality afterschool programming during childhood promotes long-term adult mental health
Background
High-quality afterschool programming in children has been found to improve standardized test scores, dropout rates, and college attendance. The APPLE (Afterschool Programming for Psychiatric Long-term Endpoints) study seeks to examine the effect of such programs on long-term adult mental health.
Design, Setting, and Participants
Socioeconomically disadvantaged children ages 5–10 were recruited for this study. Participants with a history of intellectual/developmental disability or existing psychiatric illness were excluded. Eligible families were identified by screening government social service agencies in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, and of all qualified families who were invited to participate in free afterschool enrichment activities for their children, 320 children were enrolled. The socioeconomic characteristics of study participants were found to be similar to those of the population being studied.
160 children were randomly assigned to free afterschool enrichment activities and 160 to a waiting list that served as a control; the parents of 12 children declined participation after their children were randomly assigned to the control group. Of the 83 children participating in the study's 20-year follow-up, 62 were in the treatment group and 21 were in the control group.
Interventions
The intervention involved free afterschool programming for the first three years of the study. The programming lasted three hours per day and was held five days per week, consisting of an hour of creative problem-based math/reading instruction supplemented with two hours of music, art, and athletic group activities. Children in the control group were placed on the waiting list for the intervention.
Main Outcomes and Measures
Data on the incidence of common DSM 5-validated mental health conditions was collected at the study's 20-year follow-up evaluation and confirmed by chart review.
Results
Table - Association of major depression, ADHD, bipolar disorder, and psychotic disorder at 20-year follow-up of participants who received afterschool enrichment during childhood*.
*Adjusted for income and family history of psychiatric illness.

Major Depressive Disorder
Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder

Conclusions
This study highlights the potential of high-quality afterschool programming during childhood in promoting long-term adult mental health.
Source of funding: Wisconsin Children's Mental Health Foundation, National Early Childhood Education Coalition

The APPLE study investigators are currently preparing for a 30-year follow-up evaluation. They are curious about the number of participants who will partake in follow-up interviews. The investigators noted that of the 83 participants who participated in APPLE study's 20-year follow-up, 62 were in the treatment group and 21 were in the control group. This finding raises concerns for which of the following?

This finding raises concerns for which of the following?
hint: Longitudinal studies with a large number of participants lost to follow-up are prone to this type of selection bias.
learning_objective: Recall the concept of attrition bias in longitudinal studies.

answers.explanation_why: Volunteer bias may be present at the recruitment stage of a study if individuals who opt to participate are different from those who choose not to participate. In this study, the researchers report the socioeconomic characteristics of the participants as similar, which means that volunteer bias is not a concern. Also, since volunteer bias pertains to conditions at the beginning of a study, it would not explain the discrepancy in follow-up rates between the intervention group and the control group here.

Lead-time bias is a concern with screening interventions but is not relevant in this study. Lead-time bias occurs when a screening intervention appears to prolong survival when it has only really resulted in an earlier diagnosis.

In a randomized controlled trial such as this one, randomization is done shortly after enrollment in the study. Randomization should result in treatment and control groups that are roughly equal in baseline characteristics to avoid confounding factors. A difference in the size of groups is not indicative of an error in randomization.

Allocation bias occurs when there are systematic differences between treatment and control groups. However, allocation bias occurs during group assignment at the beginning of a study, not during follow-up. Furthermore, the participants of this study were randomized to either the treatment or the control group, which makes allocation bias unlikely.

Loss to follow-up may cause attrition bias if the remaining participants differ significantly from those lost to follow-up, especially if the reason for the dropout is related to the outcome. In this case, the participants in the control group may have been more likely to be lost to follow-up, assuming they did not feel as committed to the study as those who received free afterschool programming. However, if the participants in the control group who remained in the study had a higher incidence of mental health disorders than those lost to follow-up (e.g., because those with mental health disorders in the control were more motivated to present for follow-up), using the data could lead the researchers to overestimate the risk of mental health disorders among those in the control group.

Loss to follow-up may have caused the remaining sample size to be too small and therefore reduced the statistical power of the study. However, an inadequate sample size would not explain the discrepancy observed between the number of participants in the treatment and control group lost to follow-up.

Reporting bias occurs when participants cannot or do not accurately report exposure or outcomes due to attitudes, perceptions, or beliefs. For example, a participant might be reluctant to report a history of sexually transmitted infections to a medical researcher. Reporting bias is not a concern here, as the type of exposure (afterschool programming) and outcomes were confirmed by the researchers via chart review. Moreover, the discrepancy between the original participants and the remaining participants in the groups would not be a cause of reporting bias.

question_text: A critical care fellow is interested in whether the auscultatory finding of pulmonary rales can accurately predict hypervolemic state. He conducts a study in 100 patients with a volume overloaded state confirmed by a Swan Ganz catheter in his hospital's cardiac critical care unit. He also recruits 100 patients with euvolemic state confirmed by Swan Ganz catheter. He subsequently examines all patients in the unit for rales and finds that 80 patients in the hypervolemic group have rales in comparison to 50 patients in the euvolemic group. Which of the following is the probability that a patient in the study with rales on auscultation truly has hypervolemia?
content_preview: A critical care fellow is interested in whether the auscultatory finding of pulmonary rales can accurately predict hypervolemic state. He conducts a study in 100 patients with a volume overloaded state confirmed by a Swan Ganz catheter in his hospital's cardiac critical care unit. He also recruits 100 patients with euvolemic state confirmed by Swan Ganz catheter. He subsequently examines all patients in the unit for rales and finds that 80 patients in the hypervolemic group have rales in comparison to 50 patients in the euvolemic group. Which of the following is the probability that a patient in the study with rales on auscultation truly has hypervolemia?
hint: It may help to create a two-by-two table with the values mentioned in the stem and then calculate the number of true positives (TP), true negatives (TN), false positives (FP), and false negatives (FN). The positive predictive value (PPV) is the likelihood that a patient with a positive test result (i.e., presence of rales on auscultation) truly has the condition (i.e., hypervolemia).
learning_objective: Calculate the positive predictive value.

answers.explanation_why: 80/100 reflects the sensitivity of the test, i.e. the probability that the test (rales) is positive if the condition (hypervolemia) is present. Sensitivity is calculated as TP/(TP + FN) or TP ÷ all patients with the condition. In this case: sensitivity = 80/(80 + 20) = 80/100 = 80%. Based on this study, 80% of hypervolemic patients will have rales on auscultation.

50/100 reflects the specificity of the test, i.e. the probability that the test (rales) is negative if the condition (hypervolemia) is absent. The specificity is calculated as TN/(TN + FP) or TN ÷ all patients without the condition. In this case: specificity = 50/(50 + 50) = 50/100 = 50%. Based on this study, there is a 50% chance for euvolemic patients to have rales on auscultation, making this test inappropriate to effectively exclude this condition in euvolemic patients. A test with such a low specificity causes high rates of false positives (e.g., rales due to pneumonia, ARDS).

The PPV is calculated as TP/(TP + FP) or TP ÷ all patients who tested positive. In this case PPV = 80/(80 + 50) = 80/130 ≈ 62%. Based on this study, the PPV suggests that if an individual in the study has rales on auscultation, the likelihood of that patient truly being in a hypervolemic state is approx. 62%.

It is important to note that PPV and negative predictive value (NPV) are posttest probabilities (PoTPs), which are dependent on the condition's prevalence (i.e., pretest probability). In order to calculate the true PoTPs, the condition's prevalence in the sample population must be identical to its value in the general population in consideration but this might not be feasible in all study designs. This study's PoTPs will not have external validity because the researcher selected 100 patients with hypervolemia and 100 with euvolemia for the sample population. In such a situation, the researcher can use test characteristics (sensitivity and specificity), which are independent of prevalence, and the true prevalence (obtained from medical literature) to calculate the true PoTPs.

50/70 reflects the negative predictive value (NPV), i.e. the likelihood that a patient with a negative test result (no rales) truly does not have the disease (i.e., is euvolemic). NPV is calculated as TN/(TN + FN) or TN ÷ all patients who tested negative. In this case: NPV = 50/(50 + 20) = 50/70 ≈ 71.4%. Based on this study, if a patient does not have rales on auscultation, the likelihood of being in a euvolemic state is approx. 71.4%.

100/200 is the prevalence of cases with hypervolemia in the sample population of 200 patients. The prevalence is calculated as the number of people with a condition/the total number of people studied. In this case, prevalence = 100/200 = 50%. Accordingly, 50% of the study population is in a state of hypervolemia. Note that this is not the true prevalence of hypervolemia in the cardiac critical care unit.

question_text: A researcher is studying risk factors for open-angle glaucoma in a group of older patients at a primary care clinic. He wants to assess if patients with diabetes (fasting plasma glucose ≥ 126 mg/dL on two separate readings) are at increased risk of developing open-angle glaucoma compared to patients without diabetes (fasting plasma glucose < 126 mg/dL). Which of the following statements best describes the null hypothesis for this study?
content_preview: A researcher is studying risk factors for open-angle glaucoma in a group of older patients at a primary care clinic. He wants to assess if patients with diabetes (fasting plasma glucose ≥ 126 mg/dL on two separate readings) are at increased risk of developing open-angle glaucoma compared to patients without diabetes (fasting plasma glucose < 126 mg/dL). Which of the following statements best describes the null hypothesis for this study?
hint: The researcher is planning a prospective cohort study to evaluate the relative risk (RR) of glaucoma in patients with diabetes compared to patients without diabetes. The null hypothesis is RR=1.
learning_objective: Recall the definition of the null hypothesis in cohort studies.

answers.content: The risk of developing open-angle glaucoma is not significantly different in patients with and those without diabetes.
answers.explanation_why: The null hypothesis assumes that no statistically significant relationship between the measured variables will be observed in a given study. This study investigates the relationship between an exposure and an outcome. The exposure is the diabetic status of a patient as determined by fasting plasma glucose levels (binary variable: either with or without diabetes). The outcome is the onset of open-angle glaucoma. Association is evaluated using relative risk. Therefore, the null hypothesis for this study is that there is no significant difference in the risk of developing open-angle glaucoma in patients with diabetes compared to those without diabetes.

answers.content: Diabetes does not cause open-angle glaucoma.
answers.explanation_why: The null hypothesis is the assumption that no statistically significant relationship between the measured variables will be observed in a study. This study is evaluating relative risk, which is an association and therefore never implies causation. To investigate a possible causal relationship, a regression analysis (e.g., exploring the dose-response relationship) is more appropriate than an association analysis. Even with regression analyses, causal inferences should only be made after careful evaluation of all possible explanations for a result.

answers.content: Diabetes is not associated with an increased prevalence of open-angle glaucoma.
answers.explanation_why: This null hypothesis would be more appropriate for a cross-sectional study, which would examine the prevalence of open-angle glaucoma. This study, however, has a cohort design and is examining the incidence of open-angle glaucoma rather than prevalence.

answers.content: The risk of developing open-angle glaucoma is higher in patients with diabetes than in those without diabetes.
answers.explanation_why: This statement represents a possible alternative hypothesis, which attributes the experimental observations to a true effect or relationship between the predictor and outcome variables.

answers.content: Improved adherence to antidiabetics will not be effective in decreasing the risk of developing open-angle glaucoma.
answers.explanation_why: The null hypothesis should relate to the specific variables being tested by the study. In this scenario, the variables are fasting serum glucose measurements (not diabetes medication adherence) and the risk of developing open-angle glaucoma. This option is therefore an inappropriate null hypothesis. Instead, this statement represents an example of a possible interpretation of the results or conclusion drawn from the study.

question_text:
Predictors of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma in HIV-positive adults
Background:
Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is an aggressive cancer commonly seen in HIV-positive patients. It is also the most common aggressive non-Hodgkin lymphoma in the United States. Given that the risk profile for DLBCL remains unclear, this study seeks to identify predictors of DLBCL.
Methods:
Data was obtained via retrospective chart review at a major tertiary academic medical center in California in 2017. A total of 9,820 adults with HIV diagnoses between 2000 and 2002 and subsequently started on combined antiretroviral therapy (cART) were identified. Data on demographics and antiretroviral regimen were obtained. The prevalence of DLBCL cases in the cohort, as of 2017, was obtained via chart review. Medication adherence was assessed by analyzing pharmacy claims linked to patient charts and calculating a Medication Possession Rate (MPR), the total amount of time a medication was dispensed to patients divided by treatment period. Patients with a past or present history of cancer preceding HIV diagnosis, as well as missing data on key variables, were excluded from analysis.
Results:
This study included 219 cases (DLBCL) and 7,872 controls (no DLBCL). The average age of patients at the time of diagnosis was 58. Risk factors for DLBCL are shown in the table below with adjustment for covariates.
Table – Model showing impact of risk factors on DLBCL in HIV-positive patients

Conclusions:
Our study identified a number of risk factors that significantly contribute to DLBCL risk in HIV-positive adults.
Source of funding: Not stated

A 63-year-old HIV-positive man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. Four years ago, he was diagnosed with HIV and was started on cART therapy. He tells the physician that he has been having difficulty adhering to his medication regimen. He has been unemployed for the past couple of years and relies on unemployment benefits to cover the costs of daily living. His father died of lymphoma at the age of 60 years. He had recently heard about the results of the study featured in the abstract and wants more information about his risk of developing DLBCL. Based on the study, which of the following is the strongest risk factor for the development of DLBCL in HIV-positive patients with a similar profile as this patient?

Based on the study, which of the following is the strongest risk factor for the development of DLBCL in HIV-positive patients with a similar profile as this patient?
hint: The abstract describes a retrospective cohort study. As a measure of the probability that observed results occurred by chance, p-values help determine the statistical significance of a relationship between two variables (e.g., a p-value of 0.05 indicates the probability of seeing the observed results by chance is 5%, assuming the null hypothesis is true). The magnitude of relative risk (not the p-value), however, is a measure of how strongly a risk factor is associated with a given outcome.
learning_objective: Interpret relative risk and p-values in cohort studies.

answers.explanation_why: The relative risk of developing DLBCL in HIV-positive patients with a positive family history in comparison to patients without a family history of cancer is 1.35, suggesting a 35% increased risk of developing DLBCL in patients with a positive family history. However, the p-value of 0.08 is higher than the conventional p-value cutoff point of 0.05, and the confidence interval of 0.93–1.43 includes 1.0, indicating that there is no statistically significant difference in DLBCL risk based on family history of cancer.

The relative risk of developing DLBCL in male patients in comparison to female patients is 1.08. This suggests an 8% increased risk of developing DLBCL in male patients compared to female patients. Although this finding is statistically significant (p = 0.02), another factor is associated with an even higher risk of developing DLBCL.

The relative risk of developing DLBCL in HIV-positive patients with high adherence to cART in comparison to patients with low adherence to cART is 0.69. From this, you can calculate a 31% decreased risk of DLBCL in patients with high adherence to cART compared to patients with low adherence to cART. The relative risk of developing DLBCL among low adherence patients compared to high adherence patients would be 1/0.69 ≈ 1.45, corresponding to a 45% increased risk. The p-value for this relative risk is 0.03, meaning there is a statistically significant relationship between cART adherence and development of DLBCL.

The relative risk of developing DLBCL among HIV-positive patients with an annual income between $30,000 and $90,000 and above $90,000 compared to below $30,000 is 0.87 and 0.88, respectively, indicating a decreased risk. The relative risk of developing DLBCL among patients with a yearly income below $30,000 (compared to between $30,000 and $90,000) is 1/0.87 ≅ 1.15, corresponding to a 15% increased risk. Though this finding is statistically significant (p = 0.04), another factor is associated with an even higher risk of developing DLBCL.

The relative risk of developing DLBCL in HIV-positive patients ≥ 55 years of age compared to patients < 55 years is 1.21, with a p-value of 0.11, indicating that there is no statistically significant increased risk of developing DLBCL in HIV-positive patients 55 years or older compared to patients younger than 55.

question_text:
Predictors of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma in HIV-positive adults
Background:
Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is an aggressive cancer commonly seen in HIV-positive patients. It is also the most common aggressive non-Hodgkin lymphoma in the United States. Given that the risk profile for DLBCL remains unclear, this study seeks to identify predictors of DLBCL.
Methods:
Data were obtained via retrospective chart review at a major tertiary academic medical center in California in 2017. A total of 9,820 adults with HIV diagnoses between 2000 and 2002 and subsequently started on combined antiretroviral therapy (cART) were identified. Data on demographics and antiretroviral regimen were obtained. The prevalence of DLBCL cases in the cohort, as of 2017, was obtained via chart review. Medication adherence was assessed by analyzing pharmacy claims linked to patient charts and calculating a Medication Possession Rate (MPR), the total amount of time a medication was dispensed to patients divided by treatment period. Patients with a past or present history of cancer preceding HIV diagnosis, as well as missing data on key variables, were excluded from analysis.
Results:
This study included 219 cases (DLBCL) and 7,872 controls (no DLBCL). The average age of patients at the time of diagnosis was 58. Risk factors for DLBCL are shown in the table below with adjustment for covariates.
Table – Model showing impact of risk factors on DLBCL in HIV-positive patients

Relative risk (95% CI)
P-value

Age

0.11

Age < 55
Reference

Age ≥ 55
1.21 (0.96-1.48)

Biological sex

0.02

Female
Reference

Male

Income (per capita, per year)

0.04

< $30,000
Reference

0.87 (0.78-0.99)

> $90,000

*Thresholds (low versus high) for MPR are based on established cutoffs in the literature.
Conclusions:
Our study identified a number of risk factors that significantly contribute to DLBCL risk in HIV-positive adults.
Source of funding: Not stated

The authors of the study have decided to conduct a follow-up analysis of their data. They decide to stratify their results by CD4^+ T-lymphocyte count at the time of diagnosis. Among patients with CD4^+ cell counts below 200/mm^3, cART adherence was a significant predictor of DLBCL risk (RR = 0.52, p = 0.01). However, among patients with CD4^+ cell counts above 200/mm^3, no relationship was found between DLBCL risk and cART adherence (RR = 0.96, p = 0.36). Which of the following explains the difference observed between the two strata?

It is also the most common aggressive non-Hodgkin lymphoma in the United States. Given that the risk profile for DLBCL remains unclear, this study seeks to identify predictors of DLBCL. Methods: Data were obtained via retrospective chart review at a major tertiary academic medical center in California in 2017. A total of 9,820 adults with HIV diagnoses between 2000 and 2002 and subsequently started on combined antiretroviral therapy (cART) were identified. Data on demographics and antiretroviral regimen were obtained. The prevalence of DLBCL cases in the cohort, as of 2017, was obtained via chart review. Medication adherence was assessed by analyzing pharmacy claims linked to patient charts and calculating a Medication Possession Rate (MPR), the total amount of time a medication was dispensed to patients divided by treatment period. Patients with a past or present history of cancer preceding HIV diagnosis, as well as missing data on key variables, were excluded from analysis. Results: This study included 219 cases (DLBCL) and 7,872 controls (no DLBCL). The average age of patients at the time of diagnosis was 58. Risk factors for DLBCL are shown in the table below with adjustment for covariates. Table – Model showing impact of risk factors on DLBCL in HIV-positive patients Relative risk (95% CI) P-value Age 0.11 Age < 55 Reference Age ≥ 55 1.21 (0.96-1.48) Biological sex 0.02 Female Reference Male 1.08 (1.01-1.19) Income (per capita, per year) 0.04 < $30,000 Reference $30,000–$90,000 0.87 (0.78-0.99) > $90,000 0.88 (0.79-0.97) Family history of cancer 0.08 No family history Reference Family history of cancer 1.35 (0.93-1.43) cART adherence (measured via MPR)* 0.03 Low Reference High 0.69 (0.62-0.87) *Thresholds (low versus high) for MPR are based on established cutoffs in the literature. Conclusions: Our study identified a number of risk factors that significantly contribute to DLBCL risk in HIV-positive adults. Source of funding: Not stated The authors of the study have decided to conduct a follow-up analysis of their data. They decide to stratify their results by CD4+ T-lymphocyte count at the time of diagnosis. Among patients with CD4+ cell counts below 200/mm3, cART adherence was a significant predictor of DLBCL risk (RR = 0.52, p = 0.01). However, among patients with CD4+ cell counts above 200/mm3, no relationship was found between DLBCL risk and cART adherence (RR = 0.96, p = 0.36). Which of the following explains the difference observed between the two strata?
hint: In the crude analysis, high cART adherence was associated with a decreased risk of developing DLBCL. After stratification of the data for CD4^+ cell counts at time of diagnosis, this association is only seen in patients with low CD4^+ cell counts, while the association can no longer be found in patients with high CD4^+ cell counts. Therefore, the impact of cART adherence appears to be affected by CD4^+ cell count.
learning_objective: Interpret the concept of effect modification in epidemiological studies.

answers.explanation_why: Study generalizability is important for clinicians, as they must be able to discern whether a given study is applicable to their patient population. When a study is generalizable, it means that the results can be reasonably applied to populations beyond the target population to which the researchers initially sought to apply their findings. The phenomenon described above (differences in CD4^+ cell count strata) is not related to generalizability.
In this case, the researchers used a stratified analysis to analyze the data, but this should not be confused with stratified sampling, which is part of the process of study design (not analysis).

Random error refers to unpredictable variations in measurement (or in the study population) that have no net effect on the relationship of interest but do lower the overall precision of the measures being studied. There is always some degree of random error in any study, but the described phenomenon (differences between the two CD4^+ cell count strata) is not related to random error.

Confounding occurs when a third variable associated with both the exposure and the outcome creates a spurious association. If CD4^+  cell count was a confounder in this case, the apparent relationship between cART adherence and DLBCL risk would disappear once the data was stratified by the confounder (i.e., it would be the same for both CD4^+ cell count < 200/mm^3 and CD4+ cell count > 200/mm^3 groups).

A systematic error in the collection or analysis of data is known as a bias. If there was a bias in this case, there would be a difference in the quality of the data collected among the different groups. Although there could be significant systematic error in the design of this study, the described phenomenon (differences between the two CD4^+ cell count strata) is not related to systematic error.

Effect modification occurs when the magnitude of the relationship between the exposure and the outcome of interest is modified by a third variable. In this case, the association between the exposure (cART) and the outcome (DLBCL risk) is modified by a third variable (CD4 count). Consequently, stratification of the patients by CD4+ cell count reveals that the relationship between cART adherence and DLBCL risk is present for CD4^+ cell count < 200/mm^3 but not CD4^+  cell count > 200/mm^3. In other words, low CD4 count acts as an effect modifier, as it increases the risk of DLBCL in patients with poor cART adherence.

Effect modification is often confused with confounding. These two concepts can be differentiated by performing a stratified analysis: when the population is stratified according to a factor that is thought to be a confounder or effect modifier, different results will be seen if it is a confounder (no significant difference between strata) or if it is an effect modifier (significant difference between the strata).

question_text: A first-year medical student is analyzing data in a nationwide cancer registry. She identified a group of patients who had recently undergone surgery for epithelial ovarian cancer and achieved a complete clinical response to chemotherapy. Some of these patients had been scheduled to receive annual abdominal CTs while other patients had not been scheduled for such routine imaging surveillance. The medical student then identified a subgroup of patients who have developed recurrent metastatic disease despite their previous complete clinical response to chemotherapy and surgery. She compared patients who were diagnosed with metastatic cancer during routine follow-up imaging with patients who were diagnosed with metastatic cancer based on clinical symptoms at routine follow-up history and physical exams. She found that the average survival of patients who underwent routine imaging was four months longer than the survival of their peers who were diagnosed based on history and physical exam. Which of the following would most likely be found in this study?
content_preview: A first-year medical student is analyzing data in a nationwide cancer registry. She identified a group of patients who had recently undergone surgery for epithelial ovarian cancer and achieved a complete clinical response to chemotherapy. Some of these patients had been scheduled to receive annual abdominal CTs while other patients had not been scheduled for such routine imaging surveillance. The medical student then identified a subgroup of patients who have developed recurrent metastatic disease despite their previous complete clinical response to chemotherapy and surgery. She compared patients who were diagnosed with metastatic cancer during routine follow-up imaging with patients who were diagnosed with metastatic cancer based on clinical symptoms at routine follow-up history and physical exams. She found that the average survival of patients who underwent routine imaging was four months longer than the survival of their peers who were diagnosed based on history and physical exam. Which of the following would most likely be found in this study?
hint: Survival in patients with metastatic epithelial ovarian cancer may appear longer if measured from the time of diagnosis to the time of death even though survival may remain the same if measured from the onset of disease to the time of death.
learning_objective: Recall the concept of lead-time bias in survival analysis studies.

answers.explanation_why: Observer bias is a type of bias that occurs when knowledge or expectations of the individuals collecting the data affects the investigation, e.g., if the researcher's knowledge of the patients' exposure statuses influenced the classification of patients as cases or noncases. There is nothing here to suggest that the diagnosis of metastatic cancer by the radiologists or other physicians was influenced by factors other than objective evidence of disease on screening or at presentation.

Lead time is the time between the detection of a disease through screening and its clinical presentation. Lead-time bias results from deducing a longer survival from earlier disease detection while disregarding the time from detection to disease onset. In other words, survival may appear longer if measured from the time of diagnosis to the time of death, even though it remains the same if measured from the time of disease onset to the time of death. Lead-time bias can be overcome by measuring the back-end survival, i.e., adjusting the survival according to the severity of the disease at the time of diagnosis.

See “Potential sources of bias in screening tests” table.

Confounding bias is a type of bias in which an association is assumed to exist between an exposure and outcome when, in fact, a third variable (the confounder) that was not included in the study is associated with both the exposure and the outcome. There is no information contained in the question stem that suggests the apparent relationship between screening for metastatic cancer and survival is distorted by a third variable.

Information bias can occur if information is gathered differently between the treatment and control group. Information bias may occur if the sample group of participants screened for metastatic epithelial ovarian cancer were a mix of patients screened with ultrasound and CT, or if the calculator used to count the number of patients screened with ultrasound or CT were broken. There is no evidence of such error in measurement based on the information provided in the question stem.

There is generally a longer period of time between disease onset and clinical manifestation in patients with slowly progressing disease compared to those with rapid disease progression. Therefore, the opportunity for detecting disease is greater in cases where the disease progress more slowly. Subsequently, a disproportionately high number of slowly progressing diseases are detected through screening, which is known as length-time bias. This may create a false impression that a screening test improves outcome or prognosis. A classic example is a cancer screening test that is assumed to improve survival rate but actually detects a higher number of asymptomatic, slow-growing tumors, i.e., the calculated survival rate is higher than the actual survival rate due to disproportionally more study participants with less aggressive disease.

Surveillance bias is a type of bias in which a disease is diagnosed more frequently in a sample population than in the general population due to the increased testing and monitoring within that sample. In this case, recurrent ovarian cancer was detected earlier in the group that underwent close surveillance with imaging. However, while this may have influenced the calculation of survival times, it did not skew the outcome of this study itself.

question_text: A group of 6 college students with multiple sclerosis (MS) was evaluated for flares in a neurology clinic. The results are shown in the figure. Each row represents a patient. The gray bars represent the duration of the flare. The arrowheads indicate that the MS flare was already present before and/or persisted beyond the timeframe of the study. Based on the figure, which of the following is the most accurate statement about MS flares in this group of students?
content_preview: A group of 6 college students with multiple sclerosis (MS) was evaluated for flares in a neurology clinic. The results are shown in the figure. Each row represents a patient. The gray bars represent the duration of the flare. The arrowheads indicate that the MS flare was already present before and/or persisted beyond the timeframe of the study. Based on the figure, which of the following is the most accurate statement about MS flares in this group of students?
hint: It is important to distinguish between new cases (e.g., new or recurring MS flares), preexisting cases, total population, and at-risk population when calculating measures of disease frequency.
learning_objective: Interpret disease frequency measures, and calculate incidence.

answers.content: Incidence from April 1^st to June 1^st was 3
answers.explanation_why: Only 2 patients (patients 3 and 5) developed MS flares between April and June. Patients 1 and 2 had already been diagnosed with an MS flare before the beginning of April (the incidence includes new cases only).

answers.content: Incidence during the month of May was 2
answers.explanation_why:
Incidence is the number of new cases that develop during a specified period of time. Based on the figure, 2 new cases appeared in May (patient 3 and patient 5 developed an MS flare).

The incidence proportion (cumulative incidence, incidence proportion) is the proportion of the disease-free population that developed the disease during a specified time period. Incidence rate (person-time rate) is the number of new cases divided by the total person-time at risk (the time each person was at risk, totaled for all persons in the study). Incidence proportion and incidence rate are measures that represent the likelihood of developing the disease during a time period.

Prevalence is the proportion of a population that has a condition at a specified point in time (point prevalence) or during a specified time period (period prevalence).

answers.content: Prevalence during the month of December was 50%
answers.explanation_why: Prevalence is the proportion of a population that has a condition at a specified point in time (point prevalence) or during a specified time period (period prevalence). During December, 2 of the 6 persons (∼ 33.3 %) had MS flares (patient 2 and 6).

answers.content: Incidence during the month of February was 3
answers.explanation_why: Incidence is the number of new cases of a disease that develop during a specified period of time. Only 1 patient (patient 1) developed an MS flare in February. While patients 2 and 3 did have an MS flare in February, the onset of their symptoms began before February and therefore does not factor into the incidence for that month.

Prevalence is the proportion of a population that has a condition at a specified point in time (point prevalence) or during a specified time period (period prevalence). Of the six students evaluated, all but one (patient 4) had MS flares during this year at some point or for its entirety. The prevalence for the year is therefore 5/6.

answers.content: Prevalence of the disease on May 15 was 4/6
answers.explanation_why: Prevalence is the proportion of a population that has a condition at a specified point in time (point prevalence) or during a specified time period (period prevalence). On May 15^th, 3 persons had MS flares (patients 2, 3, and 5) and the prevalence was 3/6.

answers.content: Incidence proportion during this year was 3/6
answers.explanation_why: The incidence proportion is the proportion of the disease-free population that developed the disease during a specified time period. In this case, the at-risk population for the year is 5 persons. Patient 2, who had a preexisting MS flare that continued for the entire year, is excluded, and patient 3, who had a preexisting MS flare but became disease-free (and hence at-risk) in March, is included. Since 4 of the 5 individuals at risk developed MS flares, the incidence proportion during the year was 4/5.
