question_text: A new assay for Lyme disease has been developed. While the assay has been tested extensively in Maine, a group of investigators is planning to test it in Southern California. In comparison to the assay's performance in Maine, testing the assay in Southern California would affect the performance of the assay in which of the following ways?
content_preview: A new assay for Lyme disease has been developed. While the assay has been tested extensively in Maine, a group of investigators is planning to test it in Southern California. In comparison to the assay's performance in Maine, testing the assay in Southern California would affect the performance of the assay in which of the following ways?
hint: Lyme disease primarily occurs in the Northeast and upper Midwest of the US; its prevalence is much lower in Southern California than in Maine. Prevalence (pretest probability) affects posttest probabilities, i.e., negative predictive value (NPV) and positive predictive value (PPV).
learning_objective: Recall how disease prevalence affects predictive values of a diagnostic test.

answers.content: Decreased negative likelihood ratio of the Lyme disease assay
answers.explanation_why: The negative likelihood ratio is calculated from the sensitivity and specificity, which are intrinsic properties of a diagnostic test that are not affected by disease prevalence. Therefore, the negative likelihood ratio of the assay will not change when it is tested in Southern California instead of Maine.

answers.content: Lower likelihood that a patient without Lyme disease truly has a negative test
answers.explanation_why: The likelihood that a patient without the disease will have a negative test result is the specificity. Specificity is an intrinsic characteristic of the test that is not affected by disease prevalence.

answers.content: Greater likelihood that an individual with a positive test will truly have Lyme disease
answers.explanation_why: The likelihood that an individual with a positive test truly does have the disease is the PPV. The PPV increases when a diagnostic test is used in a population with a higher prevalence of disease (i.e., the disease is more common), but in this case, the assay was tested in a population with a lower prevalence of disease (Southern California) compared to the first population in which it was tested (Maine). Consequently, the PPV of the assay will be lower in Southern California than in Maine (i.e., the likelihood of true positives will decrease).

answers.content: Decreased positive likelihood ratio of the Lyme disease assay
answers.explanation_why: The positive likelihood ratio is calculated from the sensitivity and specificity, which are intrinsic properties of a diagnostic test that are not affected by disease prevalence. Therefore, the positive likelihood ratio of the assay will not change when it is tested in Southern California instead of Maine.

answers.content: Lower likelihood that a patient with Lyme disease will truly have a positive test
answers.explanation_why: The likelihood that a patient with a disease will have a positive test result is the sensitivity. Sensitivity is an intrinsic characteristic of the test that is not affected by disease prevalence.

answers.content: Greater likelihood that an individual with a negative test will truly not have Lyme disease
answers.explanation_why:
The likelihood that an individual with a negative test result truly does not have the disease (i.e., that it is a true negative) is the NPV. The NPV is inversely related to prevalence; NPV increases as disease prevalence decreases. In this case, performing the assay for Lyme disease in Southern California (low prevalence) instead of in Maine (high prevalence) will result in an increased NPV (i.e., the likelihood of true negatives will increase). PPV is directly related to prevalence; PPV decreases as disease prevalence decreases.

Prevalence does not influence intrinsic test characteristics, i.e. sensitivity, specificity, negative likelihood ratio, and positive likelihood ratio.

question_text: A data analyst is putting 100 systolic blood pressure values into a spreadsheet for a research study on hypertension during pregnancy. The majority of systolic blood pressure values fall between 130 and 145. For one of the study participants, she accidentally types “1400” instead of “140”. Which of the following statements is most likely to be correct?
content_preview: A data analyst is putting 100 systolic blood pressure values into a spreadsheet for a research study on hypertension during pregnancy. The majority of systolic blood pressure values fall between 130 and 145. For one of the study participants, she accidentally types “1400” instead of “140”. Which of the following statements is most likely to be correct?
hint: Typing in a much larger blood pressure reading (an outlier) will result in a positively skewed distribution.
learning_objective: Recall the effects of a positively skewed distribution on measures of central tendency.

answers.explanation_why: Systematic errors (bias) are reproducible inaccuracies resulting from an inappropriate experimental design or inaccurate measuring or classification of variables. The accidental inclusion of an outlier is a random error, which can be decreased with repeated measurement or by increasing the sample size.

answers.content: The median is now equal to the mode
answers.explanation_why: In a normal bell-shaped distribution of data, all measures of central tendency are equal (median = mode = mean). Since the outlier results in a positively skewed distribution, median and mode are no longer equal. The more skewed a distribution, the greater the difference between the measures of central tendency.

answers.content: The standard deviation of the data set is decreased
answers.explanation_why: On the contrary, measures of precision, such as the standard deviation (SD) and variance (statistics), are increased as a result of this error. SD and variance reflect the spread of data, which becomes wider as a result of outliers.

answers.content: The mode is now greater than the mean
answers.explanation_why: On the contrary, the mode is now smaller than the mean. While the mean corresponds to the sum of values divided by the number of values in the set (e.g., (130 + 145 + 1400)/ 3 = 558), the mode is the most frequent value of a data set and thus more resistant to outliers (it lies somewhere between 130 and 145 in this case).

answers.content: The range of the data set is unaffected
answers.explanation_why: The range of the data set has increased since it has changed from 130–145 to 130–1400. Outliers result in widening of the range of data.

answers.content: The median is now smaller than the mean
answers.explanation_why:
Typing in a much larger blood pressure reading in relatively small sample sizes will result in a smaller median than mean. While the median is the midpoint of a data set when the values are arranged in ascending order (e.g., 130, 145, 1400; median = 145), the mean corresponds to the sum of the values divided by the number of values in the set (e.g., (130 + 145 + 1400)/ 3 = 558) and is thus particularly susceptible to the influence of outliers.

While in a perfectly symmetrical distribution of data, median, mode, and mean are equal, in a skewed distribution, the mean is being shifted to the direction of the skew. In these situations, the median and mode are better in representing the central location of the data, as they are more resistant to outliers.

images.title: Distribution of data
images.description:
The middle graph shows a perfectly symmetrical distribution of data (bell curve). In such a distribution, all measures of central tendency (mean, median, and mode) have the same value.The left graph shows a positive skew (outliers shifting the mean towards higher values), whereas the right graph shows a negative skew (outliers shifting the mean towards lower values).
The median and the mode are more resistant to outliers than the mean. Note that the mode does not change since it represents the most commonly measured value within the data set.

question_text: A first-year medical student is conducting a summer project with his medical school's pediatrics department using adolescent intelligence quotient (IQ) data from a database of 1,252 patients. He observes that the mean IQ of the dataset is 100. The standard deviation was calculated to be 10. Assuming that the values are normally distributed, approximately 87% of the measurements will fall in between which of the following limits?
content_preview: A first-year medical student is conducting a summer project with his medical school's pediatrics department using adolescent intelligence quotient (IQ) data from a database of 1,252 patients. He observes that the mean IQ of the dataset is 100. The standard deviation was calculated to be 10. Assuming that the values are normally distributed, approximately 87% of the measurements will fall in between which of the following limits?
hint: It is not necessary to know the z score to answer this question. Knowing what percentage of values fall within 1 standard deviation (SD), 2 SDs, and 3 SDs of the mean is sufficient to arrive at the right answer.
learning_objective: Calculate the range for a proportion of measurements based on a normal distribution's standard deviation and mean.

answers.explanation_why: This range (statistics) represents 99.7% (3 SD ≅ 30 IQ points) of IQ measurements, but not the range that includes 87% of all IQ levels measured.
This range (statistics) represents almost 100% of IQ measurements (> 3 SDs from the mean), but not the range that includes 87% of all IQ levels measured.

This is the only answer option that lies between 1 and 2 standard deviations from the mean. In a normal distribution, approximately 87% of measurements fall within 1.5 SDs from the mean (± 15 IQ points in this case). While knowing this specific value is not necessary, it is important to remember the values for 1 SD (68%), 2 SDs (95%), and 3 SDs (99.7%).

images.title: Bell curve and standard deviations
images.description:
Bell curve showing a normal distribution of values around a given mean value.Approx. 68% of values fall within the range of -1 SD to +1 SD from the mean.
Approx. 95% of values fall within the range of -2 SDs to +2 SDs from the mean.
Approx. 99.7% of values fall within the range of -3 SDs to +3 SDs from the mean.(SD = standard deviation)

answers.explanation_why: This range (statistics) represents 95% (2 SD ≅ 20 IQ points) of IQ measurements, but not the range that includes 87% of all IQ levels measured.
This range (statistics) represents 68% (1 SD ≅ 10 IQ points) of IQ measurements, but not the range that includes 87% of all IQ levels measured.
This range (statistics) represents < 50% of IQ measurements (< 1 SD from the mean), but not the range that includes 87% of all IQ levels measured.

question_text: An inpatient psychiatrist recently had two patients who developed serious gastrointestinal infections while taking clozapine. He was concerned that his patients had developed agranulocytosis, a relatively rare but dangerous adverse event associated with clozapine. When the psychiatrist checked the absolute neutrophil count (ANC) of both patients, one was 450/mm^3, while the other was 700/mm^3 (N = 1500/mm^3). According to the clozapine REMS (Risk Evaluation and Mitigation Strategy) program, severe neutropenia in clozapine recipients has often been defined as an absolute neutrophil count (ANC) less than 500/mm^3. Changing the cutoff value to 750/mm^3 would affect the test performance of ANC with regard to agranulocytosis in which of the following ways?
content_preview: An inpatient psychiatrist recently had two patients who developed serious gastrointestinal infections while taking clozapine. He was concerned that his patients had developed agranulocytosis, a relatively rare but dangerous adverse event associated with clozapine. When the psychiatrist checked the absolute neutrophil count (ANC) of both patients, one was 450/mm3, while the other was 700/mm3 (N = 1500/mm3). According to the clozapine REMS (Risk Evaluation and Mitigation Strategy) program, severe neutropenia in clozapine recipients has often been defined as an absolute neutrophil count (ANC) less than 500/mm3. Changing the cutoff value to 750/mm3 would affect the test performance of ANC with regard to agranulocytosis in which of the following ways?
hint: Keep in mind that this is a test in which a low cutoff value is diagnostic. Raising the cutoff from 500/mm^3 to 750/mm^3 broadens the inclusion criteria, meaning that more patients who truly have agranulocytosis test positive. However, broadening the criteria for agranulocytosis has a disadvantage.
learning_objective: Recall how changes in cutoff values affect test sensitivity and specificity.

answers.explanation_why: Raising the cutoff value to 750/mm^3 decreases the number of true negatives (i.e., individuals without agranulocytosis who correctly test negative).

Raising the cutoff value to 750/mm^3 results in a decreased positive predictive value (PPV), as PPV = True Positives/(True Positives + False Positives). PPV decreases because the number of false positives increases more than the number of true positives.

Raising the cutoff value increases the negative predictive value (NPV), as NPV = True Negatives/(True Negatives + False Negatives). NPV increases because the number of false negatives decreases more than the number of true negatives.
Raising the cutoff value to 750/mm^3 increases the number of true positives (i.e., individuals with agranulocytosis who correctly test positive).
Raising the cutoff value to 750/mm^3 decreases the specificity of the test, so fewer individuals who truly do not have agranulocytosis (true negatives) are correctly identified as negative.

The effect of changing a cutoff value depends on whether the test requires a high cutoff value (e.g., tumor marker for cancer, lipase for pancreatitis) or a low cutoff value for diagnosis (e.g., this test for agranulocytosis). For this test, raising the cutoff value to 750/mm^3 broadens the inclusion criteria for agranulocytosis, increasing the rate of true and false positives while decreasing the rate of true and false negatives. Broadening the inclusion criteria in this test also increases sensitivity and decreases specificity. In addition, broadening inclusion criteria in a low cutoff value test decreases the test's positive predictive value while increasing its negative predictive value.

Be aware: In tests for which a high cutoff value is diagnostic, raising the cutoff value increases specificity and decreases sensitivity. By contrast, in agranulocytosis, a low cutoff value is diagnostic; therefore, raising the cutoff has the opposite effect.

Raising the cutoff value to 750/mm^3 increases the sensitivity of the test because it decreases the number of false negatives. The true positives increase, but because the false negatives decrease, the denominator increases by less than the numerator, increasing the result of the formula for sensitivity: True Positives/(True Positives + False Negatives). As a result, more individuals who truly have agranulocytosis (true positives) are identified as having the condition.

question_text:
A cohort study was conducted to investigate the impact of posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) on asthma symptoms in a group of firefighters who worked at Ground Zero during the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks in New York City and developed asthma in the attack's aftermath. The study compared patients who had PTSD with those who did not have PTSD in order to determine if PTSD is associated with worse asthma control. During a follow-up period of 12 months, the researchers found that patients with PTSD had a greater number of hospitalizations for asthma exacerbations (RR = 2.0, 95% confidence interval = 1.4–2.5) after adjusting for medical comorbidities, psychiatric comorbidities other than PTSD, and sociodemographic variables. Results are shown:

≥ 1 asthma exacerbation
No asthma exacerbations

PTSD
80
80

No PTSD
50
150

Based on these results, what proportion of asthma hospitalizations in patients with PTSD could be attributed to PTSD?
content_preview: A cohort study was conducted to investigate the impact of posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) on asthma symptoms in a group of firefighters who worked at Ground Zero during the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks in New York City and developed asthma in the attack's aftermath. The study compared patients who had PTSD with those who did not have PTSD in order to determine if PTSD is associated with worse asthma control. During a follow-up period of 12 months, the researchers found that patients with PTSD had a greater number of hospitalizations for asthma exacerbations (RR = 2.0, 95% confidence interval = 1.4–2.5) after adjusting for medical comorbidities, psychiatric comorbidities other than PTSD, and sociodemographic variables. Results are shown: ≥ 1 asthma exacerbation No asthma exacerbations PTSD 80 80 No PTSD 50 150 Based on these results, what proportion of asthma hospitalizations in patients with PTSD could be attributed to PTSD?
hint: This question asks for the attributable risk percent (ARP) i.e., the proportion of excess risk in the exposed group attributable to the exposure. Attributable risk (AR), in contrast, measures the absolute risk difference between the exposed and unexposed groups. You can calculate ARP using the 2x2 table or the relative risk (RR).
learning_objective: Calculate the attributable risk percent (ARP) using relative risk.

answers.explanation_why: 2.0 is the relative risk (RR), i.e., the risk of a patient with PTSD requiring hospitalization for asthma exacerbations compared to the risk of requiring hospitalization for asthma exacerbations without PTSD. The RR can be calculated by dividing the incidence of asthma exacerbations in PTSD patients by the incidence of asthma exacerbations in patients without PTSD: (80/160)/(50/200) = 0.5/0.25 = 2. A relative risk > 1.0 indicates a positive association and increased likelihood of asthma exacerbations in patients with PTSD. However, the RR does not measure the magnitude of the excess risk attributable to PTSD. To estimate the proportion of asthma hospitalizations attributable to PTSD in patients with PTSD, the ARP needs to be calculated.

0.25 is the AR, i.e., the difference between the risk of asthma exacerbation in the PTSD group and the group of patients without PTSD. The AR is calculated by taking the absolute risk of PTSD patients and subtracting the absolute risk of patients without PTSD. In this case, (80/160) - (50/200) = (0.5 - 0.25) = 0.25 or 25%. This means that patients in the PTSD group have an excess risk of 25% of developing an asthma exacerbation compared to patients in the group without PTSD.

3.0 is the odds ratio (OR), i.e., the probability of PTSD in a patient with an asthma exacerbation that requires hospitalization. The OR can be calculated as the odds of disease in the exposed group divided by the odds of disease in the unexposed group. In this case: OR = (80/80)/(50/150) = 1/(1/3) = 3. An OR > 1 means that there is an increased odds of patients with asthma exacerbation having PTSD.

The proportion of asthma hospitalizations attributable to PTSD in the PTSD group is the ARP, which can be calculated based on the RR: ARP = (RR - 1)/RR. The RR can be calculated by dividing the incidence of asthma exacerbations in PTSD patients by the incidence of asthma exacerbations in patients without PTSD: (80/160)/(50/200) = 0.5/0.25 = 2. In this case, ARP = (2.0 - 1)/2.0 = 0.50. This means that 50% of the asthma exacerbations in the PTSD group can be attributed to PTSD.

Alternatively, the ARP can be calculated from the 2x2 table: ARP = attributable risk/risk in the exposed group. In this case, the risk in the exposed group is 80/160 = 0.5 and the AR = (80/160) - (50/200) = (0.5 - 0.25) = 0.25. Consequently, ARP = 0.25/0.5 = 0.50 or 50%.

4.0 is the number needed to harm (NNH), i.e., the number of individuals who need to be exposed (in this case, meaning the presence of PTSD) before one person develops an asthma exacerbation. NNH is calculated as: 1/attributable risk (AR). To determine the attributable risk here, the incidence of asthma exacerbations in patients with PTSD is subtracted from the incidence of asthma exacerbations in patients without PTSD. In this case, NNH is: 1/((80/160) - (50/200)) = 1/(0.5 - 0.25) = 1/0.25 = 4. In other words, 4 people need to develop PTSD in order to cause an asthma exacerbation in 1 patient.

question_text:
The division chief of general internal medicine at an academic medical center is interested in reducing 30-day readmissions for diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) in elderly patients. Her research team decided to follow 587 patients over the age of 65 who have recently been admitted to the hospital for DKA for a 30-day period. At the end of 30 days, she identified 100 patients who were readmitted to the hospital and examined risk factors associated with readmission. The main results of her study are summarized in the table:

Episodes of DKA in the past 3 years

RR (95% CI)
P-value

None
1.00 (Reference)

1–2

1.23 (1.04–1.36)
< 0.05

3–4

1.48 (1.38–1.59)
< 0.001

5+

2.20 (1.83–2.51)
< 0.001

Which of the following aspects of the results best supports a causal relationship between a history of DKA and 30-day readmission risk for DKA?
content_preview: The division chief of general internal medicine at an academic medical center is interested in reducing 30-day readmissions for diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) in elderly patients. Her research team decided to follow 587 patients over the age of 65 who have recently been admitted to the hospital for DKA for a 30-day period. At the end of 30 days, she identified 100 patients who were readmitted to the hospital and examined risk factors associated with readmission. The main results of her study are summarized in the table: Episodes of DKA in the past 3 years RR (95% CI) P-value None 1.00 (Reference) 1–2 1.23 (1.04–1.36) < 0.05 3–4 1.48 (1.38–1.59) < 0.001 5+ 2.20 (1.83–2.51) < 0.001 Which of the following aspects of the results best supports a causal relationship between a history of DKA and 30-day readmission risk for DKA?
hint: Some of the key criteria for causality include: (a) exposure preceding the outcome, (b) strength of association, (c) increased amounts of exposure leading to increased risk, (d) consistent results when replicated in different settings, (e) a plausible explanation.
learning_objective: Interpret criteria for causality in epidemiological studies.

answers.explanation_why: The p-value is a measure of statistical significance, but it has no bearing on causality. One of the criteria for causality is strength of association, which refers to the magnitude of the study's outcome measure (relative risk or odds ratio, depending on the study design), not to the p-value.

answers.content: Confidence intervals that do not cross 1.0
answers.explanation_why: The confidence interval gives the estimated range of values that is 95% likely to include the unknown “true” value in the study population. In this study, the confidence intervals for the relative risk values do not cross 1.0. This implies that there are statistically significant differences between the risk of readmission in patients with no history of DKA and the risk of readmission in patients with a history of DKA. This implies statistical significance but has no bearing on causality.

This is not a case-control study but rather a prospective cohort study. In a case-control study, the cases of an outcome of interest would first be selected, followed by suitable controls. The measure would be reported as an odds ratio, not relative risk. This is because, in a case-control study, actual risk cannot be estimated because a smaller number of controls and cases selected from the population are being studied rather than an entire population. In this prospective cohort study, 587 patients with recent admissions for DKA were followed and 100 cases and 487 controls were identified over time.

High odds ratio is incorrect because this study is a prospective cohort study, which uses relative risk as its measure of association rather than the odds ratio, which would be used in a case-control study. Actual risk (AR) cannot be estimated in a case-control study because a smaller number of controls and cases selected from the population are being studied rather than an entire population.

The relative risk (RR) of readmission increases as the number of previous episodes of DKA increases, which means that there is a dose-response gradient. Increased amounts of exposure (in this case, prior episodes of DKA) leading to an increased risk of the outcome (in this case, readmission) is one of the criteria required to establish causality in epidemiological studies. Dose-response relationships are quite common in the epidemiologic literature. Other examples include the relationship between the amount of tobacco smoked and mortality from lung cancer, an incremental increases in blood pressure or left ventricle hypertrophy correlating with increased myocardial infarction risk, and an incremental increases in clozapine doses correlating with increased risk of seizures in patients with schizophrenia.

question_text: A retrospective cohort study is conducted to assess the risk of placenta accreta at all statewide medical centers. During chart review, it is found that a history of cesarean birth is associated with a statistically significant increased risk of placenta accreta. The relative risk (RR) of placenta accreta for patients with a history of cesarean birth is 1.23, with a P value of 0.03 and a 95% confidence interval (CI) of 1.12–1.46. In the context of this study, which of the following statements is the best interpretation of the observed association between cesarean birth and placenta accreta?
content_preview: A retrospective cohort study is conducted to assess the risk of placenta accreta at all statewide medical centers. During chart review, it is found that a history of cesarean birth is associated with a statistically significant increased risk of placenta accreta. The relative risk (RR) of placenta accreta for patients with a history of cesarean birth is 1.23, with a P value of 0.03 and a 95% confidence interval (CI) of 1.12–1.46. In the context of this study, which of the following statements is the best interpretation of the observed association between cesarean birth and placenta accreta?
learning_objective: Interpret the meaning of a 95% confidence interval in the context of a study's results.

answers.content: The true population relative risk is likely between 1.12 and 1.46.
answers.explanation_why: A CI is a range of values in which the true population parameter is likely to lie, based on the sample data. In this study, the 95% CI for the RR of placenta accreta in patients with a history of cesarean birth is 1.12–1.46. In other words, with repeated sampling, 95% of calculated CIs would contain the true RR. The Cl is determined by the alpha value, which is typically set at 5%, using the following formula: 100% - alpha = Cl. The CI does not guarantee that the true RR has a 95% probability of lying within a given observed interval but rather reflects the reliability of the estimation process. The reported interval of 1.12–1.46 indicates a statistically significant association between a history of cesarean birth and increased risk of placenta accreta because the CI does not contain the null value (i.e., RR = 1.0). Reporting both the point estimate (RR = 1.23) and the CI allows for assessment of the strength and precision of the observed association; a narrower interval indicates greater precision.

answers.content: There is a 3% probability that the observed relative risk of 1.23 is due to chance alone.
answers.explanation_why: The P value is the probability that the result of a given statistical test will be at least as extreme as the result actually observed on repeat testing, assuming that the null hypothesis is true. Accordingly, the P value of 0.03 in this study signifies that there is a 3% probability that the observed sample RR will be at least as extreme as 1.23, assuming that a prior cesarean birth does not increase the risk of placenta accreta. In this case, if there were no association between prior cesarean birth and placenta accreta (i.e., RR = 1.0) and the study was repeated 100 times, a relative risk of ≥ 1.23 would only be found 3 times (i.e., 3% of the repeated studies). However, this does not mean that there is a 3% probability that the observed RR is due to chance. The P value quantifies the probability of the data given the null hypothesis rather than the probability of the hypothesis given the data.

answers.content: There is a 5% probability that the true population relative risk is lower than 1.12.
answers.explanation_why: The 95% CI calculated from a single study does not provide the probability that the true RR lies below or above any given parameter. However, with repeated sampling, in symmetrical (e.g., normal) distributions, approximately 2.5% of these intervals will lie above the true parameter, and approximately 2.5% will lie below it. For skewed distributions such as the RR, the CI is asymmetrical, and these tail probabilities are not equal.

answers.content: There is a 95% probability that the true population relative risk is higher than 1.12.
answers.explanation_why: The 95% CI calculated from a single study does not provide the probability that the true RR lies below or above any given parameter. In frequentist statistics, the true population parameter from a single study (here, the true RR) is fixed and does not have a probability distribution. The variability originates from the sample data and the calculated CI, not from the parameter itself. For this study, it is incorrect to say there is a 95% probability that the true RR is higher than 1.12, because the true RR is a fixed parameter that either does or does not fall within this specific calculated interval.

answers.content: Statistical significance cannot be inferred from the 95% CI in the study.
answers.explanation_why: Statistical significance is established when the 95% CI for an RR does not contain the null value (i.e., RR = 1.0). In this study, the interval is 1.12–1.46, indicating a statistically significant association.

question_text: A 21-year-old woman is diagnosed with a rare subtype of anti-NMDA encephalitis. During the diagnostic workup, she was found to have an ovarian teratoma. Her physician is curious whether ovarian teratoma is a risk factor for the development of anti-NMDA encephalitis. A causal relationship between this subtype of anti-NMDA encephalitis and ovarian teratomas is suspected. The physician aims to identify patients with anti-NMDA encephalitis and subsequently evaluate them for the presence or a history of ovarian teratomas. Which of the following types of study design would be the most appropriate?
content_preview: A 21-year-old woman is diagnosed with a rare subtype of anti-NMDA encephalitis. During the diagnostic workup, she was found to have an ovarian teratoma. Her physician is curious whether ovarian teratoma is a risk factor for the development of anti-NMDA encephalitis. A causal relationship between this subtype of anti-NMDA encephalitis and ovarian teratomas is suspected. The physician aims to identify patients with anti-NMDA encephalitis and subsequently evaluate them for the presence or a history of ovarian teratomas. Which of the following types of study design would be the most appropriate?
hint: Consider that the subtype of anti-NMDA encephalitis the college student has is very rare as well as the feasibility of following a cohort of patients with ovarian teratomas and waiting for a small number of them, if any, to develop anti-NMDA encephalitis.
learning_objective: Choose the appropriate study design for rare conditions with suspected risk factors.

answers.explanation_why: A cross-sectional study would determine the prevalence of teratomas and anti-NMDA encephalitis at a specific point in time, but would not allow to draw a conclusion on chronological correlations (e.g., show that ovarian teratoma precedes anti-NMDA encephalitis).

A prospective cohort study would follow a large group of individuals over a period of time until they developed anti-NMDA encephalitis. As the subject of investigation here is an uncommon subtype of anti-NMDA encephalitis, such a study would be costly and time-consuming.

A case series describes the clinical course of similar cases but does not allow drawing conclusions about causal relationships. At best, a hypothesis can be suggested based on several observed cases. Moreover, a case series would be very susceptible to selection bias because there are no comparator groups.

Case-control studies are ideal to study conditions like uncommon subtypes of anti-NMDA encephalitis because they are the most economical way to study an outcome that is rare or has a long latency period and its associated risk factors. The comparison to a control group without anti-NMDA encephalitis helps determine the presence of risk factors that might be associated with the disease. To assess the strength of association between a risk factor and disease, the odds ratio is reported. Unlike cohort studies, case-control studies identify patients with or without the suspected outcome first (here: anti-NMDA encephalitis) and then evaluate the prevalence of the risk factor (here: ovarian teratomas) in each group retrospectively.

On a side note, case-control studies have actually found a strong association between the occurrence of ovarian teratomas in young women and anti-NMDA encephalitis. Encephalitis is considered a paraneoplastic syndrome in these patients.

images.title: Temporal aspects of different study types
images.description: Cross-sectional studies (prevalence studies, snapshot studies) are used to determine the prevalence of exposure (e.g., a risk factor) and outcome (e.g., disease) at a specific point in time.Case-control studies are used to determine whether an exposure that happened in the past is associated with a present outcome. Researchers begin by selecting patients with the disease (cases) and individuals without the disease (controls). The two groups are then compared with regard to exposure to a risk factor in the past.In prospective cohort studies, participants are divided into an exposed (e.g., to a risk factor) and an unexposed group and then followed over the course of time to determine whether there is a difference in the rate of outcome (disease) between the two groups.Retrospective cohort studies begin after the exposure and outcome of interest have already occurred. Medical records previously collected about the participants are compared to determine whether there was a difference in the rate at which the exposed and unexposed groups developed the outcome of interest in the past.In experimental studies, researchers introduce an intervention and study its effects.Randomized controlled trials aim to determine the possible effect of a specific intervention on a given population. People are randomly allocated into an intervention and control group and monitored over the course of time for outcomes of interest.

answers.explanation_why: Randomized controlled trials are used to test a treatment or intervention against another one (e.g., placebo). Here, no randomization or intervention is indicated; only observation and analysis are necessary to properly assess for the presence of an association between ovarian cancer and anti-NMDA encephalitis.

Retrospective cohort studies can be used to study rare diseases, and they are relatively inexpensive, as they mainly collect and analyze data from the past. However, retrospective cohort studies determine the risk factor first (in this case, ovarian teratoma), and then evaluate the outcome (in this case, new cases of anti-NMDA encephalitis). This researcher has already determined the outcome (i.e., anti-NMDA encephalitis) and now wants to see what risk factors are associated with it. Furthermore, while a rare disease as this subtype of anti-NMDA encephalitis could theoretically be studied in a retrospective cohort study, its low incidence would make it time-consuming and impractical to find a group of patients with ovarian teratomas and determine via chart review how many of these eventually developed anti-NMDA encephalitis.

question_text: A research group designed a study to investigate the epidemiology of syphilis in the United States. The investigators examined the total number of cases of syphilis and genitourinary chlamydia in the United States using a national health survey of a nationally representative sample of US citizens conducted in 2012. The investigators ultimately found that a history of genitourinary chlamydia infection is associated with syphilis. This study is best described as which of the following?
content_preview: A research group designed a study to investigate the epidemiology of syphilis in the United States. The investigators examined the total number of cases of syphilis and genitourinary chlamydia in the United States using a national health survey of a nationally representative sample of US citizens conducted in 2012. The investigators ultimately found that a history of genitourinary chlamydia infection is associated with syphilis. This study is best described as which of the following?
hint: This study design is analyzing prevalence data in individuals collected at a single point in time.
learning_objective: Recall the characteristics of a cross-sectional study.

answers.explanation_why: In a meta-analysis, data from multiple studies is pooled to increase statistical power and to identify discrepancies and/or common effects among studies. The research group here conducted a single study.

In a single-blind clinical trial, only researchers know who is a control or treatment candidate. This study was of an observational nature, however, and did not involve administration or testing of a treatment.

In a double-blind clinical trial, neither the researcher nor the study participants know who is a control or treatment candidate. This study was of an observational nature, however, and did not involve administration or testing of a treatment.

An ecological study assesses a whole population or community for exposures and outcomes. Here, data from a survey of citizens/individuals was collected rather than aggregate data at the population level (e.g., counting all diagnoses in a city or country).

The use of a healthcare survey to determine the prevalence of syphilis and genitourinary chlamydia at a single point in time is consistent with a cross-sectional study. A cross-sectional study determines the prevalence of variables of interest simultaneously, at a specific point in time (snapshot study). It allows conclusions to be drawn about associations between two factors (genitourinary chlamydia and syphilis) but usually not about exposure-outcome or temporal relationships (e.g., it cannot show that genitourinary chlamydia infection precedes syphilis infection or vice versa).

See “Overview of descriptive studies” table.

images.title: Temporal aspects of different study types
images.description: Cross-sectional studies (prevalence studies, snapshot studies) are used to determine the prevalence of exposure (e.g., a risk factor) and outcome (e.g., disease) at a specific point in time.Case-control studies are used to determine whether an exposure that happened in the past is associated with a present outcome. Researchers begin by selecting patients with the disease (cases) and individuals without the disease (controls). The two groups are then compared with regard to exposure to a risk factor in the past.In prospective cohort studies, participants are divided into an exposed (e.g., to a risk factor) and an unexposed group and then followed over the course of time to determine whether there is a difference in the rate of outcome (disease) between the two groups.Retrospective cohort studies begin after the exposure and outcome of interest have already occurred. Medical records previously collected about the participants are compared to determine whether there was a difference in the rate at which the exposed and unexposed groups developed the outcome of interest in the past.In experimental studies, researchers introduce an intervention and study its effects.Randomized controlled trials aim to determine the possible effect of a specific intervention on a given population. People are randomly allocated into an intervention and control group and monitored over the course of time for outcomes of interest.

answers.explanation_why: Case-control studies are helpful for determining the presence of risk factors for (rare) diseases. It starts with two groups: one with the disease of interest (case group: syphilis), and one without the disease (control group: no syphilis). The risk of exposure to a risk factor of interest (e.g., genitourinary chlamydia infection) is then determined. Here, the research group looked at data at a single point in time.

A prospective cohort study starts with individuals who are either exposed or not exposed to a particular risk factor (here genitourinary chlamydia infection). These two groups are then followed for a period of time to see if the disease of interest (syphilis) develops. In this study, however, data was collected at a single point in time and not in a longitudinal study over time. Cohort studies are well-suited to calculate disease incidence but not prevalence.
A case series is a quantitative compilation of similar individual cases. This research group used a healthcare survey, a systemic collection of data, for their study.

A retrospective cohort study starts with individuals who are either exposed or not exposed to a particular risk factor (here genitourinary chlamydia infection). A review of medical records of patients in both groups is then conducted to determine if the disease of interest (here syphilis) has developed. In this study, however, data was collected at a single point in time and not in a longitudinal study over time. Cohort studies are well-suited to calculate disease incidence but not prevalence.

question_text: A research group designed a study to investigate the epidemiology of syphilis in the United States. The investigators examined the correlation between income and rates of syphilis in neighborhoods of New York City, Los Angeles, Chicago, and Houston. Data on the annual number of notified syphilis cases in a neighborhood and the number of individuals in a neighborhood who are beneficiaries of welfare programs during the same time were provided by each city's health agency. Data on each neighborhood's total population for the same time could not be obtained and approximations from the last census were used. This study is best described as which of the following?
content_preview: A research group designed a study to investigate the epidemiology of syphilis in the United States. The investigators examined the correlation between income and rates of syphilis in neighborhoods of New York City, Los Angeles, Chicago, and Houston. Data on the annual number of notified syphilis cases in a neighborhood and the number of individuals in a neighborhood who are beneficiaries of welfare programs during the same time were provided by each city's health agency. Data on each neighborhood's total population for the same time could not be obtained and approximations from the last census were used. This study is best described as which of the following?
hint: This study gathers data on syphilis and income at the neighborhood level rather than from individuals.
learning_objective: Recall the characteristics of an ecological study.

answers.explanation_why: Cohort studies are used to determine and compare the incidence of a disease in two groups of individuals. A prospective cohort study starts with individuals who are either exposed or not exposed to a particular risk factor (e.g., low income). These two groups are then followed for a period of time to see if the disease of interest (e.g., syphilis) develops. In this study, however, data for syphilis and income were gathered from several city health agencies at the population level; no individual cases were assessed.

Cohort studies are used to determine and compare the incidence of a disease in two groups of individuals. A retrospective cohort study starts with individuals who are either exposed or not exposed to a particular risk factor (e.g., low income). A review of medical records of patients in both groups is then conducted to determine if the disease of interest (e.g., syphilis) has developed. In this study, however, data for syphilis and income were gathered from several city health agencies at the population level; no individual cases were assessed.

Case-control studies are helpful for determining the presence of risk factors for (rare) diseases. They involve two groups of individuals: one with the disease of interest (case group: patients with syphilis), and one without the disease (control group: patients without syphilis). The risk of exposure to a risk factor of interest (e.g., low income) is then determined. Here, the research group collected data at the population level rather than looking at individual cases of exposure.

In a single-blind clinical trial, only researchers know who is in the control or intervention arm of the study. This study was of an observational nature, however, and did not involve the administration or testing of an intervention.

Because the researchers relied on data from city health agencies to assess the rates of syphilis and the income level of a neighborhood, they planned an ecological study. An ecological study is an observational study that assesses aggregate data collected at the population level (e.g., the population of different countries, cities, or socioeconomic groups) for exposures and/or outcomes. Ecological studies are well suited to the initial investigation of correlational hypotheses. However, they do not allow conclusions related to individuals to be drawn (e.g., personal risk of developing syphilis in a patient with low income).

See “Overview of descriptive studies” table.
A case series is a quantitative compilation of similar individual cases. This research group engaged in a systemic study of syphilis at the population level.

In a double-blind clinical trial, neither the researcher nor the study participants know who is in the control or intervention arm of the study. This study was of an observational nature, however, and did not involve the administration or testing of an intervention.

A cross-sectional study determines the prevalence of variables of interest by gathering data at the level of individuals at a specific point in time (snapshot study). Here, the investigators gathered data on syphilis and income on a neighborhood-by-neighborhood basis, which is characteristic of a different type of study design.

In a meta-analysis, data from multiple studies are pooled to increase statistical power and to identify discrepancies between and/or common effects among studies. Here, the research group conducted a single study.

question_text: A research group designs a study to investigate the epidemiology of syphilis in the United States. By reviewing medical records, the investigators identify a group of patients who were active cocaine users and did not have a history of syphilis as of one year ago. Another group of patients with no history of cocaine use and no history of syphilis infection as of one year ago is also identified. The researchers examine the medical records to determine whether the patients who were actively using cocaine were more likely to have developed syphilis over a 6-month period. The study ultimately finds that the rate of syphilis was 30% higher in patients who actively used cocaine compared to patients who had never used cocaine. This study is best described as which of the following?
content_preview: A research group designs a study to investigate the epidemiology of syphilis in the United States. By reviewing medical records, the investigators identify a group of patients who were active cocaine users and did not have a history of syphilis as of one year ago. Another group of patients with no history of cocaine use and no history of syphilis infection as of one year ago is also identified. The researchers examine the medical records to determine whether the patients who were actively using cocaine were more likely to have developed syphilis over a 6-month period. The study ultimately finds that the rate of syphilis was 30% higher in patients who actively used cocaine compared to patients who had never used cocaine. This study is best described as which of the following?
hint: In this research design, both the exposure (cocaine use) and outcome (syphilis) have occurred before the start of the study.
learning_objective: Recall the characteristics of a retrospective cohort study.

answers.explanation_why:
A prospective cohort study starts with identifying individuals who are either exposed or not exposed to a particular risk factor (e.g., cocaine use). However, in a prospective cohort study, participants are monitored for development of the outcome of interest (e.g., syphilis) for a fixed period of time after the start of the study, whereas in this example, data was collected from past medical records.

Using a prospective cohort study to research the relationship between cocaine use and syphilis infection would be time-consuming and, more importantly, ethically questionable.

In a metaanalysis, data from multiple studies is pooled to increase statistical power and to identify discrepancies between and/or common effects among studies. Here, the research group conducted a single study.

An ecological study is an observational study in which aggregate data collected at the population level (e.g., the population of different countries, cities, or socioeconomic groups) is assessed for exposures and/or outcomes. For instance, rather than collecting data from individual patients on cocaine use and history of syphilis infection, an ecological study might involve the collection of data from individual cities or communities.

A case series is a quantitative compilation of similar individual cases and does not allow conclusions about causal relationships to be drawn. At best, a hypothesis might be suggested based on several observed cases. In a case series, there are no comparison groups, which means that relative risks cannot be determined.

In a single-blind clinical trial, only the researchers know who is in the control or intervention arm of the study. This study was of an observational nature and did not involve the administration or testing of an intervention.

In a double-blind clinical trial, neither the researcher nor the study participants know who is in the control or intervention arm of the study. This study was of an observational nature and did not involve the administration or testing of an intervention.

Because the researchers followed individual patients with a certain trait (cocaine use) to determine if they had developed syphilis via chart review (i.e., retrospectively), they conducted a retrospective cohort study. This type of study begins with the selection of individuals who are determined to have either been exposed or not exposed to a risk factor of interest based on chart review. Individuals are then assessed retrospectively to see if they have or have not developed a certain disease or outcome. Retrospective cohort studies are time-saving and relatively inexpensive, as they involve the analysis of data that has already been collected. Cohort studies are well suited to determining the incidence of a disease and allow for the relative risk (RR) of developing a disease of interest to be calculated. Here, the RR of developing syphilis is 1.3 in active cocaine users compared to patients without this risk factor.

See “Types of cohort studies” table.

images.title: Temporal aspects of different study types
images.description: Cross-sectional studies (prevalence studies, snapshot studies) are used to determine the prevalence of exposure (e.g., a risk factor) and outcome (e.g., disease) at a specific point in time.Case-control studies are used to determine whether an exposure that happened in the past is associated with a present outcome. Researchers begin by selecting patients with the disease (cases) and individuals without the disease (controls). The two groups are then compared with regard to exposure to a risk factor in the past.In prospective cohort studies, participants are divided into an exposed (e.g., to a risk factor) and an unexposed group and then followed over the course of time to determine whether there is a difference in the rate of outcome (disease) between the two groups.Retrospective cohort studies begin after the exposure and outcome of interest have already occurred. Medical records previously collected about the participants are compared to determine whether there was a difference in the rate at which the exposed and unexposed groups developed the outcome of interest in the past.In experimental studies, researchers introduce an intervention and study its effects.Randomized controlled trials aim to determine the possible effect of a specific intervention on a given population. People are randomly allocated into an intervention and control group and monitored over the course of time for outcomes of interest.

answers.explanation_why: A cross-sectional study determines the prevalence of variables of interest simultaneously, at a specific point in time (snapshot study). It would not allow conclusions to be drawn about correlations over time; it could not, for instance, show that cocaine use preceded a syphilis infection.

Case-control studies are helpful for determining the presence of risk factors for (rare) diseases. They involve two groups: one with the disease of interest (case group: syphilis), and one without the disease (control group: no syphilis). The risk of exposure to a risk factor of interest (e.g., cocaine use) is then determined. Here, the investigators had already defined the risk factor of interest (active cocaine use) and wanted to assess the outcome (new cases of syphilis). Case-control studies report the odds ratio (OR), which reflects whether patients with a certain outcome are more likely to have been exposed to the risk factor (positive association if OR > 1).

question_text: The Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ-9) is a commonly used nine-question diagnostic test for major depression. A medical student is collecting data on the test's sensitivity and specificity to validate the PHQ-9 questionnaire for his summer project. The student plots the data, forming the green line in the figure. A total score of 20 out of 27 on the PHQ-9 questionnaire, which is generally used as a cutoff for a high likelihood of severe depression, is represented by point A on the graph. If the PHQ-9 questionnaire were administered in such a way that a score of 15 out of 27 was diagnostic instead, which of the points on the graph would most accurately represent the new PHQ-9 cutoff?
content_preview: The Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ-9) is a commonly used nine-question diagnostic test for major depression. A medical student is collecting data on the test's sensitivity and specificity to validate the PHQ-9 questionnaire for his summer project. The student plots the data, forming the green line in the figure. A total score of 20 out of 27 on the PHQ-9 questionnaire, which is generally used as a cutoff for a high likelihood of severe depression, is represented by point A on the graph. If the PHQ-9 questionnaire were administered in such a way that a score of 15 out of 27 was diagnostic instead, which of the points on the graph would most accurately represent the new PHQ-9 cutoff?
hint: Every diagnostic test involves a trade-off between sensitivity and specificity. Sensitivity is increased at the expense of specificity when the cutoff of the PHQ-9 questionnaire is lowered.
learning_objective: Interpret receiver operating characteristic curves, and recall how changing the test cutoff affects sensitivity and specificity.

answers.explanation_why: Changing the cutoff value from 20 to 15 out of 27 points affects the sensitivity and specificity of the PHQ-9 questionnaire and, thus, the position of the cutoff on the ROC curve as well.

Point B on the ROC curve represents the new cutoff point for severe depression. In ROC curves, the y-axis represents the sensitivity (true positive rate) and the x-axis corresponds to 1 - specificity (false positive rate). By lowering the cutoff from 20 to 15 out of 27 points, more people will be diagnosed as severely depressed. Thus, the sensitivity of the PHQ-9 test slightly increases (more true positives). At the same time, however, the specificity will decrease (more false positives).

Ideally, the cutoff point is on a curve in the upper left corner, where sensitivity and specificity are 100% (the highest rate of true positives together with the lowest rate of false positives).

images.title: Receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve
images.description: The ROC curve illustrates the relationship between the sensitivity and specificity of a test.The more closely the curve follows the Y axis, the more accurate the test. The more close the curve is to the diagonal dotted line (x = y), the less accurate the test.When choosing a cutoff value, an upward shift on the ROC curve indicates increased sensitivity, and a shift to the right indicates decreased specificity.

answers.explanation_why: This would represent an increased cutoff value (e.g., a total score of 25 out of 27 as diagnostic cutoff instead of a total score of 20 out of 27) on the PHQ-9 questionnaire. An increased cutoff value would go hand in hand with an increased specificity (more true negatives and fewer false positives) but decreased sensitivity (fewer true positives).
Changing the cutoff of the PHQ-9 questionnaire would not change the general course of the ROC curve. An altogether different questionnaire would have a different ROC curve (e.g., the middle one).
Changing the cutoff of the PHQ-9 questionnaire would not change the general course of the ROC curve. An altogether different questionnaire would have a different ROC curve (e.g., the middle one).
Changing the cutoff of the PHQ-9 questionnaire would not change the general course of the ROC curve. An altogether different questionnaire would have a different ROC curve (e.g., the middle one).

A curve close to or on the diagonal line (line of no-discrimination) indicates a nondiagnostic or useless study. On this line, sensitivity equals 1 - specificity and the positive likelihood ratio equals 1. This means that the test in question is no more diagnostic than chance (i.e., a test that yields positive or negative results entirely unrelated to the true disease status). Changing the cutoff of the questionnaire would not render the test useless.

question_text: A pediatrician is investigating determinants of childhood obesity. He has been following a cohort of pregnant women with poorly controlled diabetes and comorbid obesity. In the ensuing years, he evaluated the BMI of the cohort's children. The results of the correlation analysis between mean childhood BMI (at 4 years of age) and both mean maternal BMI before pregnancy and mean maternal hemoglobin A1c during pregnancy are shown. All variables are continuous. Based on these findings, which of the following is the best conclusion?
content_preview: A pediatrician is investigating determinants of childhood obesity. He has been following a cohort of pregnant women with poorly controlled diabetes and comorbid obesity. In the ensuing years, he evaluated the BMI of the cohort's children. The results of the correlation analysis between mean childhood BMI (at 4 years of age) and both mean maternal BMI before pregnancy and mean maternal hemoglobin A1c during pregnancy are shown. All variables are continuous. Based on these findings, which of the following is the best conclusion?
hint: A scatter plot can be helpful in the descriptive analysis of data to show whether there is a type of association. The correlation coefficient (r) represents the strength of a linear relationship between two variables (i.e., how close the data points are to a straight line of regression), as well as the polarity of the relationship.
learning_objective: Interpret the correlation coefficient to determine the relationship between two continuous variables.

answers.content: There is no association between maternal HbA1c and childhood BMI
answers.explanation_why: An examination of the scatter plot shows that there is a curvilinear (parabolic) relationship between maternal HbA1c and childhood BMI. The correlation coefficient (r) is a measure of the strength and directionality of a linear relationship between two variables. The small and statistically insignificant r coefficient in this scatter plot suggests that there is no linear relationship between the two variables. This does not, however, mean that there is no relationship at all.

answers.content: Maternal BMI is a stronger predictor of childhood BMI than maternal HbA1c
answers.explanation_why: The fact that the correlation coefficient (r) has larger magnitude for the first scatter plot (r = 0.45 versus r = 0.03) suggests that the data fits a linear relationship better than the second scatter plot. Similarly, the smaller p-value (p < 0.01 versus p = 0.23) implies that the linear correlation is statistically significant. However, neither of these values measures the strength of the association between the two variables.

answers.content: Higher maternal HbA1c leads to increased childhood BMI
answers.explanation_why: Neither the magnitude of the correlation coefficient (r), nor the level of statistical significance (p-value) have any bearing on causality. Correlation does not imply causation.

answers.content: An increase in maternal BMI is associated with a decrease in childhood BMI
answers.explanation_why: The correlation coefficient (r) for the scatter plot showing maternal BMI and childhood BMI is 0.45. When the correlation coefficient is positive, it means that there is a positive correlation between the two variables. For an increase in maternal BMI to be associated with a decrease in childhood BMI, the correlation coefficient would have to be negative.

answers.content: The association between maternal BMI and childhood BMI has a steeper slope than maternal HbA1c and childhood BMI
answers.explanation_why: The fact that the r coefficient has larger magnitude for the first scatter plot (r = 0.45 versus r = 0.03) suggests that its data fits a linear relationship better than the second scatter plot. The r coefficient is a measure of the strength and directionality of a linear relationship between two variables. However, it has no bearing on the slope of the line of best fit (which is not shown in these scatter plots).

answers.content: There is a positively correlated linear association between maternal BMI and childhood BMI
answers.explanation_why: The correlation coefficient (r) of 0.45 suggests a moderate positive linear correlation between maternal BMI and childhood BMI. An r < 0 implies that there is a negative linear correlation between two variables while an r > 0 implies that there is a positive correlation. The magnitude of the r coefficient represents how closely the data fit a linear relationship (r ranges from -1 to 1; a value of 0.45 is a moderate fit, while a value of 1 would be seen in a perfectly linear positive correlation).

images.title: Scatterplots of childhood BMI vs. maternal BMI and maternal HgA1c
images.description: Each dot on both of these graphs represents a single observation.Left: In general, as the x-values (mean maternal BMI before pregnancy) of the data points increase, the y-values (mean childhood BMI at 4-year follow-up) also increase. This indicates a positive correlation between mean maternal BMI before pregnancy and mean childhood BMI at 4-year follow-up, with a statistically significant value of the correlation coefficient (r=0.45, P<0.01)Right: In this graph, there is no linear relationship between the x-values (mean maternal BMI before pregnancy) and y-values (mean childhood BMI at 4-year follow-up). As such, the correlation coefficient is small and not statistically significant (r=0.03, p=0.23)

question_text: To conduct a case-control study, an endocrine surgeon selects patients who experienced a hypertensive crisis during pheochromocytoma resection and patients who did not experience this complication during pheochromocytoma surgery. She then compares the two groups with regard to the number of patients with underlying MEN 2 syndromes. The surgeon subsequently calculates an odds ratio of 3.4 (p < 0.01), indicating that patients who experienced intraoperative hypertension during pheochromocytoma removal are 3.4 times more likely to have underlying MEN 2 syndromes than patients in the control group. In her publication, the surgeon reports a risk ratio of 3.4 (p < 0.01), concluding that the risk for patients with MEN 2 syndromes developing intraoperative hypertension during pheochromocytoma removal is 3.4 times greater than for patients without MEN 2 syndromes. Considering the study design, which of the following concepts is the most important prerequisite to allow the surgeon to come to this conclusion?
content_preview: To conduct a case-control study, an endocrine surgeon selects patients who experienced a hypertensive crisis during pheochromocytoma resection and patients who did not experience this complication during pheochromocytoma surgery. She then compares the two groups with regard to the number of patients with underlying MEN 2 syndromes. The surgeon subsequently calculates an odds ratio of 3.4 (p < 0.01), indicating that patients who experienced intraoperative hypertension during pheochromocytoma removal are 3.4 times more likely to have underlying MEN 2 syndromes than patients in the control group. In her publication, the surgeon reports a risk ratio of 3.4 (p < 0.01), concluding that the risk for patients with MEN 2 syndromes developing intraoperative hypertension during pheochromocytoma removal is 3.4 times greater than for patients without MEN 2 syndromes. Considering the study design, which of the following concepts is the most important prerequisite to allow the surgeon to come to this conclusion?
hint: In a standard contingency table, the odds ratio is calculated as OR = (a/c)/(b/d) = (a/b)/(c/d), while the relative risk is calculated as RR = (a/(a + b))/(c/(c + d)). Normally, RR cannot be calculated from case-control studies. However, when the values representing the diseased population, a and c, become insignificant compared to the values representing the nondiseased population, b and d, RR approximates the OR: RR ≈ (a/b)/(c/d).
learning_objective: Recall the rare disease assumption in case-control studies.

answers.content: Hypertensive crisis during pheochromocytoma resection is rare
answers.explanation_why: The rare disease assumption is the most important prerequisite that allows for this surgeon's conclusion. This concept assumes that if the incidence of a study's outcome (in this case, hypertensive crisis during pheochromocytoma resection) is low (i.e., the disease is rare), the odds ratio approximates the relative risk. Usually, the relative risk cannot be established in case-control studies because subjects are not tracked over time. Instead, the odds ratio is calculated to determine whether there is an association between an exposure and outcome (in this case, MEN 2 syndrome and intraoperative hypertension, respectively), although the OR does not provide a quantitative estimate of the risk. Because intraoperative hypertension during pheochromocytoma resection is rare, the rare disease assumption holds that OR is approximately equal to RR. It can thus be assumed that the risk of intraoperative hypertension during pheochromocytoma removal is 3.4 times greater in patients with MEN 2 syndromes than in patients without MEN 2 syndromes.

answers.content: Prevalence of MEN type 2 syndromes is low
answers.explanation_why: If the prevalence of MEN 2 syndromes is low, the values representing the exposure in a standard contingency table, a and b, become very small. In this case, the odds ratio indicates an association between exposure and outcome without providing an estimate of the relative risk.

answers.content: Pheochromocytoma is common in MEN 2 syndromes
answers.explanation_why: While pheochromocytoma is common in individuals with MEN 2 syndromes, occurring in approx. 50% of patients, this has no bearing on the assumption that the odds ratio approximates the relative risk.

answers.content: The case-control study used a large sample size
answers.explanation_why: The size of the case-control study does not determine whether the relative risk can be estimated from the odds ratio or not. The odds ratio approximates the relative risk only in one specific circumstance.

answers.content: The relationship between MEN 2 syndromes and intraoperative hypertension during pheochromocytoma removal is not due to random error
answers.explanation_why: A p-value < 0.05 (here p < 0.01) indicates that the association between MEN 2 syndromes and intraoperative hypertension during pheochromocytoma removal is statistically significant rather than due to chance or random error. However, this does not allow us to assume that the relative risk is equal to the odds ratio here.

question_text: A group of gastroenterologists is concerned about low colonoscopy screening rates in their region. They decide to implement a free patient navigation program to encourage more individuals to obtain colonoscopies in accordance with US Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) guidelines. Individuals were recruited at a community center and randomly assigned into two groups. The first group was enrolled in a patient navigation program and attended monthly meetings, where they were given regular reminders that their adherence to screening guidelines was being evaluated. The second group did not participate in the patient navigation program. Colonoscopy rates were assessed via chart review and showed that 90% of participants in the first group and 34% of people in the second group adhered to screening guidelines. Which of the following most likely contributed to the observed disparity in colonoscopy screening rates?
content_preview: A group of gastroenterologists is concerned about low colonoscopy screening rates in their region. They decide to implement a free patient navigation program to encourage more individuals to obtain colonoscopies in accordance with US Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) guidelines. Individuals were recruited at a community center and randomly assigned into two groups. The first group was enrolled in a patient navigation program and attended monthly meetings, where they were given regular reminders that their adherence to screening guidelines was being evaluated. The second group did not participate in the patient navigation program. Colonoscopy rates were assessed via chart review and showed that 90% of participants in the first group and 34% of people in the second group adhered to screening guidelines. Which of the following most likely contributed to the observed disparity in colonoscopy screening rates?
hint: The frequent reminders given to participants in the first group likely influenced their behavior.
learning_objective: Recall the definition of the Hawthorne effect in behavioral studies.

answers.explanation_why: Confirmation bias is the tendency of researchers to preferentially include or exclude results that support a given hypothesis. In this case, colonoscopy screening rates were assessed via chart review, and there is no indication that the researchers preferentially included or excluded data. Confirmation bias would not account for the observed disparity in colonoscopy screening rates.

Reporting bias refers to the selective disclosure or suppression of information that is sometimes related to stigma and prevailing social attitudes (e.g., past medical history, sexual partners, drug use). In this study, colonoscopy screening rates were assessed via chart review. Reporting bias would not account for the observed disparity in colonoscopy screening rates.

The Hawthorne effect, commonly seen in behavioral studies, is the tendency of subjects to modify their behavior when they know they are being observed.

The first group in the study was given regular evaluation reminders, which likely accounts for their greater adherence to screening guidelines, as compared to the second group. If this study's researchers did not consider the role of the Hawthorne effect, they could have overestimated the success of the patient navigation program. Although there are methods for reducing the Hawthorne effect, such as withholding the aim of a study from its subjects and/or concealing the fact that they are being monitored, these strategies are not considered ethical. Conducting a study over a prolonged period of time can make subjects accustomed to being studied and is therefore an ethical strategy for reducing the Hawthorne effect.

High degrees of random errors, biases (e.g., Hawthorne effect), and confounding variables can limit the validity (i.e., accuracy) of a study.

Berkson bias is a type of selection bias that occurs when study populations are drawn from the population of hospitalized patients, which typically has different exposures and health outcomes compared to the general population. The groups involved in this study were both recruited from community centers. Berkson bias would not account for the observed disparity in colonoscopy screening rates.

Sampling bias occurs when certain individuals are more likely to be selected for a study group, resulting in a nonrandomized sample. Because the selected population is not representative of the target population, sampling bias can limit the validity (i.e., accuracy) of a study. In this study, all participants were recruited from one community center and randomly assigned into two groups. Sampling bias would not account for the observed disparity in colonoscopy screening rates.

Recall bias occurs when awareness of a condition by subjects changes their recall of related risk factors. It is common in retrospective studies. For example, a patient who has been diagnosed with cancer may have more complete recollection of possible exposures (e.g., missed preventive health screenings, occupational exposures) than a patient who has not been diagnosed with cancer. In this case, colonoscopy screening rates were assessed via chart review. Recall bias would not account for the observed disparity in colonoscopy screening rates.

question_text:
A hematologist has found a historical hemocytometer used during the 1960s. Out of curiosity, he decides to obtain platelet counts from his brother, who has immune thrombocytopenic purpura, with both the historical hemocytometer and a modern automated CBC analyzer. The platelet counts of repeated measurements are shown in ascending order:

Historical hemocytometer /mm^3

55,000
57,000
62,000
76,000
77,000
82,000
92,000

Mean: 72,000

Modern automated CBC analyzer /mm^3

71,000
71,000
72,000
72,000
73,000
74,000
74,000

Mean: 72,000

If the measurements on a modern automated CBC analyzer are considered accurate, which of the following conclusions can be drawn about the historical hemocytometer?
content_preview: A hematologist has found a historical hemocytometer used during the 1960s. Out of curiosity, he decides to obtain platelet counts from his brother, who has immune thrombocytopenic purpura, with both the historical hemocytometer and a modern automated CBC analyzer. The platelet counts of repeated measurements are shown in ascending order: Historical hemocytometer /mm3 55,000 57,000 62,000 76,000 77,000 82,000 92,000 Mean: 72,000 Modern automated CBC analyzer /mm3 71,000 71,000 72,000 72,000 73,000 74,000 74,000 Mean: 72,000 If the measurements on a modern automated CBC analyzer are considered accurate, which of the following conclusions can be drawn about the historical hemocytometer?
hint: While the mean of the two sets of measurements is the same, the measures of dispersion (e.g., range) are higher with the historical hemocytometer.
learning_objective: Interpret measures of dispersion to assess test precision.

answers.explanation_why: Overall, the historical hemocytometer seems to be accurate at measuring what it is supposed to measure (platelet counts). A lack of accuracy would probably have resulted in a different mean compared to the modern automated CBC analyzer.

Overall, the historical hemocytometer seems to be accurate at measuring what it is supposed to measure (low platelet counts from immune thrombocytopenic purpura). A lack of validity would have resulted in a different mean than the modern automated CBC analyzer.

Specificity is a measure of test validity and refers to the ability of a test to correctly identify those who do not have a certain disease (low platelet counts from immune thrombocytopenic purpura; ITP). As there are no standard values for normal or ITP-altered platelet counts offered here, no conclusions about specificity can be drawn.

Based on the results presented, the historical hemocytometer lacks precision (reliability). The test is unreliable, as it does not consistently give similar results on repeated measurements. The range (statistics) of results of the historical hemocytometer is 55,000–92,000/mm^3, while the range of results of the modern automated CBC analyzer is much smaller (71,000–74,000/mm^3), indicating that it is more precise. Random errors result in single values differing significantly from the mean during test-retest measurement, which reduces the precision of a test.

images.title: Reliability and validity
images.description: Illustration of the principles of reliability (precision) and validity (accuracy)The crosses represent data points from repeated measurements taken using the same instrument, and the target represents the true value of the attribute being measured.Reliability refers to how similar the data points are to each other: when reliability is low, the data points are more widely dispersed. When reliability is high, the data points are more close together.Validity refers to how close the data points are to the true value: when validity is low, the data points do not approximate the true value.

answers.explanation_why: Sensitivity is a measure of test validity and refers to the ability of a test to correctly identify those who have a certain disease (low platelet counts from immune thrombocytopenic purpura; ITP). As there are no standard values for normal or ITP-altered platelet count values offered here, no conclusions about sensitivity can be drawn.
