question_text: An investigator is conducting a 6-month incidence study of a new viral respiratory disease in the population of a small town of 2500 residents. The virus seems to be infecting teenagers more often than adults. There is evidence that the virus provides long-term immunity after the infection has cleared. Prior to the investigation, 150 residents had developed the disease, 100 of whom were teenagers. During the 6 months of the study, another 400 residents were diagnosed with the disease, 350 of whom are teenagers. Which of the following is the incidence of the new disease for the given time period in this town?
content_preview: An investigator is conducting a 6-month incidence study of a new viral respiratory disease in the population of a small town of 2500 residents. The virus seems to be infecting teenagers more often than adults. There is evidence that the virus provides long-term immunity after the infection has cleared. Prior to the investigation, 150 residents had developed the disease, 100 of whom were teenagers. During the 6 months of the study, another 400 residents were diagnosed with the disease, 350 of whom are teenagers. Which of the following is the incidence of the new disease for the given time period in this town?
hint: Incidence is typically expressed either as a proportion (i.e., cumulative incidence) or as a rate (i.e., incidence rate). The data from this study can be used to calculate cumulative incidence, which is the proportion of the town's residents who newly developed the disease during the 6-month study period.
learning_objective: Calculate the cumulative incidence.

answers.explanation_why: This is the ratio of the number of teenagers who developed the disease in the 6-month study period (350) to the overall population at risk during the study (2350). The question asks about the incidence of the disease in the overall population rather than in a specific age group. If the question had asked for the 6-month incidence in teenagers, the total number of teenagers in the town (X) would be needed to calculate the number at risk of developing the disease during the study. The 6-month incidence for this age group would be 350/(X - 100).

This is the 6-month period prevalence of the disease. Prevalence does not account for the number of individuals at risk during a given period. 400/2500 = 16% is the ratio of new cases of disease during the 6-month study to the total number of residents regardless of their susceptibility to infection.

This is the period prevalence of the disease since its discovery. Prevalence does not account for the number of individuals at risk during a given period. 550/2500 = 22% is the ratio of new cases of the disease since its discovery to the total number of residents regardless of their susceptibility to infection.

Cumulative incidence is calculated as the number of new cases of a disease divided by the number of people at risk in a given period. In this scenario, 400 residents develop the disease during the 6 months of the study. 2350 residents were at risk during the study (2500 residents - 150 residents who had already contracted the virus and have long-term immunity). Therefore, the 6-month cumulative incidence of the disease in this scenario is 400/2350 = 17.02%.

This is the ratio of the overall number of teenagers who developed the disease since the discovery of the disease (450) to the overall population (2500). The question asks about the 6-month incidence of the disease in the overall population rather than its period prevalence since discovery in a specific age group. If the question had asked for the prevalence of the disease in teenagers since its discovery, the total number of teenagers in the town (X) would be needed for the calculation. The period prevalence since the discovery of the disease for this age group would be 450/X.

question_text: A group of investigators is evaluating the efficacy of a new mRNA vaccine in preventing a viral infection. They conducted a pilot phase II study in which participants were randomized to receive either the new vaccine or a placebo vaccine. After one month of follow-up with the level of significance fixed at 5%, the investigators conclude that the study lacks statistical power because their study design was flawed. Assuming the investigators intended to keep the level of significance at 5%, which of the following factors most likely contributed to the low statistical power of the study?
content_preview: A group of investigators is evaluating the efficacy of a new mRNA vaccine in preventing a viral infection. They conducted a pilot phase II study in which participants were randomized to receive either the new vaccine or a placebo vaccine. After one month of follow-up with the level of significance fixed at 5%, the investigators conclude that the study lacks statistical power because their study design was flawed. Assuming the investigators intended to keep the level of significance at 5%, which of the following factors most likely contributed to the low statistical power of the study?
hint: Statistical power is the probability that a study will detect a true difference (i.e., rejecting the null hypothesis when the alternative hypothesis is true).
learning_objective: Recall factors that contribute to statistical power, and interpret the impact of sample size on it.

answers.content: Large difference between the mean immune responses
answers.explanation_why: The difference between the mean immune responses in the study is the effect size. Large effect sizes yield a high rather than a low statistical power.

answers.content: Low probability of a type 2 error
answers.explanation_why: The probability of a type 2 error (denoted as “β”), is inversely related to the statistical power of a study. A low β would, therefore, lead to a high rather than low statistical power.

answers.content: Inadequate number of participants in the study
answers.explanation_why:
A low sample size leads to a greater variance of the data and increases the type 2 error rate (denoted as “β”). Since β is inversely related to statistical power (1 - β), the higher the β, the lower the statistical power. To increase the statistical power, investigators must decrease β by increasing the sample size in the study and/or making more precise measurements of the outcome of interest.

With pilot studies, low statistical power on post hoc power analysis is a common occurrence. Pilot studies are conducted when the effect size cannot be reliably estimated (e.g., from literature). When designing a pilot study, the power is fixed a priori (usually at a value ≥ 0.80). The study is then performed using a small number of participants (usually 10–50; the exact number depends on the type of study and type of statistical analysis) and the minimum detectable effect size is measured. Based on this information, a sample size that yields adequate power is calculated, and this sample size is used during the main study.

answers.content: High precision of the tests used to measure the immune response
answers.explanation_why: A test with high precision will reduce the number of random errors in a study. This will narrow the standard deviation of the mean immune response in each arm and increase the statistical power of a study, not decrease it.

answers.content: High probability of a type 1 error
answers.explanation_why:
The probability of a type 1 error (denoted as “α”), is inversely related to the type 2 error rate (denoted as “β”). Because β is inversely related to statistical power, a higher α would result in a higher statistical power.

α is the significance level that is chosen by the researcher. In this experiment, it has been set at 0.05 (i.e., 5%), which is the most common threshold for this value.

question_text: A group of investigators designs a small phase 0 trial to evaluate the pharmacodynamics and pharmacokinetics of a new drug against pregnancy-induced hypertension. They decide to conduct the study after a renowned journal published the results of an animal trial that showed the drug to be safe and effective in reducing blood pressure in pregnant chimps. No teratogenic effects were reported. The investigators receive a grant from the pharmaceutical company that manufactures the drug after the company contractually agrees not to influence the design, conduct, analysis, or publication of the trial in any way. The grant funds are designated to be used for expenses incurred in conducting the study. Other than a grant-drawn salary for the predetermined duration of the trial, no financial or material compensation would be offered to the investigators. The investigators propose to recruit a group of ten healthy pregnant women. Both the study participants and the fathers of their children would be informed in their native language, verbally as well as in writing, about the investigators' industry affiliation, the purpose and design of the study, the benefits and known side effects of the new drug, and the alternative options for treating pregnancy-induced hypertension. The participants would also be informed of their rights to confidentiality, to withdraw from the trial at any time, to free medical treatment as well as financial compensation in the event of harm to them or their fetus, and to decision-making autonomy regarding termination or continuation of the pregnancy, antenatal care, and medical or surgical treatment. For participating in the study, they would be offered subsidized antenatal care with a health care provider of their choosing, and the subsidy would not be stopped even if they were to withdraw after enrolling. The investigators would enroll the prospective participants only after the participant and the child's father confirm their understanding of the provided information and sign a consent form. Which of the following would most likely be the cause for the rejection of this study design by an institutional review board?

The grant funds are designated to be used for expenses incurred in conducting the study. The participants would also be informed of their rights to confidentiality, to withdraw from the trial at any time, to free medical treatment as well as financial compensation in the event of harm to them or their fetus, and to decision-making autonomy regarding termination or continuation of the pregnancy, antenatal care, and medical or surgical treatment. For participating in the study, they would be offered subsidized antenatal care with a health care provider of their choosing, and the subsidy would not be stopped even if they were to withdraw after enrolling. The investigators would enroll the prospective participants only after the participant and the child's father confirm their understanding of the provided information and sign a consent form. Which of the following would most likely be the cause for the rejection of this study design by an institutional review board?
hint: All aboard the sleepy train… This is a very long question with a lot of words, but the answer lies on the surface for the attentive reader.
learning_objective: Recognize ethical considerations when conducting research in vulnerable populations.

answers.explanation_why:
Vulnerable populations (e.g., pregnant women, neonates, children, prisoners, individuals with impaired decision-making capacity, economically or educationally disadvantaged individuals) are at increased risk of harm in clinical trials, and certain safeguards for protection of these populations are set in place by the Office of Human Research Protection (OHRP). Before including pregnant women in clinical trials, preclinical trials in pregnant animals and clinical trials in nonpregnant individuals must have been conducted, and data regarding potential risks has to be available. Because the proposed trial was preceded only by an animal trial in pregnant chimps, it would most likely be rejected by an institutional review board. In addition to the animal trial, phase 0, I, II, and III clinical trials in nonpregnant women should be conducted to ensure the safety of the new drug.

Two of the central ethical requirements for clinical trials are voluntary participation and informed consent. The OHRP safeguards aim to ensure that vulnerable populations are not coerced (e.g., prisoners generally cannot be recruited for studies unless the research investigates health issues directly related to the prison population) and that those who may not be fully capable of informed consent are protected by all means (e.g., neonates can only participate in trials for the purpose of obtaining crucial biomedical knowledge that cannot be obtained by other means or has the potential to provide direct benefit to the neonate without posing any additional risk).

Informed consent for participation in research is ensured by the proposed study design, as both parents would be provided with sufficient information (e.g., full description of the purpose and design of the study, benefits and side effects of the drug, treatment options, confidentiality) to allow for an informed, voluntary decision about whether to participate in the study. The information would be provided in the participants' native language in written and spoken form to ensure comprehension and sufficient opportunities for the participants to obtain more information. The participants would only be enrolled in the trial after signing a consent form, which is another requirement for informed consent for research purposes.

A conflict of interest can arise when researchers accept financial compensation from a pharmaceutical company, as seen here. However, in the proposed study the company has contractually agreed not to influence the design, conduct, analysis, or publication. Moreover, other than a grant-drawn salary, no financial or material compensation is offered to the investigators, and the duration of the trial is predetermined, excluding any incentives to prolong the duration of the trial for financial reasons.

Plagiarism is the unlicensed and/or unauthorized reproduction of someone else’s work for the purpose of passing it off as one’s own original effort. The proposed study is based on the results of a previous study, but its design is significantly different (e.g., involving humans instead of chimps). Plagiarism is not an issue with the study design at this point, although it will be important for the animal trial to be properly cited in the study publication.

A study design for research in healthy individuals in a phase II or higher clinical trial would most likely be rejected by an institutional review board because those phases involve testing a drug in individuals with a specific condition. However, research in healthy individuals is the standard procedure for phase 0 and phase I clinical trials, and an institutional review board would not reject the proposed study design for this reason.

question_text: A 65-year-old woman with recently diagnosed acute myelocytic leukemia (AML) comes to a physician-investigator for a follow-up visit. Two months ago, she was enrolled in a randomized, single-blind, active-control equivalence trial involving an experimental combination chemotherapy regimen for AML. At every monthly visit, the study participants undergo chemotherapy along with a clinical evaluation and laboratory workup. The study participants are given prorated compensation following each visit. There is no additional compensation for completing the study. She has completed two of the four planned monthly cycles. On examination today, she appears tired but is in no apparent distress. During the evaluation, she says that she wants to “continue medical treatments” but would like to “withdraw from the study.” In addition to asking her why she wants to withdraw, which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician-investigator concerning the participant's request?
content_preview: A 65-year-old woman with recently diagnosed acute myelocytic leukemia (AML) comes to a physician-investigator for a follow-up visit. Two months ago, she was enrolled in a randomized, single-blind, active-control equivalence trial involving an experimental combination chemotherapy regimen for AML. At every monthly visit, the study participants undergo chemotherapy along with a clinical evaluation and laboratory workup. The study participants are given prorated compensation following each visit. There is no additional compensation for completing the study. She has completed two of the four planned monthly cycles. On examination today, she appears tired but is in no apparent distress. During the evaluation, she says that she wants to “continue medical treatments” but would like to “withdraw from the study.” In addition to asking her why she wants to withdraw, which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician-investigator concerning the participant's request?
hint: This patient wants to discontinue her participation in a human subjects research study. The investigator should follow the guidelines set forth by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the Office for Human Research Protections (OHRP).
learning_objective: Recognize a participant's right to withdraw from a clinical trial, and choose the appropriate follow-up actions.

answers.content: Ask the participant if she is willing to undergo any follow-up evaluation
answers.explanation_why: A participant has a right to withdraw from a clinical trial at any time. The investigator should accept the decision without attempting to influence the participant in any way but may inquire about the reason for withdrawal to identify any potential risks or adverse events. In addition, the investigator should clarify whether the participant wants to withdraw completely (i.e., from all aspects of the study including follow-up) or only partially. Follow-up is important for ensuring the validity of the research and identifying adverse events that could negatively affect other participants. Informed consent on partial participation should be obtained. In the event of complete withdrawal, the participant should not be contacted for further study-related activities, and no additional information should be collected about them. The information collected to date may be kept.

answers.content: Unblind the participant by revealing which group she was in
answers.explanation_why: The protocol for unblinding is determined by the institutional review board at the beginning of a trial. Specific circumstances, such as a subject's pregnancy or adverse events that affect safety, may require unblinding participants. Investigators may also decide to unblind participants after completion of the trial. However, withdrawal from a study is not an obligatory reason to unblind the participant and another action is more appropriate.

answers.content: Offer remaining compensation for subsequent visits
answers.explanation_why:
The type of compensation is determined prior to study enrollment and should be uniformly applicable to all participants. Prorated compensation is used for studies involving multiple visits. This compensation model equitably distributes compensation among participants and pays participants a predetermined amount for each procedure and/or visit. With this compensation model, a participant who wishes to withdraw completely from the study should not be denied compensation that they have already earned but should not be offered compensation for the subsequent visits because such an action may go against the principle of justice for the other participants and risks imposing an element of undue influence on the withdrawing participant to remain (either completely or partially) in the study. Another action is necessary before discussing compensation.

Regardless of the type of compensation model used, a study participant may be eligible for additional compensation if they experienced adverse events from the intervention.

answers.content: Consult the institutional review board overseeing the trial
answers.explanation_why: All clinical trials are required to have institutional review board (IRB) approval before enrolling participants and conducting research. The IRB should be notified in the event of a protocol deviation (e.g., including a participant who does not meet the required criteria, dosing error) or adverse event. Although study withdrawal should be documented, participants are allowed to withdraw from studies without prior consultation with the IRB.

answers.content: Destroy all clinical and diagnostic data collected on the participant so far
answers.explanation_why: Study participants may withdraw at any time, and all data gathered about them should be secured. To ensure patient confidentiality, it may be further necessary to anonymize the data. However, the FDA and OHRP guidelines for clinical drug trials stipulate that all data collected prior to withdrawal must remain in the study database to ensure validity of the research and enable intention-to-treat analysis if needed.

question_text:
A researcher is investigating the effect of a new oral antidiabetic drug on fasting serum glucose concentration in patients with untreated type 2 diabetes mellitus. For his initial hypothesis, he draws blood from 8 patients who have been taking the drug regularly for 2 weeks and measures their fasting serum glucose concentrations. Laboratory studies show:

Patient 1
90 mg/dL

Patient 2
100 mg/dL

Patient 3
102 mg/dL

Patient 4
119 mg/dL

Patient 5
95 mg/dL

Patient 6
105 mg/dL

Patient 7
109 mg/dL

Patient 8
100 mg/dL

Which of the following is the median of these serum glucose concentrations?
content_preview: A researcher is investigating the effect of a new oral antidiabetic drug on fasting serum glucose concentration in patients with untreated type 2 diabetes mellitus. For his initial hypothesis, he draws blood from 8 patients who have been taking the drug regularly for 2 weeks and measures their fasting serum glucose concentrations. Laboratory studies show: Patient 1 90 mg/dL Patient 2 100 mg/dL Patient 3 102 mg/dL Patient 4 119 mg/dL Patient 5 95 mg/dL Patient 6 105 mg/dL Patient 7 109 mg/dL Patient 8 100 mg/dL Which of the following is the median of these serum glucose concentrations?
hint: After arranging the data set in ascending order, the median value separates the lower half of the data from the upper half.
learning_objective: Calculate the median.

answers.explanation_why: To determine the median (statistics), the data set must be arranged in ascending order. The values of this set, in ascending order, are 90, 95, 100, 100, 102, 105, 109, 119. Since there is an even number of values in the set, the median is the average of the two middle values (i.e., (100 + 102)/2 = 101).
102.5 mg/dL is the mean (statistics) of the data set, which is the arithmetic average of the data set: (90 + 100 + 102 + 119 + 95 + 105 + 109 + 100)/8 = 102.5.
100 mg/dL is the mode (statistics) of this data set, which is the most common value in the data set.
10 mg/dL is the interquartile range of this data set, which is the difference between the 75^th and 25^th percentile and is calculated as 105 – 95 = 10.
29 mg/dL is the range of this data set, which is the difference between the largest and smallest value in the set and is calculated as 119 – 90 = 29.

question_text: A group of investigators conduct a randomized, double-blinded, placebo-controlled trial to evaluate the efficacy of a new medication in the treatment of infectious mononucleosis. They enroll 3143 patients between the ages of 18 and 30 years who presented with mononucleosis-like illness and had a positive Monospot test. These patients are randomized to receive either the new drug or placebo for a period of one week. The primary endpoint of the trial is the time to resolution of symptoms from the onset of therapy and the secondary endpoint is the splenic volume as measured by ultrasonography one month after initiating therapy. At the end of the study, the mean differences of endpoint measures in each arm are determined and evaluated using t-statistics. For analysis, the investigators decide to exclude patients from both arms who did not adhere to the treatment protocol or dropped out of the study. When compared to an analysis that includes the nonadherent patients and dropouts from both study arms, the analysis performed by the investigators is most likely to have which of the following properties?
content_preview: A group of investigators conduct a randomized, double-blinded, placebo-controlled trial to evaluate the efficacy of a new medication in the treatment of infectious mononucleosis. They enroll 3143 patients between the ages of 18 and 30 years who presented with mononucleosis-like illness and had a positive Monospot test. These patients are randomized to receive either the new drug or placebo for a period of one week. The primary endpoint of the trial is the time to resolution of symptoms from the onset of therapy and the secondary endpoint is the splenic volume as measured by ultrasonography one month after initiating therapy. At the end of the study, the mean differences of endpoint measures in each arm are determined and evaluated using t-statistics. For analysis, the investigators decide to exclude patients from both arms who did not adhere to the treatment protocol or dropped out of the study. When compared to an analysis that includes the nonadherent patients and dropouts from both study arms, the analysis performed by the investigators is most likely to have which of the following properties?
hint: When analyzing data from a randomized controlled trial, the two main ways of dealing with study protocol violations (e.g., dropouts, nonadherence) are intention-to-treat analysis (ITT analysis), which includes all subjects (once randomized, always analyzed), and per-protocol analysis (PP analysis), which only includes subjects who adhered to the study protocol.
learning_objective: Interpret the implications of per-protocol analysis on effect size.

answers.explanation_why: Despite a slight reduction in sample size, a PP analysis has a lower, not higher, risk of type 2 error compared to ITT analysis because PP analysis tends to overestimate the effect of the studied treatment. This also means that a PP analysis has a higher risk of type 1 error compared to ITT analysis.

In a PP analysis, the evaluation of the effect of treatment assumes optimal trial conditions (i.e., an ideal scenario in which all patients receive and complete the treatment regimen they were assigned). In a real clinical scenario, however, patients may be nonadherent to treatment or lost to follow-up. This means that a PP analysis tends to overestimate the difference between outcomes in the treatment and placebo groups, which results in larger effect size (i.e., greater strength of association). Moreover, PP analysis increases the risk of biases (e.g., selection bias, confounding bias) because the original randomization of the trial is lost. On the other hand, an ITT analysis results in a smaller effect size (i.e., avoids overestimation of the new intervention's effect), greater generalizability (external validity) of results, and preserves randomization, which decreases the risk of bias.

An as-treated analysis (sometimes considered a subtype of PP analysis) evaluates patients according to the intervention they actually received, no matter which intervention they were originally assigned. This type of analysis is primarily used to assess the side effects of interventions.

When compared to ITT analysis, a PP analysis has less, not more, external validity (generalizability). A PP analysis is used to evaluate the treatment effect in an ideal scenario, in which all patients received and completed the treatment regimen by the end of the trial, rather than a scenario that more closely resembles a true clinical setting, where nonadherence is common (as in an ITT analysis).

When compared to ITT analysis, PP analysis reduces the degree of randomization, which normally results in groups with equal distributions of known and unknown confounders. The risk of bias (e.g., selection bias, confounding bias) thereby increases due to potential nonrandom nonadherence. Therefore, the risk of confounding is higher, not lower, in a PP analysis.

Lead time is often discussed in the context of a screening test for a chronic disease in which the studied outcome is survival. Since earlier diagnosis does not necessarily result in increased survival, the lead time may result in bias (i.e., lead time bias). In this scenario, the lead time is irrelevant because the study focuses on the efficacy of a new medication and not on a diagnostic test.

question_text: An investigator is conducting a retrospective study on the effects of ivermectin on the treatment of adult patients with coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) during hospitalization. 315 patients are enrolled in the study and categorized further into three treatment groups; the trial period is 3 months. One group receives 6 mg of oral ivermectin once daily, one group receives 12 mg of oral ivermectin once daily, and one control group receives a placebo once daily. The primary endpoint is viral clearance measured as the mean number of days to a negative polymerase chain reaction test. The confidence level is set at 95%. Which of the following statistical methods is most appropriate to compare the results from the different treatment groups?
content_preview: An investigator is conducting a retrospective study on the effects of ivermectin on the treatment of adult patients with coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) during hospitalization. 315 patients are enrolled in the study and categorized further into three treatment groups; the trial period is 3 months. One group receives 6 mg of oral ivermectin once daily, one group receives 12 mg of oral ivermectin once daily, and one control group receives a placebo once daily. The primary endpoint is viral clearance measured as the mean number of days to a negative polymerase chain reaction test. The confidence level is set at 95%. Which of the following statistical methods is most appropriate to compare the results from the different treatment groups?
hint: The study compares the different times to a negative polymerase chain reaction test, that is, the difference in means (continuous outcome) of three categorical treatment groups.
learning_objective: Choose the appropriate statistical method to compare means of continuous outcomes across multiple categorical groups.

answers.explanation_why: A Pearson correlation analysis determines the Pearson correlation coefficient, which describes the strength and polarity (positive, negative) of a linear relationship between two continuous variables. In this scenario, there is only one continuous variable (mean number of days to a negative polymerase chain reaction test).

An unpaired t-test is used to compare the means of a continuous outcome for no more than two different categorical groups. This study design compares the means of three groups, so an unpaired t-test would not be appropriate. An unpaired t-test could be used, for example, if the study was comparing the time to negative polymerase chain reaction tests (continuous outcome) in the placebo and 6 mg ivermectin groups.

A paired t-test can be used to compare the means of a continuous outcome (dependent variable) at different points in time in the same sample group. This study compares the continuous outcome (mean results) of 3 categorical groups at the same point in time. A paired t-test could be used, for example, to compare the viral load assessed by quantitative polymerase chain reaction test (a continuous result) in the 6 mg ivermectin group on two different days.

Analysis of variance (ANOVA) is a parametric test that compares the means of continuous outcomes of ≥ 2 categorical groups. ANOVA can be used to determine whether the difference in the means of the groups is statistically significant. In this study, the investigators are comparing the difference in the means (dependent, continuous variable) between the intervention groups (independent, categorical variable). ANOVA is therefore the most appropriate statistical method.

The difference between an unpaired t-test and an ANOVA test is that an unpaired t-test can only be performed when the independent variable is composed of no more than two categorical groups (e.g., female or male). Whenever there are three or more categories (e.g., 3 mg, 6 mg, and placebo), only an ANOVA can be performed. For 2 categories, the t-test and the ANOVA should yield the same results (under the condition that certain required assumptions around the distribution of data are true for the sample).

images.title: Selection of statistical tests depending on data type
images.description: For 2 categories, the t-test and the ANOVA should yield the same results. Whenever there are more than two categories, only an ANOVA can be performed.

answers.explanation_why: A chi-square test is used to compare the distributions of two categorical variables. This study aims to test the relationship of continuous outcomes (dependent variables) between 3 categorical groups (independent variable). The chi-square test could be used, for example, to assess if there is a statistically significant difference between the proportions of participants with a negative polymerase chain reaction test (dependent variable, categorical data, true/not true) on day 5 in the different treatment groups (independent variable, categorical data).

question_text: A group of physicians from different specialties in the greater Phoenix, Arizona, area meet at a regional conference to discuss the application of evidence-based medicine in their respective clinics. On day 1 of the conference, the group is randomly split up into two subgroups of equal size. Every physician receives a questionnaire. The first subgroup receives questionnaires that assess the knowledge transfer of evidence-based medicine. The second subgroup receives questionnaires that explore the strategic approaches for the application of evidence-based medicine in the physicians' clinics. Both questionnaires contain a set of 10 questions. The physicians respond to each question by writing out short answers in a comment field. On day 2 of the conference, the replies to the questionnaires are anonymized and discussed within the subgroups. On day 3, both subgroups present their key takeaways. After the conference, an article with a summary of the findings is published in a national journal and the physicians decide to repeat the conference after 1 year to evaluate for changes over time. This study design is best described as which of the following?
content_preview: A group of physicians from different specialties in the greater Phoenix, Arizona, area meet at a regional conference to discuss the application of evidence-based medicine in their respective clinics. On day 1 of the conference, the group is randomly split up into two subgroups of equal size. Every physician receives a questionnaire. The first subgroup receives questionnaires that assess the knowledge transfer of evidence-based medicine. The second subgroup receives questionnaires that explore the strategic approaches for the application of evidence-based medicine in the physicians' clinics. Both questionnaires contain a set of 10 questions. The physicians respond to each question by writing out short answers in a comment field. On day 2 of the conference, the replies to the questionnaires are anonymized and discussed within the subgroups. On day 3, both subgroups present their key takeaways. After the conference, an article with a summary of the findings is published in a national journal and the physicians decide to repeat the conference after 1 year to evaluate for changes over time. This study design is best described as which of the following?
hint: This study collects data with a free text field questionnaire and does not analyze the data through statistical methods.
learning_objective: Recall the characteristics of qualitative study designs.

answers.explanation_why: Ecological studies are observational descriptive studies that assess the prevalence of an exposure and/or outcome on a population or group level. These studies can be conducted with or without statistical analysis. The study in this scenario gathers data on an individual level rather than on a group level, so the data is not representative of a population.

Case-control studies are observational analytical studies that use statistical analysis, a quantitative research design. These studies retrospectively compare the exposure status (e.g., a risk factor) of individuals (i.e., cases) with a certain outcome (e.g., a disease) to the exposure status of a group of similar individuals without the outcome (i.e., controls). Although the physicians were split into subgroups in this scenario, the results of the groups were not compared and no statistical analysis was performed.

Qualitative studies involve the collection and analysis of nonnumerical data obtained by certain methods, such as observations, interviews, and questionnaires with open-ended questions, that aim to describe and provide a deeper understanding of concepts and phenomena. The collected data is usually organized, reviewed, and explored for patterns, from which hypotheses or theories can be inductively developed. Common qualitative research approaches include grounded theory, ethnography, phenomenology, action research, and case studies. As opposed to quantitative research, qualitative research does not run statistical analysis of the collected data nor test hypotheses.

Cohort studies are observational, analytical studies that use statistical analysis, a quantitative research design. In these studies, two groups, one with a certain exposure (e.g., a risk factor) and one without, are monitored over time to determine whether the exposure is associated with a certain outcome (e.g., a disease). No statistical analysis was performed in this scenario, and the physicians were not observed over time.

Randomized controlled studies are experimental studies that use statistical analysis to determine the possible effect of a specific intervention on a given population (i.e., a quantitative research design). In these studies, participants are randomly allocated as either treatment or control subjects. Although the physicians in this scenario are randomly split into subgroups, the results of the groups are not compared and the data is not statistically analyzed.

question_text:
The head of a private urology practice is evaluating the results of a recent patient satisfaction survey. The results indicate that patients consider the time from registration to departure to be too long. The practice identifies the different components of a patient's visit and times how long each one takes. The results are shown:

Registration
Measuring vital parameters
Patient interview
Obtaining blood samples
Scheduling follow-up visits

Mean (min)
4
8
20
8
6

Standard deviation (min)
0.5
5
6
3
2

Optimization of which of the following components is most likely to have the greatest impact on reducing the average duration of a patient's visit?
content_preview: The head of a private urology practice is evaluating the results of a recent patient satisfaction survey. The results indicate that patients consider the time from registration to departure to be too long. The practice identifies the different components of a patient's visit and times how long each one takes. The results are shown: Registration Measuring vital parameters Patient interview Obtaining blood samples Scheduling follow-up visits Mean (min) 4 8 20 8 6 Standard deviation (min) 0.5 5 6 3 2 Optimization of which of the following components is most likely to have the greatest impact on reducing the average duration of a patient's visit?
hint: The coefficient of variation (CV) can be used to measure and compare the dispersion around the mean of multiple data sets. CV = standard deviation (SD) ÷ mean.
learning_objective: Recognize the use of coefficient of variation to identify processes for optimization.

answers.explanation_why: Registration has the lowest CV (0.5 ÷ 4 = 0.12). Registration is also the shortest component of the visit, and, therefore, optimization of another component is more likely to have a greater impact on reducing the average duration of a patient's visit.
Obtaining blood samples does not have the highest CV (3 ÷ 8 = 0.38). Optimization of another component is more likely to have a greater impact on reducing the average duration of a patient's visit.

The patient interview is the longest component of the visit with a mean time of 20 minutes. However, the patient interview process does not have the highest CV (6 ÷ 20 = 0.30) and therefore does not have the greatest variation in duration relative to the mean. Some variation in the duration of patient interviews is expected and necessary, as each patient's needs are unique, and care should be personalized accordingly. Optimization of another component is more likely to have a greater impact on reducing the average duration of a patient's visit.

CV, which is a statistical relative measure of dispersion, allows SD to be interpreted relative to the mean, allowing for the comparison of multiple data sets that may have means of different magnitudes or units of measurement, as CV is dimensionless. A high CV indicates that values are widely spread around the mean. In a system with multiple processes, such as the various aspects of a patient's visit, the process with the highest CV should be optimized first to improve the system's overall reliability and efficiency. Optimization of vital parameter measurements, which has the highest CV (5 ÷ 8 = 0.62), will therefore most likely have the greatest impact on reducing the average time that patients spend in the practice.

In contrast, SD, which is an absolute measure of dispersion, describes the variability of data in relation to the mean within a single data set.

Scheduling follow-up visits does not have the highest CV (2 ÷ 6 = 0.33). Optimization of another component is more likely to have a greater impact on reducing the average duration of a patient's visit.

question_text:
A 32-year-old primigravid woman at 28 weeks' gestation comes to the office because she is concerned about having hepatitis E virus (HEV) infection. Yesterday, she saw a program on television about hepatitis E and its potential fulminant course in pregnant women. She feels well. Pregnancy has been uncomplicated. Her only medication is a prenatal vitamin; immunizations are up-to-date. The physician recently read a paper about a new test for HEV infection. The paper covered a trial that evaluated the efficacy of the new test in 145 pregnant women who presented to the emergency department with right upper quadrant pain, fever, vomiting, and jaundice. The findings of the trial are shown in the table:

Patients with hepatitis E
Patients without hepatitis E

Positive test result
15
30

Negative test result
10
90

The physician decides to try out the test in this patient. Which of the following is the most appropriate statement regarding the performance of the new HEV test in this patient compared to its performance in the trial?
content_preview: A 32-year-old primigravid woman at 28 weeks' gestation comes to the office because she is concerned about having hepatitis E virus (HEV) infection. Yesterday, she saw a program on television about hepatitis E and its potential fulminant course in pregnant women. She feels well. Pregnancy has been uncomplicated. Her only medication is a prenatal vitamin; immunizations are up-to-date. The physician recently read a paper about a new test for HEV infection. The paper covered a trial that evaluated the efficacy of the new test in 145 pregnant women who presented to the emergency department with right upper quadrant pain, fever, vomiting, and jaundice. The findings of the trial are shown in the table: Patients with hepatitis E Patients without hepatitis E Positive test result 15 30 Negative test result 10 90 The physician decides to try out the test in this patient. Which of the following is the most appropriate statement regarding the performance of the new HEV test in this patient compared to its performance in the trial?
hint: The patient is asymptomatic and presenting to an office, whereas the study participants were drawn from a population of patients with symptoms of hepatitis presenting to an emergency department. Therefore, this patient has a lower pretest probability of HEV infection than the trial group.
learning_objective: Interpret the relationship between pretest probability and positive predictive value.

answers.content: Lower likelihood that if this patient has HEV infection, she will have a positive test
answers.explanation_why: The likelihood that a patient with a disease will have a true positive test result is referred to as the sensitivity of a test (true positive rate). Sensitivity is an intrinsic characteristic of the test that is not affected by pretest probability.

The positive likelihood ratio is calculated from sensitivity and specificity, which are intrinsic properties of a diagnostic test that are unaffected by the pretest probability. Therefore, the positive likelihood ratio of the test will not change when it is tested in this patient compared to the trial setting.

The positive predictive value (PPV) is the likelihood that an individual with a positive test result truly has the disease, i.e., true positives/(true positives + false positives). PPV is directly related to pretest probability; PPV decreases as pretest probability decrease. Similarly, a decrease in prevalence results in a lower pretest probability and, therefore, a decrease in PPV. The study population prevalence of HEV infection in this scenario is 25/145 = 17%, which is certainly much higher than the prevalence of Hepatitis E for the general population. Negative predictive value (NPV) is inversely related to pretest probability; NPV increases as pretest probability decreases.

Pretest probability does not influence intrinsic test characteristics, i.e., sensitivity, specificity, negative likelihood ratio, and positive likelihood ratio.

images.title: Effect of prevalence on post-test probabilities

answers.content: Lower likelihood that if this patient's test is negative, she truly does not have HEV infection
answers.explanation_why: The likelihood that a patient with a negative test truly does not have the disease is the negative predictive value (NPV). The NPV would increase, not decrease, because the pretest probability of HEV infection is lower in this patient.

Precision (i.e., reliability) is the reproducibility of test results on the same sample under similar conditions. Therefore, precision can only be calculated from data obtained in a consistent setting (e.g., test results from groups of trial participants) and is not applicable to the performance of a test in a single individual.

question_text: A 76-year-old woman comes to the office for a follow-up visit 8 months after undergoing transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR). Medical history is otherwise remarkable for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient has been on dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) with clopidogrel and aspirin since TAVR. Other medications include lisinopril and metformin. The patient feels well but is concerned about the number of pills she is taking. She asks about the benefit of taking “two blood clot pills” and wants to know whether she can discontinue one of them. The physician informs the patient that one important indication for antiplatelet therapy after TAVR is the risk of stroke. The physician reviews a recent metaanalysis comparing the effects of single antiplatelet therapy (SAPT) to DAPT on the risk of disabling ischemic stroke 6–12 months after TAVR. The graph shows the results of the study. Based on the graph, which of the following conclusions about the metaanalysis is most appropriate?
content_preview: A 76-year-old woman comes to the office for a follow-up visit 8 months after undergoing transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR). Medical history is otherwise remarkable for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient has been on dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) with clopidogrel and aspirin since TAVR. Other medications include lisinopril and metformin. The patient feels well but is concerned about the number of pills she is taking. She asks about the benefit of taking “two blood clot pills” and wants to know whether she can discontinue one of them. The physician informs the patient that one important indication for antiplatelet therapy after TAVR is the risk of stroke. The physician reviews a recent metaanalysis comparing the effects of single antiplatelet therapy (SAPT) to DAPT on the risk of disabling ischemic stroke 6–12 months after TAVR. The graph shows the results of the study. Based on the graph, which of the following conclusions about the metaanalysis is most appropriate?
hint: The graph shown is a forest plot that summarizes the findings of a metaanalysis. Squares and horizontal lines represent the results from individual studies, and the combined results are represented by a diamond.
learning_objective: Interpret forest plots, and determine the statistical significance of meta-analysis results.

answers.content: The results indicate publication bias and should not be used to make a clinical decision
answers.explanation_why: Publication bias occurs when the findings of a study affect the likelihood of its publication, typically causing an imbalance toward the publication of positive results. In a metaanalysis, publication bias can be evaluated with a funnel plot and certain statistical tests (e.g., Begg's and Egger's tests). The graph in this scenario is a forest plot that summarizes the relative risk of ischemic stroke in the included studies and does not contain information about publication bias.

answers.content: The sample sizes of the individual studies were too small to compare the overall risks of ischemic stroke
answers.explanation_why: In a forest plot, the sample size of each study is typically represented by the size of its corresponding square; the larger the sample size, the larger the square. Additionally, the sample sizes of individual studies are taken into account when calculating the pooled result (e.g., relative risk), which is represented by the diamond. The graph does not provide enough information on whether the sample sizes of the individual studies were too small to be compared.

answers.content: Ischemic stroke was more common in patients receiving DAPT than in patients receiving SAPT
answers.explanation_why: The mean value (i.e., horizontal line) of the summary of all studies (i.e., the diamond) is > 1. This means that the relative risk (RR) of ischemic stroke 6–12 months after TAVR in patients on SAPT compared to DAPT is > 1. Although more patients on SAPT had an ischemic stroke, the difference was not statistically significant because the confidence interval included the null value.

answers.content: None of the included studies showed a statistically significant increase in risk of ischemic stroke of SAPT compared to DAPT
answers.explanation_why: In a forest plot, the horizontal line of each study represents the width of the confidence interval (CI). A horizontal line crossing the middle vertical line (i.e., the line of null effect) indicates that the CI includes the null value (a RR of 1 in this scenario) and that the result of the study is not statistically significant. There are two studies (B and F) in this metaanalysis for which the CI does not include the null value, indicating statistically significant results. Study B reports a statistically significant RR of ∼ 1.5 in patients who received SAPT compared to those who received DAPT, i.e., an increase in the risk of ischemic stroke.

answers.content: Patients on SAPT appeared to have no statistically significant difference in the risk of ischemic stroke compared to patients on DAPT
answers.explanation_why:
In this forest plot, the left column lists the included studies (A–F). The next column shows the primary outcome measure that is being compared between the studies, which is the relative risk (RR) of ischemic stroke in patients receiving SAPT versus DAPT 6–12 months after TAVR. The central vertical line on the x-axis represents the point of null effect (a RR of 1 in this scenario).

The results of each study are represented as squares and vertical and horizontal lines. The vertical line at the center of each square represents the point estimate of the effect of the intervention in the respective study, and the horizontal line of each square represents the confidence interval (CI) of the results (typically 95%). The area of each square is proportional to the weight that the corresponding study is given in the overall metaanalysis (e.g., based on sample size and/or statistical power). The larger the square, the more weight the result of the individual study carries.

The diamond at the bottom of the plot represents the combined results of all studies; its midpoint corresponds to the point estimate of the summary result, and its width reflects the CI.

Because the CI of the summary (i.e., diamond) in this forest plot crosses the vertical line of no effect (i.e., RR = 1), there is no statistically significant difference in the relative risk of ischemic stroke between patients on SAPT and those on DAPT in this study.

question_text: A clinical trial is performed to assess the efficacy of a new antidiabetic drug in decreasing serum glucose concentration. A total of 500 participants are enrolled and randomly assigned to receive either the new drug or a placebo. After 6 months, the mean glucose concentration is 121 mg/dL in the new drug group and 124 mg/dL in the placebo group, with a p-value of 0.02 for the observation. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the study result?
content_preview: A clinical trial is performed to assess the efficacy of a new antidiabetic drug in decreasing serum glucose concentration. A total of 500 participants are enrolled and randomly assigned to receive either the new drug or a placebo. After 6 months, the mean glucose concentration is 121 mg/dL in the new drug group and 124 mg/dL in the placebo group, with a p-value of 0.02 for the observation. Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the study result?
hint: Implementation of research results in clinical practice requires appropriate interpretation.
learning_objective: Interpret the difference between statistical significance and clinical significance.

answers.content: There is a 2% probability that the observed effect will be seen again if the trial is repeated under similar conditions
answers.explanation_why:
The p-value of 0.02 means that if the null hypothesis (H_0) is true, there is a 2% probability of obtaining results as extreme or more extreme than those observed on repeated testing. This is not the same as saying that there is a 2% probability of obtaining the observed effect if the study is repeated.

The concept can be understood by flipping a coin twice with the H_0 of the coin not being loaded. There are three possible outcomes: two heads (HH), one head and one tail (HT or TH), and two tails (TT) with probabilities of 0.25, 0.5, and 0.25, respectively. If we get the outcome of HH, the p-value for this observation is the probability of obtaining HH plus the sum of the probabilities of outcomes as likely or less likely than HH, which would be 0.25 + 0.25 = 0.5.

answers.content: The new drug is unlikely to have a clinically significant impact on patient outcome
answers.explanation_why: The results of a trial are considered clinically significant if they are likely to have a substantial impact on patient outcomes. Although the study shows that the new antidiabetic drug leads to a statistically significant reduction in mean glucose concentration (p < 0.05), this 3 mg/dL decrease is unlikely to benefit patients and have a clinically significant impact on outcomes. Statistical significance and clinical significance do not necessarily correlate. In contrast to statistical significance, there are no predetermined parameters for measuring clinical significance. To estimate the clinical significance of a trial, effect size measures (e.g., Cohen-d, relative risk), impact on patient outcomes, and overall context of the disease, such as prevalence and course (e.g., mortality, morbidity), must be considered.

answers.content: There is a 98% probability that the new antidiabetic drug is better than placebo
answers.explanation_why: The p-value of 0.02 means that if the null hypothesis (H_0) is true, there is a 2% probability that repeat tests will obtain results at least as extreme as those observed in this test. This does not mean that there is a 98% probability that the alternative hypothesis (H_1; that the new antidiabetic drug is better than the placebo) is true.

answers.content: The 95% confidence intervals of each group's serum glucose concentration do not overlap
answers.explanation_why: If 95% confidence intervals (CIs) do not overlap, there is a statistically significant difference (i.e., the p-value is < 0.05) between the two groups in question. However, the converse statement is not true; a p-value of < 0.05 does not imply that the 95% CIs do not overlap. The 95% CIs can overlap and still result in a p-value of < 0.05.

question_text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a progressively worsening cough for the past 3 weeks. His mother reports that the coughs occur in bouts and are occasionally followed by vomiting. One week ago, he was prescribed amoxicillin, but his cough has continued to worsen. Immunization records are not available. His two cousins, with whom he spent Thanksgiving, have similar symptoms. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 102/64 mmHg. A new rapid test to confirm pertussis has a sensitivity of 10% and a specificity of 90%. Based on this information, which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the test?
content_preview: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a progressively worsening cough for the past 3 weeks. His mother reports that the coughs occur in bouts and are occasionally followed by vomiting. One week ago, he was prescribed amoxicillin, but his cough has continued to worsen. Immunization records are not available. His two cousins, with whom he spent Thanksgiving, have similar symptoms. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 102/64 mmHg. A new rapid test to confirm pertussis has a sensitivity of 10% and a specificity of 90%. Based on this information, which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding the test?
hint: Likelihood ratios, which are calculated from sensitivity and specificity, can be used to determine the utility of a diagnostic test. A likelihood ratio compares the probability of a test result in an individual with the disease to the probability of the same result in an individual without the disease.
learning_objective: Interpret likelihood ratios to determine the utility of a diagnostic test.

answers.content: The test is not useful to confirm pertussis.
answers.explanation_why:
Generally, a test with a high specificity can be used to rule in a disease. However, a test with high specificity but very low sensitivity has a poor diagnostic value. For such a test, the positive likelihood ratio (LR^+), which is sensitivity/(1 - specificity), should be determined first. In this scenario, LR^+ is 10%/(100% - 90%) = 1, indicating that patients without pertussis are just as likely to have a positive test as patients with pertussis.

Similarly, a disease cannot effectively be ruled out using a test with a high sensitivity but very low specificity. For such a test, the negative likelihood ratio (LR^-), which is (1 - sensitivity)/specificity, should be determined first. In this scenario, LR^- is (100% - 10%)/90% = 1, indicating that patients with pertussis are just as likely to have a negative test as patients without pertussis.

This test with an LR^+ and LR^- of 1 has no clinical utility. A test with an LR^+ > 10 is highly effective at ruling in a disease. An LR^- < 0.1 indicates that a test is highly effective at ruling out a disease.

answers.content: There is a 10% probability that a patient with a positive test has pertussis.
answers.explanation_why: The probability that a patient with a positive test has pertussis is the positive predictive value (PPV), which cannot be estimated because the pretest probability for pertussis is unknown. PPV should not be confused with sensitivity, the probability of a patient with pertussis having a positive test.

answers.content: There is a 50% probability that a patient with a negative test does not have pertussis.
answers.explanation_why: The probability that a patient with a negative test does not have pertussis is the negative predictive value (NPV), which cannot be estimated because the pretest probability for pertussis is unknown. Given the sensitivity and specificity in this scenario, an NPV of 50% can only be obtained by assuming a 50% pretest probability of pertussis (e.g., a sample of 200 patients, of whom 100 have pertussis and 100 do not).

answers.content: There is a 10% probability that a patient with pertussis has a negative test.
answers.explanation_why: The probability that a patient with pertussis has a negative test is the false negative rate, which is equal to 1 - sensitivity. The false negative rate in this scenario is 100% - 10% = 90%.

answers.content: There is not enough information to determine the diagnostic value of the test.
answers.explanation_why: There is insufficient information to determine post-test probabilities (e.g., negative predictive value, positive predictive value) because the pretest probability for pertussis is unknown. However, the test's sensitivity and specificity are sufficient to determine the diagnostic value of the test.

question_text:
A phase 2 multicenter, double-blind randomized superiority trial is performed to compare the efficacy of a new mood-stabilizing drug to lithium for reducing the risk of acute manic episodes in patients with bipolar disorder. The investigators plan to enroll 300 individuals with bipolar disorder over one year and assign them to receive either the new drug or lithium for 2 years. An interim analysis performed by the data monitoring committee 6 months after the start of the study reveals that several patients in the trial developed myocardial infarction. The results of the interim analysis for 187 participants over a 4-month period are shown:

New drug (n = 93)
Lithium (n = 94)
Relative risk (95% CI)

Incidence of a manic episode
6.4%
14.9%
0.43 (0.17, 1.07)

Incidence of myocardial infarction
4.3%
1.1%
3.90 (0.46, 35.49)

The dropout rate at the time of the interim analysis is negligible. No events of myocardial infarction were reported during phase 0 and phase 1 trials of the new drug. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial recommendation by the data monitoring committee to the principal investigator?
content_preview: A phase 2 multicenter, double-blind randomized superiority trial is performed to compare the efficacy of a new mood-stabilizing drug to lithium for reducing the risk of acute manic episodes in patients with bipolar disorder. The investigators plan to enroll 300 individuals with bipolar disorder over one year and assign them to receive either the new drug or lithium for 2 years. An interim analysis performed by the data monitoring committee 6 months after the start of the study reveals that several patients in the trial developed myocardial infarction. The results of the interim analysis for 187 participants over a 4-month period are shown: New drug (n = 93) Lithium (n = 94) Relative risk (95% CI) Incidence of a manic episode 6.4% 14.9% 0.43 (0.17, 1.07) Incidence of myocardial infarction 4.3% 1.1% 3.90 (0.46, 35.49) The dropout rate at the time of the interim analysis is negligible. No events of myocardial infarction were reported during phase 0 and phase 1 trials of the new drug. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial recommendation by the data monitoring committee to the principal investigator?
hint: Unexpected adverse events (UAEs) typically occur in phase 2 and phase 3 trials because these phases involve a large number of participants who all have the disease of interest, whereas phase 0 or phase 1 trials are typically performed on a small number of healthy individuals.
learning_objective: Interpret interim analysis results, and choose the appropriate action for unexpected serious adverse events in clinical trials.

answers.content: Discontinue the trial because of futility
answers.explanation_why: A trial may be discontinued if it is shown to be futile (i.e., unable to achieve its objectives) because of a poor enrollment rate, higher than expected dropout rate, or clearly inferior treatment efficacy. However, in this scenario, enrollment rates are acceptable (187 of 300 planned participants have already been recruited in the first 6 months), dropout rates are negligible, and the new drug does not show an inferior efficacy compared to lithium. A different recommendation is more appropriate.

answers.content: Continue the trial but inform unaffected and new participants about the risk of myocardial infarction
answers.explanation_why: If UAEs occur during a trial, it may be necessary to provide additional information both to current and new participants as part of the informed consent process. However, in this scenario, a different initial step is needed to determine whether the UAE is related to the trial.

answers.content: Continue the trial because the results are not statistically significant
answers.explanation_why:
Neither result of the interim analysis is statistically significant because the 95% confidence intervals (CIs) of the relative risks cross the null value of one. Continuing the trial as planned with more participants would narrow the CIs and likely result in statistical significance. However, for UAEs (especially serious ones, such as myocardial infarction), the lack of statistical significance in an interim analysis is not a reason to continue the trial.

For expected adverse events, stopping rules, which take statistical significance and other factors into account, can help determine whether to continue a trial.

answers.content: Discontinue the trial until the reasons for myocardial infarction in the participants are clear
answers.explanation_why:
Every trial requires a monitoring plan (e.g., interim analysis by a data monitoring committee) to ensure participant safety and scientific merit. Ongoing trials are discontinued when there is evidence of futility, safety concerns, or early evidence of clear benefit. A UAE, especially if it is serious (e.g., myocardial infarction), should result in temporary discontinuation of the clinical trial (even if the risk is not statistically significant on the interim analysis) until the reasons for the event are determined.

If the adverse event is determined to be related to the trial, it may be necessary to modify the research protocol (e.g., by altering the exclusion or inclusion criteria, changing the dosing, increasing the monitoring frequency) to minimize the risk to participants. Protocol modifications need approval from the institutional review board and often require reconfirming informed consent for ongoing participation. The trial should be terminated if it is not feasible to minimize risk to an acceptable level.

answers.content: Continue the trial but exclude participants with additional risk factors for myocardial infarction
answers.explanation_why: If a UAE is shown to be related to research and restricting certain participants from the trial can reduce risk to an acceptable level, a change in the exclusion criteria (with approval from the institutional review board) may be appropriate. However, a different initial step is needed to determine whether the UAE is related to the trial in this scenario.

question_text:
Question
In patients with type 2 diabetes and concomitant chronic kidney disease, how does ambogliflozin combination therapy (SGLT-2 inhibitor ambogliflozin plus metformin) vs. standard combination therapy (standard SGLT-2 inhibitor plus metformin) affect long-term kidney function and glycemic control?
Methods
Design: Prospective, randomized controlled trial (Ambogliflozin in Chronic Kidney Disease Study). ClinicalTrials.gov FJIM 11001110.
Allocation: Concealed.
Blinding: Double-blinded.
Follow-up period: Up to 5 years.
Setting: 4 veterans care centers in Montana, Idaho, and Wyoming.
Patients: 300 patients (mean age 65 ± 5.4 years, 95% men) with chronic kidney disease (stage G3–5; eGFR < 60 mL/min/1.73 m²) and type 2 diabetes receiving a combination regimen with an SGLT-2 inhibitor and metformin. Exclusion criteria were diabetic neuropathy, hemoglobin A_1c > 8.5%, and previous kidney transplant. The alpha level was set at 0.05.
Interventions: Ambogliflozin plus metformin (n = 150) vs. standard SGLT-2 inhibitor plus metformin (n = 150).
Outcomes: Mean change in eGFR, hemoglobin A_1c, systolic blood pressure, and BMI; and incidence of hypoglycemia, diabetic retinopathy, and cardiovascular complications (i.e., stroke and myocardial infarction).
Patient follow-up: 98% (minimum follow-up of 3 years).
Main results
The study found that patients in the ambogliflozin group had a significant improvement in kidney function as measured by eGFR compared to those who received standard combination therapy (mean change from baseline of +2.3 mL/min/1.73 m² vs. -0.5 mL/min/1.73 m², p < 0.001). The incidence of diabetic retinopathy was also significantly lower in the ambogliflozin group (7% vs. 12%, RR = 0.6).
Ambogliflozin vs. standard combination therapy in patients with chronic kidney disease and type 2 diabetes

Outcome
Ambogliflozin combination therapy
Standard combination therapy
P-value

Mean change in eGFR (mL/min/1.73 m^2) ± 2 SD
+2.3 ± 0.2
-0.5 ± 0.3
< 0.001

Mean change in hemoglobin A_1c (%) ± 2 SD 
-0.5 ± 0.3
-0.2 ± 0.1
0.1

Mean change in systolic blood pressure (mm Hg) ± 2 SD 
-5 ± 1
-3 ± 2
0.12

Mean change in BMI (kg/m^2) ± 2 SD 
-3 ± 1
-1 ± 3
0.5

Outcome
Ambogliflozin combination therapy
Standard combination therapy
Relative risk (95% CI)

Incidence of hypoglycemia
10%
12%
0.8 (0.5–1.2)

Incidence of diabetic retinopathy
7%
12%
0.6 (0.4–0.9)

Incidence of cardiovascular complications
12%
13%
0.9 (0.7–1.2)

Conclusion
In this study, ambogliflozin combination therapy was more effective than standard combination therapy in improving long-term kidney function and preventing diabetic retinopathy in patients with type 2 diabetes and concomitant chronic kidney disease.
Sources of funding: AMBOSS Pharmaceuticals 
Structured abstract based on: Doe J*, Roe J*, et al. Ambogliflozin in Chronic Kidney Disease Study: a randomized controlled trial. Fictional Journal of Internal Medicine. 2023;109:91–111. 11001110

A 68-year-old man with a 20-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician for a follow-up visit. One week ago, he had an ophthalmologist appointment during which he underwent repeat laser photocoagulation for severe nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy. Medical history is also notable for diabetic chronic kidney disease, hypertension, and a stroke 3 years ago. He feels well. Current medications include metformin, empagliflozin, enalapril, atorvastatin, and aspirin. Pulse is 79/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 121/83 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show an HbA_1c of 6.8%, which is at target, and an eGFR of 53 mL/min/1.73 m². Urine albumin to creatinine ratio is 30 mg/g. The patient is a retired military physician who is following recent developments in the pharmaceutical market. He considers a switch from empagliflozin to ambogliflozin therapy. Based on the abstract shown, informing this patient of which of the following effects of the new treatment on his condition is most appropriate?

Sources of funding: AMBOSS Pharmaceuticals Structured abstract based on: Doe J*, Roe J*, et al. Ambogliflozin in Chronic Kidney Disease Study: a randomized controlled trial. Fictional Journal of Internal Medicine. 2023;109:91–111. 11001110 A 68-year-old man with a 20-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician for a follow-up visit. One week ago, he had an ophthalmologist appointment during which he underwent repeat laser photocoagulation for severe nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy. Medical history is also notable for diabetic chronic kidney disease, hypertension, and a stroke 3 years ago. He feels well. Current medications include metformin, empagliflozin, enalapril, atorvastatin, and aspirin. Pulse is 79/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 121/83 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show an HbA1c of 6.8%, which is at target, and an eGFR of 53 mL/min/1.73 m². Urine albumin to creatinine ratio is 30 mg/g. Based on the abstract shown, informing this patient of which of the following effects of the new treatment on his condition is most appropriate?
hint: When applying study results to patient care, individual patient history should be taken into account to weigh up the most likely benefits and risks.
learning_objective: Interpret clinical trial results and apply them to individual patient care considering clinical significance.

answers.explanation_why: The most common adverse effects (AEs) of SGLT-2 inhibitors include urinary and genital tract infections, dehydration, weight loss, orthostatic hypotension, and severe diabetic ketoacidosis. However, the incidence of these AEs was not assessed in the study. The only AE assessed was hypoglycemia, and the difference in incidence between the ambogliflozin group and those who received standard combination therapy was not statistically significant (i.e., 95% confidence interval of the relative risk includes the null value 1). Other assessed outcomes are more likely to be complications of diabetes than AEs of treatment with an antidiabetic drug.

Although the study reports a lower incidence of diabetic retinopathy (DR) in the ambogliflozin group than in those who received standard combination therapy, this patient already has DR. Progression of preexisting DR was not an outcome measure of the study and the potential impact of ambogliflozin combination therapy on the progression of DR cannot be drawn from the results.

Statistical significance does not necessarily result in clinical significance. In the study, mean change in eGFR over time was statistically significantly higher (p < 0.001) in the ambogliflozin group (+2.3 ± 0.2 mL/min/1.73 m^2) than in those who received standard combination therapy (-0.5 ± 0.3 mL/min/1.73 m^2). However, while this patient has chronic kidney disease with an eGFR of 53 mL/min/1.73 m² (stage G3 according to the classification of CKD), an increase in eGFR of 2.3 mL/min/1.73 m² would most likely have no clinically significant benefit on his individual health outcomes. The only other statistically significant result of the trial is decreased incidence of diabetic retinopathy (DR) in the ambogliflozin group compared to those who received standard combination therapy. However, this patient already has DR and further studies would be needed to evaluate the impact of ambogliflozin combination therapy on the progression of preexisting DR.

The main results of the clinical trial show that patients treated with ambogliflozin combination therapy had an average BMI reduction of -3 ± 1 kg/m² over the study period vs. -1 ± 3 kg/m² in those who received standard combination therapy. However, this difference was not statistically significant, as the p-value (p = 0.5) was greater than the study's significance level of 0.05.

This patient's diabetes is already well-controlled at target HbA_1c values. Additionally, in the study, the difference in HbA_1c levels over time between the ambogliflozin group and those who received standard combination therapy was not statistically significant, as the p-value (p = 0.1) was greater than the study's significance level of 0.05.

question_text:
Question
In patients with type 2 diabetes and concomitant chronic kidney disease, how does ambogliflozin combination therapy (SGLT-2 inhibitor ambogliflozin plus metformin) vs. standard combination therapy (standard SGLT-2 inhibitor plus metformin) affect long-term kidney function and glycemic control?
Methods
Design: Prospective, randomized controlled trial (Ambogliflozin in Chronic Kidney Disease Study). ClinicalTrials.gov FJIM 11001110.
Allocation: Concealed.
Blinding: Double-blinded.
Follow-up period: Up to 5 years.
Setting: 4 veterans care centers in Montana, Idaho, and Wyoming.
Patients: 300 patients (mean age 65 ± 5.4 years, 95% men) with chronic kidney disease (stage G3–5; eGFR < 60 mL/min/1.73 m²) and type 2 diabetes receiving a combination regimen with an SGLT-2 inhibitor and metformin. Exclusion criteria were diabetic neuropathy, hemoglobin A_1c > 8.5%, and previous kidney transplant. The alpha level was set at 0.05.
Interventions: Ambogliflozin plus metformin (n = 150) vs. standard SGLT-2 inhibitor plus metformin (n = 150).
Outcomes: Mean change in eGFR, hemoglobin A_1c, systolic blood pressure, and BMI; and incidence of hypoglycemia, diabetic retinopathy, and cardiovascular complications (i.e., stroke and myocardial infarction).
Patient follow-up: 98% (minimum follow-up of 3 years).
Main results
The study found that patients in the ambogliflozin group had a significant improvement in kidney function as measured by eGFR compared to those who received standard combination therapy (mean change from baseline of +2.3 mL/min/1.73 m² vs. -0.5 mL/min/1.73 m², p < 0.001). The incidence of diabetic retinopathy was also significantly lower in the ambogliflozin group (7% vs. 12%, RR = 0.6).
Ambogliflozin vs. standard combination therapy in patients with chronic kidney disease and type 2 diabetes

Outcome
Ambogliflozin combination therapy
Standard combination therapy

Incidence of diabetic retinopathy

Incidence of cardiovascular complications
12%
13%
0.9 (0.7–1.2)

Conclusion
In this study, ambogliflozin combination therapy was more effective than standard combination therapy in improving long-term kidney function and preventing diabetic retinopathy in patients with type 2 diabetes and concomitant chronic kidney disease.
Sources of funding: AMBOSS Pharmaceuticals 
Structured abstract based on: Doe J*, Roe J*, et al. Ambogliflozin in Chronic Kidney Disease Study: a randomized controlled trial. Fictional Journal of Internal Medicine. 2023;109:91–111. 11001110

Which of the following most strongly limits the generalizability of the findings in the study?
