Fictional Journal of Internal Medicine. 2023;109:91–111. 11001110 Which of the following most strongly limits the generalizability of the findings in the study?
hint: To assess whether a study is generalizable, the study population characteristics and set-up of the trial have to be evaluated.
learning_objective: Recall factors that affect the generalizability of study findings.

answers.content: The statistician performing the analysis was blinded
answers.explanation_why: In double-blinded clinical trials, neither the participants nor the researchers know who is in the control group and who is in the treatment group. However, the statistician performing the analysis would not be blinded. The statistician would be blinded in a triple-blinded trial design. In addition, blinding generally reduces biases and increases internal validity in randomized controlled trials, which therefore increases rather than limits generalizability.

Allocation concealment (blind randomization) is a method used in randomized clinical trials to prevent selection bias. Participants are randomly assigned to either the treatment or the control group using techniques such as centralized randomization schemes and sequentially numbered containers. Concealed allocation is a quality criterion in randomized controlled trials and increases validity, which therefore increases rather than limits generalizability.

answers.content: Patient selection was not representative of the general patient population
answers.explanation_why: Generalizability (external validity) is the applicability of study results to populations other than the study population. A study must be internally valid to have external validity. However, high internal validity does not guarantee external validity. A lack of external validity can arise, for example, if the study population is not representative of the patient population as a whole. This study only included patients with chronic kidney disease and type 2 diabetes with HbA_1c ≤ 8.5% who did not have concomitant diabetic neuropathy or previous kidney transplant. In addition, the study population consisted only of veterans, and 95% of the participants were men. The study population is therefore unlikely to represent the patient population with type 2 diabetes and chronic kidney disease as a whole, which strongly limits generalizability.

answers.content: A large number of patients were lost to follow-up
answers.explanation_why: Loss to follow-up can result in attrition bias and can have a significant impact on the internal validity of a study, also limiting its generalizability. However, in this study, only 2% of patients were lost to follow-up.

answers.content: The treatment of chronic kidney disease is limited to quaternary care centers
answers.explanation_why: The level of care is an indicator of the complexity of medical cases treated. Some therapeutic interventions (e.g., experimental procedures, robot surgery) are only available at quarternary care centers because they must be performed by specialists who only practice in quarternary care centers. Studies using such interventions have limited generalizability because the treatment is often not accessible to the majority of patients. However, chronic kidney disease is a common long-term comorbidity of type 2 diabetes and can be treated by physicians practicing at secondary and tertiary care centers, and SGLT-2 inhibitors are widely available.

question_text:
Question
In patients with type 2 diabetes and concomitant chronic kidney disease, how does ambogliflozin combination therapy (SGLT-2 inhibitor ambogliflozin plus metformin) vs. standard combination therapy (standard SGLT-2 inhibitor plus metformin) affect long-term kidney function and glycemic control?
Methods
Design: Prospective, randomized controlled trial (Ambogliflozin in Chronic Kidney Disease Study). ClinicalTrials.gov FJIM 11001110.
Allocation: Concealed.
Blinding: Double-blinded.
Follow-up period: Up to 5 years.
Setting: 4 veterans care centers in Montana, Idaho, and Wyoming.
Patients: 300 patients (mean age 65 ± 5.4 years, 95% men) with chronic kidney disease (stage G3–5; eGFR < 60 mL/min/1.73 m²) and type 2 diabetes receiving a combination regimen with an SGLT-2 inhibitor and metformin. Exclusion criteria were diabetic neuropathy, hemoglobin A_1c > 8.5%, and previous kidney transplant. The alpha level was set at 0.05.
Interventions: Ambogliflozin plus metformin (n = 150) vs. standard SGLT-2 inhibitor plus metformin (n = 150).
Outcomes: Mean change in eGFR, hemoglobin A_1c, systolic blood pressure, and BMI; and incidence of hypoglycemia, diabetic retinopathy, and cardiovascular complications (i.e., stroke and myocardial infarction).
Patient follow-up: 98% (minimum follow-up of 3 years).
Main results
The study found that patients in the ambogliflozin group had a significant improvement in kidney function as measured by eGFR compared to those who received standard combination therapy (mean change from baseline of +2.3 mL/min/1.73 m² vs. -0.5 mL/min/1.73 m², p < 0.001). The incidence of diabetic retinopathy was also significantly lower in the ambogliflozin group (7% vs. 12%, RR = 0.6).
Ambogliflozin vs. standard combination therapy in patients with chronic kidney disease and type 2 diabetes

Outcome
Ambogliflozin combination therapy
Standard combination therapy
P-value

-1 ± 3

Outcome

Relative risk (95% CI)

Incidence of hypoglycemia
10%

Incidence of diabetic retinopathy
7%
12%
0.6 (0.4–0.9)

Incidence of cardiovascular complications
12%
13%
0.9 (0.7–1.2)

Conclusion
In this study, ambogliflozin combination therapy was more effective than standard combination therapy in improving long-term kidney function and preventing diabetic retinopathy in patients with type 2 diabetes and concomitant chronic kidney disease.
Sources of funding: AMBOSS Pharmaceuticals 
Structured abstract based on: Doe J*, Roe J*, et al. Ambogliflozin in Chronic Kidney Disease Study: a randomized controlled trial. Fictional Journal of Internal Medicine. 2023;109:91–111. 11001110

hint: The outcomes of this study are reported as mean change ± 2 SD with corresponding p-values, and incidence with corresponding relative risk and 95% confidence interval.
learning_objective: Interpret relative risk, and calculate relative risk reduction.

answers.content: Patients in the ambogliflozin group had a 10% reduced risk of developing hypoglycemia compared to those who received standard combination therapy
answers.explanation_why: Patients in the ambogliflozin group had a (nonsignificant) 20% reduced risk of developing hypoglycemia compared to those who received standard combination therapy (relative risk reduction). The absolute risk of developing hypoglycemia was 2% lower in patients treated with ambogliflozin combination therapy than in those who received standard combination therapy (10% vs. 12%, respectively).

answers.content: The risk of developing cardiovascular complications in the ambogliflozin group was 10% lower than the risk in those who received standard combination therapy
answers.explanation_why: Patients in the ambogliflozin group had a relative risk of developing cardiovascular complications of 0.9 compared to patients who received standard combination therapy. This means that patients in the ambogliflozin group had a (nonsignificant) 10% reduced risk of developing cardiovascular complications compared to those who received standard combination therapy (relative risk reduction). The absolute risk of developing cardiovascular complications, on the other hand, was 1% lower in patients in the ambogliflozin group than in those who received standard combination therapy (12% vs. 13%, respectively).

answers.content: Patients in the ambogliflozin group were 3 times more likely to lose weight compared to those who received standard combination therapy
answers.explanation_why: There was no statistically significant difference in mean body mass index (BMI) reduction between the two groups (p-value > alpha level). Additionally, the table reports the crude variation in BMI over time, not the likelihood of losing weight in one arm vs. the other arm of the trial. In order to obtain this information, the investigators would need to fit a linear regression model investigating the association between ambogliflozin combination therapy and BMI reduction over time.

answers.content: Patients treated with ambogliflozin combination therapy had a 40% reduction in risk of developing diabetic retinopathy compared to patients treated with standard combination therapy
answers.explanation_why:
In this study, the incidence of diabetic retinopathy (DR) has a relative risk (RR) of 0.6 in patients treated with ambogliflozin combination therapy compared to standard combination therapy. The confidence interval does not include the null value of 1 and the results are therefore statistically significant. When results of a study are presented as RR, the corresponding relative risk reduction (if RR < 1) is calculated as follows: % risk reduction = (1 - RR) x 100; relative risk increase (if RR > 1) is calculated as follows: % risk increase = (RR - 1) x 100. In this study, relative risk reduction is (1 - 0.6) x 100 = 40%.

Relative risk reduction should not be confused with absolute risk reduction (ARR), which is calculated as follows: ARR = risk in control group - risk in treatment group. In this study, the ARR for DR would be 12% - 7% = 5%. The risk of developing DR in the ambogliflozin group is therefore 5% lower than the risk of developing DR in the standard combination therapy group.

question_text: A pharmaceutical company is sponsoring a phase 3 randomized controlled trial to evaluate the efficacy of a newly developed recombinant vaccine against a highly virulent novel pathogen and to generate a hypothesis about the effects of the new vaccine on herd immunity in high-risk, immunocompromised individuals. The efficacy and safety of the new vaccine have been demonstrated in a prior phase 2 trial sponsored by the same company. The researchers are conducting a trial in community hospitals in 350 towns. Each hospital is randomly assigned to administer either the standard vaccine or the new vaccine. All staff, patients, and visitors at each hospital are invited to enroll in the study. The data is collected by nurses who have full insight into the study protocol, including which group the hospital belongs to, and they transfer the data to the evaluating researchers who also have full insight into the protocol. Because they must keep records of potential side effects, the physician assistants administering the vaccines are also informed about which vaccines the participants are given. The participants are not informed about which of the two vaccines they receive. The endpoint is to compare the efficacy of the new vaccine to the standard vaccine and to form a hypothesis about its effect on herd immunity in immunocompromised individuals. Which of the following best describes the study design?
content_preview: A pharmaceutical company is sponsoring a phase 3 randomized controlled trial to evaluate the efficacy of a newly developed recombinant vaccine against a highly virulent novel pathogen and to generate a hypothesis about the effects of the new vaccine on herd immunity in high-risk, immunocompromised individuals. The efficacy and safety of the new vaccine have been demonstrated in a prior phase 2 trial sponsored by the same company. The researchers are conducting a trial in community hospitals in 350 towns. Each hospital is randomly assigned to administer either the standard vaccine or the new vaccine. All staff, patients, and visitors at each hospital are invited to enroll in the study. The data is collected by nurses who have full insight into the study protocol, including which group the hospital belongs to, and they transfer the data to the evaluating researchers who also have full insight into the protocol. Because they must keep records of potential side effects, the physician assistants administering the vaccines are also informed about which vaccines the participants are given. The participants are not informed about which of the two vaccines they receive. The endpoint is to compare the efficacy of the new vaccine to the standard vaccine and to form a hypothesis about its effect on herd immunity in immunocompromised individuals. Which of the following best describes the study design?
learning_objective: Choose the appropriate study design based on group or cluster randomization.

answers.explanation_why: In studies with a cluster design, participants are randomized in groups or clusters rather than individually. In this study, the clusters consist of hospitals, which are randomized into either the intervention group (new vaccine) or the control group (standard vaccine), and all participants at each hospital receive the same vaccine. Cluster randomized trials have a lower risk of contamination of intervention. For example, in this study, the effects of the two vaccines can be observed separately. If the participants had been individually randomized into intervention and control groups, each vaccine's efficacy would be difficult to evaluate because of the other vaccine's effects on herd immunity in the community. Other advantages of cluster randomization include typically lower costs than other study designs and simpler enrollment procedures. On the downside, cluster randomized trials have low statistical power because the units of analysis are groups rather than individual participants. In addition, recruitment bias can occur when participants are enrolled after interventions have already been allocated to clusters.

In a placebo-controlled trial, the control group is given a placebo to evaluate the efficacy of the treatment used in the intervention group. In this study, the control group will receive the standard vaccine rather than a placebo. Furthermore, a placebo-controlled study design could be unethical for trials in vulnerable populations. Because this study involves a highly virulent pathogen and high-risk, immunocompromised participants, a placebo-controlled study design is inappropriate.

In a single-arm study, all participants receive the same intervention and there is no control group. In this study, participants receiving the new vaccine are being compared to participants receiving the standard vaccine.

In a double-blinded study, both the participants and the researchers are not informed about which intervention each participant is receiving. Although the participants in this study are blinded, the researchers are not.

In a factorial study, multiple interventions are tested simultaneously, and their combined effects are examined. This study design can identify interactions between interventions (e.g., synergistic effects of drug combinations). The study in this scenario only compares a single dose of two vaccines.

question_text:
A 62-year-old man comes to the office with epigastric pain, flatulence, and a 1.4-kg (3-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. He emigrated to the United States 2 months ago. Prior to that, he had always lived in Nigeria, which has an overall prevalence of H. pylori infection of 85%. The patient is given a urea breath test for suspected H. pylori infection, and the result is negative. The urea breath test has a sensitivity of 90% and a specificity of 96%. The physician finds an article on the performance of the urea breath test in primary care patients in Nigeria who present with symptoms of dyspepsia. The results of the study are shown in the table.

Patients with
H. pylori infection
Patients without
H. pylori infection

Urea breath test positive
495
4

Urea breath test negative

55
94

Which of the following formulas best estimates the likelihood that the patient does not have an H. pylori infection?
content_preview: A 62-year-old man comes to the office with epigastric pain, flatulence, and a 1.4-kg (3-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. He emigrated to the United States 2 months ago. Prior to that, he had always lived in Nigeria, which has an overall prevalence of H. pylori infection of 85%. The patient is given a urea breath test for suspected H. pylori infection, and the result is negative. The urea breath test has a sensitivity of 90% and a specificity of 96%. The physician finds an article on the performance of the urea breath test in primary care patients in Nigeria who present with symptoms of dyspepsia. The results of the study are shown in the table. Patients withH. pylori infection Patients withoutH. pylori infection Urea breath test positive 495 4 Urea breath test negative 55 94 Which of the following formulas best estimates the likelihood that the patient does not have an H. pylori infection?
hint: The likelihood that an individual with a negative test for a disease truly does not have the disease is the test's negative predictive value (NPV).
learning_objective: Calculate the negative predictive value (NPV) of a diagnostic test.

answers.explanation_why: This formula calculates the negative likelihood ratio (LR^-), which measures the diagnostic utility of a test. LR^- is the likelihood of an individual who has the disease testing negative divided by the likelihood of an individual who does not have the disease testing negative. LR^-  is calculated as (1 - sensitivity)/specificity.

This formula calculates the false positive rate (FPR) of the test, which is 1 - specificity. Because the specificity of a test is its true negative rate, the FPR in this scenario is calculated as 1 - 0.96 = 0.04. The FPR of a test can also be calculated as the proportion of false positives to the total number of patients without the disease or FP/(FP + TN). The FPR in this scenario is calculated as 4/(4 + 94) = 4/98 = 0.04.

This formula calculates the NPV of the test, which is the proportion of negative test results that are true negatives. In this scenario, the test's NPV is the likelihood that a patient with a negative test for H. pylori infection truly does not have the disease. NPV is calculated as the number of true negatives divided by the total number of negative test results or TN/(FN + TN). The NPV in this scenario is 94/(55 + 94) = 0.63 or 63%.

This formula calculates the overall accuracy of the test, which is the proportion of true test results to the total number of test results: (TP + TN)/(TP + TN + FP + FN). The accuracy of a test provides no information regarding the likelihood that an individual with a negative test result truly does not have H. pylori infection.

This formula calculates the false negative rate (FNR) of the test, which is 1 - sensitivity. Because the sensitivity of a test is its true positive rate, the FNR in this scenario is calculated as 1 - 0.9 = 0.1. The FNR of a test can also be calculated as the proportion of false negatives to the total number of patients with the disease or FN/(TP + FN). The FNR in this scenario is calculated as 55/(495 + 55) = 55/550 = 0.1.

question_text: A clinical trial is performed to assess the efficacy of a dietary supplement in decreasing the risk of developing type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM). Eight hundred white men between 40 and 60 years of age without preexisting illnesses are randomly assigned to receive the dietary supplement or placebo. After following the subjects for 10 years, the results of the trial show no statistically significant difference in the risk of developing T2DM between the subjects receiving the supplement and the group receiving the placebo. One year later, the researchers receive another grant and decide to further analyze the data collected during the trial. They now categorize the participants into 7 groups according to the participants' fasting plasma glucose (FPG) at the beginning of the trial. One group is categorized as FPG < 70 mg/dL; the other study participants are divided into 6 groups according to the following value ranges: 70–74 mg/dL, 75–79 mg/dL, 80–84 mg/dL, 85–89 mg/dL, 90–94 mg/dL, and 95–99 mg/dL. The researchers observe that subjects with an FPG of 95–99 mg/dL who took the supplement had a 4% lower risk of developing T2DM compared to subjects in this category who took the placebo. The result was statistically significant. Which of the following is the most accurate reason for questioning the internal validity of the supplement's efficacy analysis among subjects with an FPG of 95–99 mg/dL?
content_preview: A clinical trial is performed to assess the efficacy of a dietary supplement in decreasing the risk of developing type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM). Eight hundred white men between 40 and 60 years of age without preexisting illnesses are randomly assigned to receive the dietary supplement or placebo. After following the subjects for 10 years, the results of the trial show no statistically significant difference in the risk of developing T2DM between the subjects receiving the supplement and the group receiving the placebo. One year later, the researchers receive another grant and decide to further analyze the data collected during the trial. They now categorize the participants into 7 groups according to the participants' fasting plasma glucose (FPG) at the beginning of the trial. One group is categorized as FPG < 70 mg/dL; the other study participants are divided into 6 groups according to the following value ranges: 70–74 mg/dL, 75–79 mg/dL, 80–84 mg/dL, 85–89 mg/dL, 90–94 mg/dL, and 95–99 mg/dL. The researchers observe that subjects with an FPG of 95–99 mg/dL who took the supplement had a 4% lower risk of developing T2DM compared to subjects in this category who took the placebo. The result was statistically significant. Which of the following is the most accurate reason for questioning the internal validity of the supplement's efficacy analysis among subjects with an FPG of 95–99 mg/dL?
hint: Grouping study participants into categories and analyzing these groups is a subgroup analysis. Posthoc subgroup analysis may identify a statistically significant effect, but outcomes should always be interpreted with caution.
learning_objective: Recall the implications of posthoc subgroup analysis on internal validity.

answers.content: Results of the overall trial showed no statistically significant difference.
answers.explanation_why: The statistical significance of the results of the overall trial does not affect the internal validity of the subgroup analysis. Even if the overall trial shows no statistically significant difference between the treatment groups, a properly performed subgroup analysis may be able to detect statistically significant differences for subgroups of the trial. There is a different reason to question the validity of subgroup analysis in this scenario.

answers.content: Participants with a higher fasting plasma glucose were more likely to withdraw from the clinical trial.
answers.explanation_why: Attrition bias, which can cause differences between the experimental and the control group as a result of selective loss of participants to follow-up, can limit the internal validity of a trial’s results. In this case, there is no information about selective loss to follow-up. Regardless of the possibility of an attrition bias, the subgroup analysis compares one group with an FPG of 95–99 mg/dL with another group that has the same FPG. Therefore, even if participants with a higher FPG were more likely to withdraw from the clinical trial, this selective loss to follow-up would not threaten the internal validity of a subgroup analysis comparing results within one subgroup.

answers.content: Incidence of type 2 diabetes mellitus is higher in individuals with an elevated fasting plasma glucose.
answers.explanation_why: Elevated plasma glucose levels (100–125 mg/dL) are defined as prediabetes and are associated with an increased risk of developing diabetes mellitus (DM). Plasma glucose levels of < 100 mg/dL are considered normal and there is no sufficient evidence that these levels are associated with an increased risk of DM. In addition, the subgroup analysis compares one group with an FPG of 95–99 mg/dL with another group that has the same FPG. Therefore, even if participants with a high fasting plasma glucose were more likely to develop DM, this increased incidence would not threaten the internal validity of a subgroup analysis comparing results within one subgroup.

answers.content: Only white men without preexisting illnesses were included in the clinical trial.
answers.explanation_why: The initial results of the study lack generalizability (external validity) to the general population because of sampling bias (including only white men without preexisting illnesses). Regardless, the lack of generalizability of the initial results is no reason to question the internal validity of the subgroup analysis.

answers.content: Treatment response among subjects of different categories of fasting plasma glucose was not the primary outcome measure.
answers.explanation_why:
In this scenario, subgroups (i.e., subjects of different groups, categorized according to their FPG) were determined and analyzed after the initial trial ended, raising concerns about the validity of the subgroup efficacy analysis. Posthoc subgroup analysis of the same data is associated with an increased rate of false positives or false negatives and increases the chance of coincidentally discovering statistically significant results. In addition, subgroups also have a smaller number of subjects, which leads to reduced statistical power of the subgroup analysis, making it difficult to identify true subgroup effects. The results of posthoc subgroup analysis should not be used to infer treatment effects or make clinical decisions but can be used for hypothesis generation for further clinical studies.

If subgroup analysis will be performed as a part of the study to infer treatment effects or make clinical decisions, the subgroups should be determined a priori (during the study design phase) in order to avoid selection bias and to ensure adequate sample sizes within each subgroup. In addition, only a small number of subgroups should be analyzed to avoid the multiple comparisons problem. Finally, the expected subgroup effect (direction and magnitude) should be defined before the trial and based on logical reasoning (e.g., pathophysiological considerations).
answers.explanation_but:
A prominent example that demonstrates the limitations of posthoc subgroup analyses is the second International Study of Infarct Survival (ISIS-2). The authors performed a posthoc subgroup analysis based on astrological birth signs on their data. According to this analysis, patients born under the astrological signs of Libra and Gemini did not benefit from one month of daily aspirin after myocardial infarction. The result of the analysis was statistically significant. The authors reported this outcome as an example of the questionable nature of posthoc subgroup analyses.

Randomized trial of intravenous streptokinase, oral aspirin, both, or neither among 17,187 cases of suspected acute myocardial infarction: ISIS-2. ISIS-2 (Second International Study of Infarct Survival) Collaborative Group. Lancet. 1988 Aug 13;2(8607):349-60. PMID: 2899772.

question_text:
A major outbreak of SARS-CoV-2 has reached pandemic levels. Patients with infection are known to be contagious before clinical symptoms develop. Infection control experts want to use a rapid diagnostic test that can identify asymptomatic patients who should quarantine at home. Four direct-to-consumer rapid diagnostic tests with a similar cost, degree of invasiveness, and turnaround time have recently been developed. The characteristics of the tests are summarized in the table.

Test A
Test B
Test C
Test D

Sensitivity
70
75
90
85

Specificity
90
75
40
90

Based on this information, a negative result of which of the following tests decreases the likelihood of having the infection most?
content_preview: A major outbreak of SARS-CoV-2 has reached pandemic levels. Patients with infection are known to be contagious before clinical symptoms develop. Infection control experts want to use a rapid diagnostic test that can identify asymptomatic patients who should quarantine at home. Four direct-to-consumer rapid diagnostic tests with a similar cost, degree of invasiveness, and turnaround time have recently been developed. The characteristics of the tests are summarized in the table. Test A Test B Test C Test D Sensitivity 70 75 90 85 Specificity 90 75 40 90 Based on this information, a negative result of which of the following tests decreases the likelihood of having the infection most?
hint: When comparing diagnostic tests with similar sensitivity or tests with similar specificity, likelihood ratios are used to determine the relative clinical utility.
learning_objective: Recognize the importance of negative likelihood ratios in diagnostic tests, and recall that a lower negative likelihood ratio more effectively decreases the post-test probability of disease.

answers.explanation_why: Test A, which has a high specificity and a positive likelihood ratio of 0.7/(1 - 0.9) = 7, can be used to confirm (rule in) the diagnosis but has a low sensitivity and a negative likelihood ratio of (1 - 0.7)/0.9 = 0.33. Another test, if negative, has a larger effect on the likelihood of having the infection.
Test B has a low sensitivity and a negative likelihood ratio of (1 - 0.75)/0.75 = 0.33. Another test, if negative, has a larger effect on the likelihood of having the infection.

Generally, a test with high sensitivity can be used to rule out disease but a test with high sensitivity and very low specificity has poor clinical utility. The negative likelihood ratio is a better test characteristic to compare the ability of tests with similar sensitivity to rule out a disease. The negative likelihood ratio of this test is (1 - 0.9)/0.4 = 0.25. Another test, if negative, has a larger effect on the likelihood of having the infection.

The likelihood ratio (LR) represents the probability of a positive or negative test result in someone with the disease of interest over the probability of the test result in someone without the disease. LRs reflect how much more likely a disease is in a person with a given test result compared to their pretest probability. The lower the value of the negative likelihood ratio (i.e., the closer to 0 it is), the larger the effect of a negative test result in reducing the post-test probability of disease. LR^- is calculated using the equation (1 - sensitivity)/specificity. In this scenario, the LR^- of Test D is (1 - 0.85)/0.9 = 0.17, which is the lowest LR^- of the four tests. LR^- < 0.1 indicates that the test is effective at ruling out the presence of disease.

Similarly, a high positive likelihood ratio (LR^+) indicates that a positive test strongly increases the post-test probability of disease. LR^+ is calculated using the equation sensitivity/(1 - specificity). An LR^+ > 10 indicates that the test is highly effective at ruling in a disease.

question_text:
Researchers conducted a large randomized controlled trial comparing three treatments for infants hospitalized with respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection: an experimental product, hypertonic saline, and routine care. Each treatment arm included 48 infants. The goal and primary outcome of the trial was to reduce the duration of hospitalization. The findings are as follows:

Experimental product
Hypertonic saline
Routine care

P value for difference among the groups

Duration of hospitalization (days)
2.1
1.9
2.2
0.22

Time to sterilization of nasal passages (days)
1.1
4.3
5.2
< 0.001

Cost (dollars per hospital day)
1250
25
5
< 0.001

Clinically significant adverse effects
Vomiting in 4 subjects
Severe broncho­constriction in 2 subjects
None

Which of the following conclusions can be drawn from these data about the most appropriate intervention for an infant hospitalized with RSV infection?
content_preview: Researchers conducted a large randomized controlled trial comparing three treatments for infants hospitalized with respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection: an experimental product, hypertonic saline, and routine care. Each treatment arm included 48 infants. The goal and primary outcome of the trial was to reduce the duration of hospitalization. The findings are as follows: Experimental product Hypertonic saline Routine care P value for difference among the groups Duration of hospitalization (days) 2.1 1.9 2.2 0.22 Time to sterilization of nasal passages (days) 1.1 4.3 5.2 < 0.001 Cost (dollars per hospital day) 1250 25 5 < 0.001 Clinically significant adverse effects Vomiting in 4 subjects Severe broncho­constriction in 2 subjects None Which of the following conclusions can be drawn from these data about the most appropriate intervention for an infant hospitalized with RSV infection?
learning_objective: Distinguish statistical significance from clinical importance.

answers.content: Hypertonic saline and the experimental product are equally appropriate interventions
answers.explanation_why: Although the experimental product was statistically superior in sterilizing the nasal passages, such differences were not reflected in length of hospital stay, a more clinically relevant outcome. Hypertonic saline appears to be associated with several complications, and the experimental product is very expensive.

answers.content: Routine care is the most appropriate intervention
answers.explanation_why: Statistically significant outcome differences in a clinical trial are not necessarily clinically important if the difference between treatment groups is very small, the outcomes studied are not relevant to clinical practice, or both. Analyzing the performance of a specific test or intervention should therefore include relevant parameters, such as adverse effects, costs, psychological impact, quality of life, and burden to individual patients and to society. In this case, data were complete and available for four outcomes of interest. Of these, routine care was not statistically superior in sterilizing the nasal passages, but was superior in costs and not associated with complications, the more clinically relevant outcomes. Therefore, routine care can be recommended over both the experimental product and hypertonic saline.

answers.content: The experimental product is the most appropriate intervention
answers.explanation_why: Although the experimental product was statistically superior in sterilizing the nasal passages, such differences were not reflected in length of hospital stay, a more clinically relevant outcome. Given that patients in all three groups were discharged after similar lengths of hospital stay, one can conclude that there are no differences in clinical effectiveness across the interventions. However, the experimental product is very expensive.

answers.content: Hypertonic saline is the most appropriate intervention
answers.explanation_why: Although the experimental product was statistically superior in sterilizing the nasal passages, such differences were not reflected in length of hospital stay, a more clinically relevant outcome. Hypertonic saline appears to be associated with several complications.

Given that patients in all three groups were discharged after similar lengths of hospital stay, one can conclude that there are no differences in clinical effectiveness across the interventions. However, the experimental product is very expensive, and hypertonic saline appears to be associated with several complications.

question_text:
A 45-year-old woman with recurrent urinary tract infections comes to the physician for advice on appropriate prevention. A review of the literature reveals five different approaches to preventing recurrence relative to placebo. Which set of results provides the most precise estimate of a protective effect?

Approach
Relative risk
95% Confidence interval

A
0.78
0.71–0.86

B
0.74
0.37–0.99

C
0.82
0.75–1.2

D
1.2
1.1–1.4

E
1.3
1.0–1.4
content_preview: A 45-year-old woman with recurrent urinary tract infections comes to the physician for advice on appropriate prevention. A review of the literature reveals five different approaches to preventing recurrence relative to placebo. Which set of results provides the most precise estimate of a protective effect? Approach Relative risk 95% Confidence interval A 0.78 0.71–0.86 B 0.74 0.37–0.99 C 0.82 0.75–1.2 D 1.2 1.1–1.4 E 1.3 1.0–1.4
hint: When evaluating a relative risk (RR) estimate, consider whether it is greater or less than 1.0. To evaluate a confidence interval (CI), consider whether it includes 1.0 and its width.
learning_objective: Recall the importance of a confidence interval in the interpretation of study results.

answers.explanation_why: The RR estimates the ratio of the probability of an outcome (e.g., recurrence of urinary tract infections) occurring in an exposed group (e.g., those receiving treatment) to the probability of the outcome occurring in an unexposed group (e.g., those receiving placebo). An RR < 1.0 indicates that a given treatment decreases the probability of an outcome. The CI provides a range of plausible values for the true RR based on the available data. A CI that does not include 1.0 indicates a statistically significant difference between the two groups. Finally, the width of the CI provides information about the precision of the estimate. If the RR estimate is 0.78 and the CI is 0.71–0.86, the intervention likely has a protective effect, and the magnitude of that effect (relative risk reduction) could be anywhere from 14–29%. The narrower the CI, the more precise the RR estimate. Therefore, approach A has the set of results that shows a protective effect (i.e., an RR <1.0 with a CI that does not include 1.0) with the most precision (i.e., the narrowest CI).

An RR < 1.0 with a CI that does not include 1.0 suggests a protective effect for this intervention. However, the width of the CI is 0.37–0.99, indicating a relative risk reduction anywhere from 1–63%, which makes this a less precise estimate.
An RR < 1.0 indicates a protective effect of this intervention. However, a CI that includes 1.0 suggests no statistically significant difference in outcomes between the exposed and unexposed groups.
An RR > 1.0 with a CI that does not include 1.0 indicates that this approach increases the risk of urinary tract infections rather than preventing their recurrence.

An RR > 1.0 indicates that the risk of recurrent urinary tract infection in the treatment group is higher than in the placebo group. In addition, a CI that includes 1.0 suggests no statistically significant difference in outcomes between the exposed and unexposed groups.

question_text: Researchers are studying a novel cancer treatment in patients whose disease is refractory to conventional therapy. The study participants are randomized to one of two arms. Both arms receive the current standard of care; one arm also receives the new therapeutic agent, while the other arm receives placebo. The primary outcome in the study is the difference in progression-free survival (PFS) between the two arms. Which of the following scenarios would constitute a type 2 error in this study?
content_preview: Researchers are studying a novel cancer treatment in patients whose disease is refractory to conventional therapy. The study participants are randomized to one of two arms. Both arms receive the current standard of care; one arm also receives the new therapeutic agent, while the other arm receives placebo. The primary outcome in the study is the difference in progression-free survival (PFS) between the two arms. Which of the following scenarios would constitute a type 2 error in this study?
learning_objective: Distinguish between type I and type II statistical errors.

answers.content: Concluding that PFS is the same in the two study arms when, in reality, the new drug prolongs PFS
answers.explanation_why: A type 2 error is defined as acceptance of a null hypothesis that is actually false. In this study, the null hypothesis is that there is no difference in PFS between the two treatment groups. Therefore, concluding that PFS is the same in the two study arms when, in fact, the new drug prolongs PFS constitutes a type 2 error.

answers.content: Concluding that PFS is longer with the new drug when appropriate hypothesis testing gives a p-value of 0.08
answers.explanation_why: Concluding that there is a difference between the study groups when the p-value is >0.05 would not constitute a type 1 or type 2 error.

answers.content: Concluding that PFS is longer with the new drug when, in reality, the new drug has no effect on PFS
answers.explanation_why: Concluding that there was a difference in PFS between the groups when there actually was no difference constitutes a type 1 error.

answers.content: Concluding that PFS is longer with placebo when, in reality, the new drug prolongs PFS
answers.explanation_why: Concluding that PFS is longer with placebo when, in fact, it is longer with the new drug could occur from misreading the data or if an error occurred during data analysis, but this would not represent a type 2 error.

answers.content: Concluding that PFS is the same in the two study arms when, in reality, the new drug has no effect on PFS
answers.explanation_why: Concluding that there is no PFS difference between the study groups when there truly is none (i.e., accepting a true null hypothesis) constitutes a correct interpretation of the results.

question_text: A 61-year-old woman with stage IV ovarian cancer comes to the physician for follow-up after cytoreductive surgery and completion of first-line chemotherapy with bevacizumab, carboplatin, and paclitaxel. She currently has no evidence of disease and a normal cancer-antigen-125 level. The plan is to continue maintenance chemotherapy, and her oncologist reported that a new trial supported adding olaparib to the current standard of care, which is bevacizumab. In reviewing the literature, the physician finds a randomized controlled trial comparing the addition of olaparib or placebo to maintenance chemotherapy with bevacizumab in ovarian cancer. The trial’s efficacy data were analyzed in the intention-to-treat population. Which of the following is the immediate effect of using the intention-to-treat population to analyze the efficacy data in this study?
content_preview: A 61-year-old woman with stage IV ovarian cancer comes to the physician for follow-up after cytoreductive surgery and completion of first-line chemotherapy with bevacizumab, carboplatin, and paclitaxel. She currently has no evidence of disease and a normal cancer-antigen-125 level. The plan is to continue maintenance chemotherapy, and her oncologist reported that a new trial supported adding olaparib to the current standard of care, which is bevacizumab. In reviewing the literature, the physician finds a randomized controlled trial comparing the addition of olaparib or placebo to maintenance chemotherapy with bevacizumab in ovarian cancer. The trial’s efficacy data were analyzed in the intention-to-treat population. Which of the following is the immediate effect of using the intention-to-treat population to analyze the efficacy data in this study?
learning_objective: Recall the advantages of intention-to-treat analysis in randomized controlled trials.

answers.content: Reduced data loss due to loss of follow-up
answers.explanation_why: Intention-to-treat analysis is an analytical method for randomized controlled trials; it does not mitigate data loss due to loss of follow-up.

answers.content: Improved generalizability to a larger population
answers.explanation_why: Improved generalizability to a larger population can be a downstream advantage of intention-to-treat analysis, as it reflects treatment efficacy in real-world settings. However, this is not the immediate effect of this analytical method.

answers.content: Most accurate estimate of the efficacy of the treatment under optimal conditions
answers.explanation_why: Intention-to-treat (ITT) analysis includes patients who did not adhere to treatment, which can make the novel treatment appear less effective than it is. The converse of ITT analysis is per-protocol (PP) analysis, in which study participants who deviated from their assigned study protocol are excluded from analysis. Using PP analysis improves the estimate of the effect of treatment under optimal conditions but increases selection bias.

answers.content: Preservation of the balance of randomization
answers.explanation_why:
Randomized controlled trials are designed to reduce as many differences as possible between the two groups being studied, so that any difference observed between the groups can truly be attributed to the intervention being studied. However, participants do not always fully follow the protocol they were assigned to; for example, they might discontinue the intervention because of adverse events, cross over to the alternative intervention, or not return for follow-up. In an intention-to-treat (ITT) analysis, all study participants are analyzed according to the group that they were originally randomized to (analyzed as-randomized), regardless of whether they followed the full protocol for that group or even remained in the study. Thereby, ITT analysis preserves the benefits of the randomization, reduces selection bias, and better reflects real-world settings (where patients do not always follow the treatment plans laid out for them), but it may also underestimate the true efficacy of an intervention.

The converse of ITT analysis is per-protocol analysis, in which study participants who deviated from their assigned study protocol are excluded from analysis.

answers.content: Inclusion of participants limited to those who received their allocated treatment
answers.explanation_why: In intention-to-treat analysis, all study participants are analyzed according to the group that they were originally randomized to, regardless of whether they followed the full protocol for that group or even remained in the study.

question_text: A 13-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 12-hour history of fever, irritability, decreased oral intake, and foul-smelling urine. A urinalysis is positive for white cells, leukocyte esterase, and nitrites. The physician prescribes a 10-day course of oral cefixime and discusses close follow-up with the family. One week later, the patient is afebrile, eating well, and in no distress. A voiding cystourethrogram shows grade 2 vesicoureteral reflux. The family asks how to proceed. In reviewing the literature, the physician finds a randomized controlled trial regarding the use of antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent subsequent urinary tract infections and renal scarring in young children with vesicoureteral reflux. Which of the following statements about this study’s design is correct?
content_preview: A 13-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 12-hour history of fever, irritability, decreased oral intake, and foul-smelling urine. A urinalysis is positive for white cells, leukocyte esterase, and nitrites. The physician prescribes a 10-day course of oral cefixime and discusses close follow-up with the family. One week later, the patient is afebrile, eating well, and in no distress. A voiding cystourethrogram shows grade 2 vesicoureteral reflux. The family asks how to proceed. In reviewing the literature, the physician finds a randomized controlled trial regarding the use of antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent subsequent urinary tract infections and renal scarring in young children with vesicoureteral reflux. Which of the following statements about this study’s design is correct?
hint: Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) are considered the gold standard for testing interventions.
learning_objective: Recognize the defining attributes and limitations of randomized controlled trials.

answers.content: The study design ensures that even adverse effects of prophylactic antibiotics can be identified.
answers.explanation_why: Although RCTs can identify common adverse effects, they are not optimal to identify rare adverse effects; these are usually better identified with larger observational studies.

answers.content: The statistical analyses performed in this type of study are different from those performed in other study types.
answers.explanation_why: The statistical analyses used for clinical trials are similar to those used in other study designs. Randomization in a clinical trial allows estimation of the causal effect, but the statistical approaches used are not different in this study design than in others.

answers.content: This study is designed to optimize the ability to make inferences about the effect of prophylactic antibiotics on the outcome.
answers.explanation_why:
The primary advantage of RCTs is high internal validity so that a causal inference can be made about the intervention (in this case, prophylactic antibiotics) and the outcome (urinary tract infections and renal scarring). Random allocation to the treatment groups (which leads to balancing of potential confounders between the groups) and blinding allow the investigators to attribute any observed differences in the primary outcome between treatment groups to the intervention and not to other causes. Thus, the advantage of the study identified is that it allows the researchers to determine whether prophylactic antibiotics are beneficial in preventing urinary tract infections and scarring.

Patients that sign up for RCTs tend to differ from people in the broader population, making generalizability of the results to the larger population difficult. RCTs are costly and time-consuming, so recruiting an adequate sample size to account for heterogeneity can be difficult. Therefore, the results of this trial may not apply to all children with vesicoureteral reflux, only those who match the characteristics of the trial participants.

answers.content: The study design allows the most accurate measurement of the outcome of urinary tract infections and renal scarring.
answers.explanation_why: The accuracy of the outcome metric is not affected by the study design. It is determined by the manner in which the researchers are able to measure or determine the outcome. An accurate measure of the outcome is important for a clinical trial, but it is equally important for any other research study design.

answers.content: This study is designed to optimize generalizability of the results to all children with vesicoureteral reflux.
answers.explanation_why: Patients that sign up for RCTs tend to differ from people in the broader population, making generalizability of the results to the larger population difficult. RCTs are costly and time-consuming, so recruiting an adequate sample size to account for heterogeneity can be difficult. Therefore, the results of this trial may not apply to all children with vesicoureteral reflux, only those who match the characteristics of the trial participants.

question_text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician in the winter with fever, runny nose, cough, and bilateral leg pain for the past 2 days. A point-of-care rapid influenza test, which has a sensitivity of 82% and a specificity of 98%, is positive for influenza infection. Which of the following additional information would be most helpful in determining the probability that this patient has influenza?
content_preview: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician in the winter with fever, runny nose, cough, and bilateral leg pain for the past 2 days. A point-of-care rapid influenza test, which has a sensitivity of 82% and a specificity of 98%, is positive for influenza infection. Which of the following additional information would be most helpful in determining the probability that this patient has influenza?
hint: All screening and diagnostic tests have intrinsic test characteristics such as sensitivity and specificity. However, a more useful concept for clinicians who are interpreting diagnostic tests are the positive predictive value (PPV) and the negative predictive value (NPV). The PPV and NPV depend on both the intrinsic characteristics of the test and the pretest probability that the patient has the condition of interest.
learning_objective: Recall that the correct interpretation of a test result requires knowledge of both the intrinsic characteristics of the test and the prevalence of disease in the population being tested.

answers.content: The proportion of 2-year-old children without influenza on gold-standard testing who had a positive rapid-test result
answers.explanation_why: Knowing the proportion of children without influenza on gold-standard testing who had a positive result on the rapid test provides information about the likelihood of a false-positive result on the rapid test, but does not help to define a pretest probability.

answers.content: The lifetime incidence of influenza among all children in the patient’s community
answers.explanation_why: The lifetime incidence of influenza in this case would be the proportion of children in the community who were ever diagnosed with influenza, no matter the age at diagnosis. This information would not provide the best pretest probability of influenza for this patient.

answers.content: The proportion of 2-year-old children with influenza on gold-standard testing who had a negative rapid-test result
answers.explanation_why: Knowing the proportion of children with influenza on gold-standard testing who had a negative result on the rapid test provides information about the likelihood of a false-negative result on the rapid test, but it does not help to define a pretest probability.

answers.content: The prevalence of influenza among 2-year-old children in the patient’s community who had an upper respiratory infection during the past month
answers.explanation_why: The pretest probability is best approximated from the prevalence of the condition in a population similar to that of the patient in question. In this particular scenario, the PPV is the proportion of all 2-year-old children with an upper respiratory infection and a positive rapid-test result who actually have influenza infection, as determined on a gold-standard test (polymerase-chain-reaction assay or viral culture). Using the same diagnostic test in a population with higher disease prevalence increases the PPV; that is, someone who tests positive is more likely to have true disease. Conversely, increased prevalence results in decreased NPV; individuals who test negative are more likely to actually have disease. Therefore, when considering predictive values of diagnostic tests, it is important to take into account the influence of the prevalence of disease.

answers.content: The incidence of influenza among 2-year-old children in the patient’s community during the past winter
answers.explanation_why: Incidence is defined as the rate at which a condition occurs in a population. For example, if influenza diagnoses among children in a particular community accrue at a rate of 3% per person-month during the winter, then the children in that community have a 3% chance each month of being diagnosed with influenza. Incidence does not define the pretest probability for an individual patient at the time a test is administered.

question_text:
A 17-year-old boy comes to the office to discuss a positive result on an enzyme immunoassay (EIA) screening test for HIV infection conducted 2 days ago. The results of an expedited confirmatory HIV test are pending. At this time, the patient would like to know the probability that he actually has HIV infection, given the positive EIA result. A review of the characteristics of the EIA test, compared with the gold standard, polymerase chain-reaction (PCR) testing, shows the following data:

PCR positive
PCR negative

EIA positive
125 = true positive
13 = false positive

EIA negative
1 = false negative
950 = true negative

After this patient’s positive EIA screening test, which of the following most accurately identifies the probability that he actually has HIV infection?
content_preview: A 17-year-old boy comes to the office to discuss a positive result on an enzyme immunoassay (EIA) screening test for HIV infection conducted 2 days ago. The results of an expedited confirmatory HIV test are pending. At this time, the patient would like to know the probability that he actually has HIV infection, given the positive EIA result. A review of the characteristics of the EIA test, compared with the gold standard, polymerase chain-reaction (PCR) testing, shows the following data: PCR positive PCR negative EIA positive 125 = true positive 13 = false positive EIA negative 1 = false negative 950 = true negative After this patient’s positive EIA screening test, which of the following most accurately identifies the probability that he actually has HIV infection?
learning_objective: Interpret the clinical relevance of positive and negative predictive values.

answers.explanation_why: The positive predictive value (PPV) of a screening test is the probability that a patient with a positive result actually has the disease, making the PPV the pertinent test characteristic in this case. The negative predictive value is the probability that the patient does not have the disease when the test is negative. The higher the predictive values of a screening test, the more valuable the test is. For the HIV test conducted in this scenario, the PPV is calculated as follows: 125/(125+13) x 100% = 90.6%.
Sensitivity is the probability that a patient with the disease will test positive. In this scenario, sensitivity is calculated as follows: 125/(125+1) x 100% = 99.2%.

The negative predictive value (NPV) is the probability that the patient does not have the disease when the test is negative. In this scenario, the NPV is calculated as follows:
950/(950+1) x 100% = 99.9%.
Specificity is the probability that a patient without the disease will test negative. In this scenario, specificity is calculated as follows: 950/(950+13) x 100% = 98.7%.

The positive likelihood ratio compares the chance that a patient with the disease will test positive to the chance that a patient without the disease will test positive. In this scenario, it is calculated as follows: positive likelihood ratio = sensitivity/(1 - specificity) = (125/(125+1))/(1 - (950/(950+13))) = 73.

question_text: A 6-week-old boy is brought to the physician for a routine well-child visit. The mother reports that she lives with her partner, who is a smoker. She asks about the health effects of household smoking on children, especially on the risk of developing childhood asthma. In literature search, the physician finds an observational study describing the effect of cigarette smoking on childhood health outcomes in 5000 children. An unadjusted analysis of the data from 10-year follow-up shows that childhood exposure to household tobacco smoke is associated with a high risk of developing childhood asthma. Which of the following strategies would have been appropriate for the researchers to use to address confounding in this study?
content_preview: A 6-week-old boy is brought to the physician for a routine well-child visit. The mother reports that she lives with her partner, who is a smoker. She asks about the health effects of household smoking on children, especially on the risk of developing childhood asthma. In literature search, the physician finds an observational study describing the effect of cigarette smoking on childhood health outcomes in 5000 children. An unadjusted analysis of the data from 10-year follow-up shows that childhood exposure to household tobacco smoke is associated with a high risk of developing childhood asthma. Which of the following strategies would have been appropriate for the researchers to use to address confounding in this study?
learning_objective: Recall the various ways to address confounding in a research study.

answers.content: Adjust the analysis for sex, socioeconomic class, and exposure to air pollution
answers.explanation_why: Confounders are factors that affect both the exposure and the outcome in a study. For example, in this study, a possible confounder is air pollution, which could be associated with both household tobacco smoke (the exposure of interest) and the development of childhood asthma (the outcome of interest). If this confounder is not properly accounted for, then the observed association between household tobacco smoke and childhood asthma could be incorrectly interpreted to signify causation. Researchers can address and reduce confounding during study design (by e.g., randomization, matching) and/or study analysis (by using e.g., stratified analysis, multiple regression analysis).

answers.content: Increase the follow-up time of the study
answers.explanation_why: Increasing the follow-up time of a study would increase the likelihood of detecting an effect and increase the power of the study. However, it would not address confounders, which would still affect the exposure and outcome regardless of how long the participants were followed.
Adjustment for multiplicity is an approach to handle performing many statistical tests in a single analysis, but it does not address confounding.

answers.content: Increase the sample size of the study
answers.explanation_why: Increasing the sample size of a study would increase the likelihood of detecting an effect and increase the power of the study. However, it would not address confounders, which would still affect the exposure and outcome regardless of how many participants were included.

answers.content: Change the study design to a randomized controlled trial
answers.explanation_why: One way to address confounders during study design is by choosing to conduct a randomized controlled trial (RCT). However, there are scenarios in which RCTs are impractical or unethical, such as evaluating the long-term effects of household tobacco smoke exposure in children. In observational studies, the effects of confounding can be minimized during study design by restricting the inclusion criteria so that the study population is homogenous with respect to a particular variable (e.g., by including only a certain socioeconomic class).

question_text: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the office after receiving a new diagnosis of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). Genetic analysis showed that the cancer is Philadelphia chromosome positive (Ph+), and the physician is now deciding which chemotherapy regimen to initiate. She reviews the recently published results of a randomized controlled trial that compared a new chemotherapy agent with standard care in children with Ph+ ALL. The primary outcome was progression-free survival. Which of the following is the main question that this study was designed to address?
content_preview: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the office after receiving a new diagnosis of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). Genetic analysis showed that the cancer is Philadelphia chromosome positive (Ph+), and the physician is now deciding which chemotherapy regimen to initiate. She reviews the recently published results of a randomized controlled trial that compared a new chemotherapy agent with standard care in children with Ph+ ALL. The primary outcome was progression-free survival. Which of the following is the main question that this study was designed to address?
hint: Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) aim to determine the possible effect of a specific intervention or treatment on a selected population.
learning_objective: Recall the advantages and limitations of controlled clinical trials.

answers.content: Is the new chemotherapy agent better than standard care at improving progression-free survival in patients with ALL?
answers.explanation_why: RCTs are designed to identify the effect of the intervention in either direction (an improved outcome or a worsened one). This means the trial design and interpretation of results are robust but rigid: the effect of an intervention applies only to a specific population (in this case, the results would not apply to all patients with ALL, only to children who have Ph+ ALL) and only on the measured outcome (in this case, progression-free survival). Thus, this type of study design ensures highly valid results but also limits the generalizability of those results.

answers.content: What is the effect of the new chemotherapy agent, compared with standard care, on progression-free survival in children with Ph+ ALL?
answers.explanation_why: RCTs are considered the gold standard for testing interventions because they can demonstrate causality between an intervention and an outcome. The design of RCTs ensures that intervention groups are treated the same except for the intervention that is being studied, and the process of randomization and blinding (if present) minimizes confounding and bias so that the effect of the treatment can be estimated. RCTs attempt to isolate the intervention so that any effects on the outcome are solely attributed to the intervention instead of other factors. This means the trial design and interpretation of results are robust but rigid: the effect of an intervention applies only to a specific population (in this case, the results would not apply to all patients with ALL, only to children who have Ph+ ALL) and only on the measured outcome (in this case, progression-free survival). Thus, this type of study design ensures highly valid results but also limits the generalizability of those results.

answers.content: What is the best chemotherapy agent for patients with Ph+ ALL?
answers.explanation_why: RCTs cannot directly account for multifactorial effects that are difficult to measure and thus cannot determine which treatment is best on balance.

answers.content: Do patients with Ph+ ALL live longer if they are treated with the new chemotherapy agent?
answers.explanation_why: RCTs cannot directly account for multifactorial effects that are difficult to measure and thus cannot determine which treatment is best on balance.

answers.content: What is the effect of the new chemotherapy agent on progression-free survival in children with ALL?
answers.explanation_why: RCTs are designed to identify the effect of the intervention in either direction (an improved outcome or a worsened one). This means the trial design and interpretation of results are robust but rigid: the effect of an intervention applies only to a specific population (in this case, the results would not apply to all patients with ALL, only to children who have Ph+ ALL) and only on the measured outcome (in this case, progression-free survival). Thus, this type of study design ensures highly valid results but also limits the generalizability of those results.

question_text: A novel at-home influenza test is being evaluated as a diagnostic tool. Among 520 patients tested, 242 had a positive test result, and 278 had a negative test result. Of the 242 patients with positive results, 228 had influenza confirmed on a gold-standard test. Of the 278 patients with negative results, 266 did not have influenza on gold-standard testing. Which of the following is the positive likelihood ratio of the at-home influenza test?
content_preview: A novel at-home influenza test is being evaluated as a diagnostic tool. Among 520 patients tested, 242 had a positive test result, and 278 had a negative test result. Of the 242 patients with positive results, 228 had influenza confirmed on a gold-standard test. Of the 278 patients with negative results, 266 did not have influenza on gold-standard testing. Which of the following is the positive likelihood ratio of the at-home influenza test?
hint: The positive likelihood ratio (LR+) is the ratio of the true positive rate to the false positive rate and is calculated as sensitivity/(1 - specificity).
learning_objective: Calculate and interpret a positive likelihood ratio.

answers.explanation_why: Based on the information provided in this scenario, the positive likelihood ratio for the at-home influenza test is not 0.86.

The negative likelihood ratio is the ratio of the false negative rate to the true negative rate and is calculated as (1 - sensitivity)/specificity. Based on the information provided in this scenario, both the sensitivity and specificity are calculated to be 0.95. Given these values, 0.05 represents the negative likelihood ratio ((1–0.95)/0.95 = 0.05) rather than the positive likelihood ratio.

Based on the information provided in this scenario, the test characteristics of the at-home influenza test can be calculated as shown in the table below. Given these values, the positive likelihood ratio can be calculated as follows: 0.95/(1–0.95) = 19. A high LR^+ (> 10) indicates that the test is excellent at confirming a disease. The negative likelihood ratio compares the probability of a person without the disease of interest testing negative to the probability of a person with the disease testing negative. For this scenario, it can be calculated as follows: LR^- = (1 - sensitivity) / specificity = (1–0.95)/0.95 = 0.05. A low negative likelihood ratio (< 0.1) indicates that a negative test is good at ruling out the presence of disease. Together, these ratios suggest that the test performs well in accurately detecting the presence of disease.

If the likelihood ratio of a diagnostic test is 1, it has poor clinical utility.
In this scenario, both the sensitivity and specificity are calculated to be 0.95, as shown in the table below. The positive likelihood ratio for the at-home influenza test is not 0.95.
Based on the information provided in this scenario, the positive likelihood ratio for the at-home influenza test is not 33.

question_text: A 25-year-old man presents to the emergency department with acute-onset abdominal pain, vomiting, and fever for the past 4 hours. He is approached about participating in a research study of patients being evaluated for appendicitis, and he consents. The goal of the study is to validate a new point-of-care test measuring “serum protein Y” to diagnose appendicitis in patients presenting with abdominal pain. The outcome of whether appendicitis was present will be established by validation based on experts’ retrospective review of the clinical, laboratory, and imaging data as well as histopathologic examination of the appendix in patients who undergo appendectomy. These data will be used to establish whether the test for “serum protein Y” may be useful in diagnosing appendicitis preoperatively. The patient is informed that participating in the study will not provide any benefit to himself but that the results may benefit future patients. During the patient’s evaluation, an abdominal CT scan reveals mild thickening of the appendix with signs of surrounding inflammation. He is scheduled for urgent surgical exploration of the appendix. As part of the study protocol, a research assistant obtains a drop of blood with a fingerstick. The result of the “serum protein Y” returns very low, which the investigators have hypothesized may indicate low risk for appendicitis. The research assistant enters the result into the study database for future analysis. The patient continues to await his surgery. At the current time, who of the following should the research assistant inform about the results of the experimental test?
content_preview: A 25-year-old man presents to the emergency department with acute-onset abdominal pain, vomiting, and fever for the past 4 hours. He is approached about participating in a research study of patients being evaluated for appendicitis, and he consents. The goal of the study is to validate a new point-of-care test measuring “serum protein Y” to diagnose appendicitis in patients presenting with abdominal pain. The outcome of whether appendicitis was present will be established by validation based on experts’ retrospective review of the clinical, laboratory, and imaging data as well as histopathologic examination of the appendix in patients who undergo appendectomy. These data will be used to establish whether the test for “serum protein Y” may be useful in diagnosing appendicitis preoperatively. The patient is informed that participating in the study will not provide any benefit to himself but that the results may benefit future patients. During the patient’s evaluation, an abdominal CT scan reveals mild thickening of the appendix with signs of surrounding inflammation. He is scheduled for urgent surgical exploration of the appendix. As part of the study protocol, a research assistant obtains a drop of blood with a fingerstick. The result of the “serum protein Y” returns very low, which the investigators have hypothesized may indicate low risk for appendicitis. The research assistant enters the result into the study database for future analysis. The patient continues to await his surgery. At the current time, who of the following should the research assistant inform about the results of the experimental test?
learning_objective: Recall the process for evaluating the accuracy of a new diagnostic test.

answers.content: The principal investigator of the study
answers.explanation_why: When clinical studies are taking place, both the principal investigator (PI) and the treating clinicians should be blinded to any preliminary results so that clinical care is not modified to compromise the integrity of the study (i.e., introduce bias). Study findings are shared with the PI and clinicians only when the results are so significant before the end of the study that it would be unethical not to stop the study and inform others.

The ideal assessment of a new diagnostic test requires comparison to the currently best diagnostic test (i.e., the gold-standard test). Given that the serum marker being investigated in this case is currently experimental and that the current gold standard of evaluation (abdominal CT) suggests that this patient has appendicitis, the patient’s care should proceed as planned regardless of the results of the experimental test. When clinical studies are taking place, both the principal investigator and the treating clinicians should be blinded to any preliminary results so that clinical care is not modified to compromise the integrity of the study (i.e., introduce bias).

answers.content: The principal investigator of the study, the surgeon, and the patient

Study findings are shared with the PI and clinicians only when the results are so significant before the end of the study that it would be unethical not to stop the study and inform others. Once the predictive value of the experimental test becomes known, its use may begin to inform clinical decisions.

question_text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the office because she is nervous about her regular use of tanning beds after seeing in a news story that they increase the risk of skin cancer. The paper referenced in the news story describes a prospective cohort study conducted among 600 women aged ≥ 30 years: 300 reported regular use of tanning beds and 300 did not. During the 10-year study period, the women completed annual surveys indicating whether they had been diagnosed with skin cancer in the preceding year. At the end of the 10 years, researchers reported that the relative risk of skin cancer associated with tanning-bed use was 1.63 (95% confidence interval, 1.13–2.36). Which of the following conclusions about the relative risk reported in this study is most appropriate?
content_preview: A 32-year-old woman comes to the office because she is nervous about her regular use of tanning beds after seeing in a news story that they increase the risk of skin cancer. The paper referenced in the news story describes a prospective cohort study conducted among 600 women aged ≥ 30 years: 300 reported regular use of tanning beds and 300 did not. During the 10-year study period, the women completed annual surveys indicating whether they had been diagnosed with skin cancer in the preceding year. At the end of the 10 years, researchers reported that the relative risk of skin cancer associated with tanning-bed use was 1.63 (95% confidence interval, 1.13–2.36). Which of the following conclusions about the relative risk reported in this study is most appropriate?
learning_objective: Interpret relative risk as a measure of association in observational studies.

answers.content: Study participants who used tanning beds had a 63% increase in the risk of developing skin cancer compared with those who did not use tanning beds
answers.explanation_why:
The relative risk (RR) of 1.63 reported in this study means that there was a 63% increased risk of skin cancer in tanning-bed users compared with nonusers.

The RR is calculated by dividing the incidence of disease in the exposed group by the incidence of disease in the unexposed group. An RR of 1 means that the event is equally likely to occur in the exposed and unexposed groups. An RR > 1 means that the event is more likely to occur in the exposed group than in the unexposed group. An RR < 1 means the event is less likely to occur in the exposed group than in the unexposed group.

answers.content: There was an average of 1.63 more skin-cancer diagnoses per year in study participants who used tanning beds than in those who did not
answers.explanation_why: There was an average of 1.63 more skin cancer diagnoses per 10-year study period (not in one year) in study participants who used tanning beds than in those who did not.

answers.content: 63% of study participants who used tanning beds developed skin cancer
answers.explanation_why: The relative risk does not tell us the percentage of tanning-bed users who develop skin cancer (that would be the risk in the exposed; 21% in this study).

answers.content: Study participants who used tanning beds had a 163% increase in the risk of developing skin cancer compared with those who did not use tanning beds
answers.explanation_why: The relative risk of 1.63 does not mean that tanning-bed users had a 163% increase in the risk of developing skin cancer.

answers.content: Study participants who used tanning beds were 63 times more likely to develop skin cancer than those who did not use tanning beds
answers.explanation_why: The relative risk of 1.63 does not mean that tanning-bed users are 63 times more likely to develop skin cancer.
