question_text: A 16-year-old boy presents to the office for follow-up shortly after being diagnosed with type 2 diabetes. He has a long history of obesity, with a current BMI of 45. For the past 3 years, he has engaged in an exercise program and attempted to diet by restricting calories and following various supervised weight-loss programs. Although he lost some weight with these interventions, he quickly regained it. With his new diabetes diagnosis, both he and his parents are increasingly concerned about the effect of his weight on his health. They ask the physician whether bariatric surgery could provide a longer-lasting weight-loss solution and reverse his diabetes diagnosis. In looking for answers to their question, the physician finds a prospective, observational, multicenter cohort study that enrolled adults and adolescents with obesity who were about to undergo Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery. The participants were followed longitudinally with serial measurements of outcomes related to weight loss and remission of comorbid conditions. The 5-year outcomes of that trial showed that adolescents seemed to derive similar benefits to adults, with maintenance of weight loss at 5 years. Which of the following is a common limitation with this type of study design?
content_preview: A 16-year-old boy presents to the office for follow-up shortly after being diagnosed with type 2 diabetes. He has a long history of obesity, with a current BMI of 45. For the past 3 years, he has engaged in an exercise program and attempted to diet by restricting calories and following various supervised weight-loss programs. Although he lost some weight with these interventions, he quickly regained it. With his new diabetes diagnosis, both he and his parents are increasingly concerned about the effect of his weight on his health. They ask the physician whether bariatric surgery could provide a longer-lasting weight-loss solution and reverse his diabetes diagnosis. In looking for answers to their question, the physician finds a prospective, observational, multicenter cohort study that enrolled adults and adolescents with obesity who were about to undergo Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery. The participants were followed longitudinally with serial measurements of outcomes related to weight loss and remission of comorbid conditions. The 5-year outcomes of that trial showed that adolescents seemed to derive similar benefits to adults, with maintenance of weight loss at 5 years. Which of the following is a common limitation with this type of study design?
learning_objective: Recall the limitations of prospective cohort studies.

answers.content: Outcome data that rely on measurements obtained during routine medical care
answers.explanation_why: Study procedures are often as rigorous in prospective cohort studies as they are in interventional studies, with study visits to obtain a uniform data set rather than reliance on data obtained in routine clinical care only.

answers.content: Participants differing in their ability to recall the exposure, leading to recall bias
answers.explanation_why: Another observational study design is the case-control study design, which allows comparison to a control group. Individuals with a specific disease or outcome (cases) are compared to those without the disease or outcome (controls). This design may be prone to recall bias if participants are asked to retrospectively recall their exposure. Recall bias may also affect other study designs such as retrospective cohort studies and cross-sectional studies. In prospective cohort studies, however, the information about the exposure of interest is typically obtained close to the time of the actual exposure, which is why the risk of recall bias is reduced.

answers.content: A high likelihood of participant attrition over the study period
answers.explanation_why:
Prospective cohort studies are observational studies that follow a predetermined group over time. They are useful in demonstrating the effect of interventions or exposures on outcomes, determining a sequence of events, and studying the effect of time on the group. Because information about the exposure of interest is obtained close to the time of the actual exposure, the risk of recall bias is reduced. However, prospective cohort studies typically take place over long periods of time, which can be costly in terms of time and funding and can also lead to participant attrition or loss to follow-up.

Loss to follow-up may cause attrition bias if the remaining participants differ significantly from those lost to follow-up, especially if the reason for the dropout is related to the outcome.

answers.content: Eligible patients declining enrollment to avoid being randomized to a treatment arm they prefer to avoid
answers.explanation_why: Unlike in interventional studies, such as randomized controlled trials, cohort studies do not alter the participants’ exposure. The exposure is determined by other factors, and the investigator is simply following participants over time to assess the effect of the exposure on the outcome of interest.

answers.content: An inappropriate control group introducing bias
answers.explanation_why: Another observational study design is the case-control study design, which allows comparison to a control group. In case-control studies, the study sample is selected according to having a disease or not, and then it is determined which participants were exposed to a risk factor. Controls are selected from the same source population and ideally have similar characteristics (e.g., gender, age) to the cases. Inappropriate choice of the control group can lead to confounding.

question_text: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the office for a routine visit. Her mother mentions that her previously healthy father, the child’s grandfather, was recently diagnosed with metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinoma. The mother reports that she has been preoccupied with the diagnosis and has subsequently tried to limit her family’s exposure to potential carcinogens. She has read multiple media reports about exposure to plastics and the development of pancreatic cancer. She asks the physician about the carcinogenic potential of bisphenol A in the plastic containers she uses to pack and microwave lunches for her daughter. The physician decides to review the appropriate literature. Which of the following types of research studies would be most appropriate to answer this patient’s question?
content_preview: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the office for a routine visit. Her mother mentions that her previously healthy father, the child’s grandfather, was recently diagnosed with metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinoma. The mother reports that she has been preoccupied with the diagnosis and has subsequently tried to limit her family’s exposure to potential carcinogens. She has read multiple media reports about exposure to plastics and the development of pancreatic cancer. She asks the physician about the carcinogenic potential of bisphenol A in the plastic containers she uses to pack and microwave lunches for her daughter. The physician decides to review the appropriate literature. Which of the following types of research studies would be most appropriate to answer this patient’s question?
learning_objective: Recall the uses and limitations of cohort studies.

answers.explanation_why: A case series is a type of descriptive study that is used to report rare or novel associations between an exposure and an outcome. This type of study is useful for documenting rare clinical events but cannot provide analytical measures such as risk difference.

Cross-sectional studies are a type of observational study in which population-level data are analyzed at a single point in time. Because of the descriptive nature of these studies, they cannot be used to estimate the risk difference or determine the temporal relationship between an exposure and an outcome.

Although crossover trials, in which patients are randomized to a series of exposures, can be used to determine a risk difference, randomizing patients to be exposed to a potential environmental carcinogen would not be practical or ethical.

Randomized controlled trials are superior in the hierarchy of evidence because of their ability to limit bias. Although this type of study can be used to determine a risk difference, randomizing patients to be exposed to a potential environmental carcinogen would not be practical or ethical.

One study design that is best suited to investigate the link between environmental exposures and rare outcomes is a cohort study. In prospective cohort studies, groups of patients who do and do not have the exposure in question are followed to determine if they develop a defined outcome. This type of study provides a direct measure of risk difference (incidence in the exposed group minus incidence in the unexposed group). In this example, the exposed cohort would be those who had exposure to bisphenol A, and the outcome would be the development of pancreatic cancer.

An alternative way to address this question would be a case-control study. In this type of study, researchers enroll individuals who already have or do not have the outcome in question (in this case, pancreatic cancer). These individuals are then studied retrospectively to determine their exposures. This study design is subject to recall bias, which can limit the strength of the conclusions drawn.

question_text: Clinicians at a weight-loss clinic serving late adolescents and young adults are planning to investigate the average BMI of patients at the time they enroll in a program. They randomly select 150 patients and find that the mean BMI of this group was 36.2 at program enrollment. One of the clinicians asks if there is a way to measure whether the mean BMI in this patient sample is a precise measurement of the mean BMI in the larger clinic population. Which of the following measures would be most useful to answer this question?
content_preview: Clinicians at a weight-loss clinic serving late adolescents and young adults are planning to investigate the average BMI of patients at the time they enroll in a program. They randomly select 150 patients and find that the mean BMI of this group was 36.2 at program enrollment. One of the clinicians asks if there is a way to measure whether the mean BMI in this patient sample is a precise measurement of the mean BMI in the larger clinic population. Which of the following measures would be most useful to answer this question?
learning_objective: Identify the measurement that is most useful in assessing the precision of a sample mean in estimating a population mean.

answers.explanation_why: The power of a study is the probability that a test of significance will detect an effect that is present. This value would not help answer the clinicians’ question at this weight-loss clinic. Furthermore, there is no hypothesis testing in this scenario and therefore no power.

The standard error of the mean (SEM) is a measure of dispersion used to assess the precision of a sample mean in estimating a population mean. In this case, the clinicians want to make inferences about the mean BMI of their clinic population based on their random sample. However, the mean BMI of the sample population is likely not identical to the mean BMI of the clinic population; if the clinicians chose other similarly sized samples, they would get slightly different mean BMIs. By repeatedly choosing different samples and calculating a sample mean each time, it becomes possible to calculate the standard deviation (SD) of those sample means, which is the SEM. The SEM can be estimated by dividing the sample SD by the square root of the sample size: SEM = SD / √(sample size). If either the sample size increases or the SD of the measurement decreases, then the SEM decreases and the precision increases.

A median is another measurement of central tendency and can be used instead of a mean in certain circumstances. It represents the middle value of a data set and does not allow any inferences regarding the population mean.

A p-value is calculated in hypothesis testing and indicates how incompatible the observed data may be with a null hypothesis. This value would not help answer the clinicians’ question at this weight-loss clinic. Furthermore, there is no hypothesis testing in this scenario and therefore no p-value.

answers.content: Standard deviation of the BMI measurement
answers.explanation_why: The standard deviation (SD) of the BMI measurement is an indication of the spread of the values around the mean. If there is a wide range of BMI values, then the SD will be large; if there is a narrow range, then the SD will be small. Although the SD is needed to calculate the measurement that is most useful in assessing the precision of a sample mean in estimating a population mean, it does not (on its own) allow for inferences about the population.

question_text: A 30-year-old man presents for evaluation of low back pain that has persisted for several months. The physician is considering a diagnosis of ankylosing spondylitis and recalls that a genetic test for HLA-B27 may be helpful in diagnosing this condition. She obtains a family history, which is negative for ankylosing spondylitis, and the patient reports predominantly European ancestry. Consulting a reference, the physician finds that 90% of men of European ancestry with ankylosing spondylitis are HLA-B27 positive, and 10% of healthy men of European ancestry (i.e., without ankylosing spondylitis) are HLA-B27 positive. Given this patient’s history and physical examination, she estimates the patient’s probability of having ankylosing spondylitis (i.e., the pretest probability) is 10%. If this patient tests positive for HLA-B27, which of the following is the likelihood that he truly has ankylosing spondylitis?
content_preview: A 30-year-old man presents for evaluation of low back pain that has persisted for several months. The physician is considering a diagnosis of ankylosing spondylitis and recalls that a genetic test for HLA-B27 may be helpful in diagnosing this condition. She obtains a family history, which is negative for ankylosing spondylitis, and the patient reports predominantly European ancestry. Consulting a reference, the physician finds that 90% of men of European ancestry with ankylosing spondylitis are HLA-B27 positive, and 10% of healthy men of European ancestry (i.e., without ankylosing spondylitis) are HLA-B27 positive. Given this patient’s history and physical examination, she estimates the patient’s probability of having ankylosing spondylitis (i.e., the pretest probability) is 10%. If this patient tests positive for HLA-B27, which of the following is the likelihood that he truly has ankylosing spondylitis?
hint: The likelihood that a patient with a positive test result truly has the condition is the positive predictive value (PPV). The easiest way to calculate the PPV in this case is to construct a two-by-two table for a hypothetical population of 100 back-pain patients.
learning_objective: Calculate the positive predictive value of a diagnostic test.

answers.explanation_why: The sensitivity and specificity of HLA-B27 testing in this population are both 90%. The positive predictive value is not the same as either sensitivity or specificity.
The pretest probability, as estimated by the clinician, is 10%. The positive predictive value is a posttest probability and has a different value.
The calculated positive predictive value in this scenario is not 75%.

To calculate the PPV, one must know the sensitivity and specificity of a test as well as the patient’s probability of having the disease of interest (i.e., the pretest probability). The sensitivity of HLA-B27 in this population is 90%, given that 90% of men of European ancestry with ankylosing spondylitis (AS) are HLA-B27 positive. The specificity is also 90%, given that 90% of men of European ancestry without AS will be HLA-B27 negative. In a hypothetical population of 100 back-pain patients with a 10% pretest probability of AS, 10 will have AS, and 9 of them will be HLA-B27 positive. Conversely, 90 patients will not have AS, and 81 of them will be HLA-B27 negative. The corresponding two-by-two table is shown below. The table shows that only 9 of the 18 patients who are HLA-B27 positive have the disease; thus, the positive predictive value is 50% (PPV = true positives ÷ all patients who tested positive). Stated another way, even if this patient tests positive for HLA-B27, his probability of having AS is still only 50%.
The calculated positive predictive value in this scenario is not 25%.

question_text: A physician and her colleagues are discussing their clinic’s choice of influenza vaccine for the upcoming influenza season. The physician notes that a new influenza vaccine was recently tested in a randomized controlled trial. The trial showed that 2% of participants receiving the new vaccine developed laboratory-confirmed influenza infection compared with 3% of those receiving the standard vaccine. The physician describes these results to her colleagues by stating that “the number needed to treat was 100.” In the context of this study, which of the following statements about the number needed to treat is most appropriate?
content_preview: A physician and her colleagues are discussing their clinic’s choice of influenza vaccine for the upcoming influenza season. The physician notes that a new influenza vaccine was recently tested in a randomized controlled trial. The trial showed that 2% of participants receiving the new vaccine developed laboratory-confirmed influenza infection compared with 3% of those receiving the standard vaccine. The physician describes these results to her colleagues by stating that “the number needed to treat was 100.” In the context of this study, which of the following statements about the number needed to treat is most appropriate?
learning_objective: Apply the concept of number needed to treat when describing study results.

answers.content: If 100 patients were treated with the new vaccine, one additional participant would develop laboratory-confirmed influenza
answers.explanation_why: An implication of harm (developing laboratory-confirmed influenza) is not supported by the provided data. Harm from intervention in comparison to control is measured by the number needed to harm, not the number needed to treat (NNT). Moreover, the NNT must always be used in the context of a comparator (i.e., the control group); it is not a measure of the effect of an intervention on its own.

answers.content: The new vaccine would need to be given to at least 100 people for the trial results to be valid
answers.explanation_why: The number needed to treat is not a measure of trial validity.

answers.content: If 100 patients were treated with the new vaccine rather than the old vaccine, one additional case of laboratory-confirmed influenza would be prevented
answers.explanation_why:
The number needed to treat (NNT) is a measure of the clinical effect of a particular intervention compared with another intervention or a control. It is calculated by taking the reciprocal of the absolute risk difference between groups. The NNT represents the number of participants, on average, who need to receive a given intervention to prevent one more adverse outcome than would have occurred in the control setting. In other words, in this study, if 100 patients were treated with the new vaccine rather than the old vaccine, one case of laboratory-confirmed influenza would be prevented.

NNT is often considered a more intuitive measure for clinical decision-making than a relative risk or odds ratio. It is especially useful in cases of a single intervention with a definitive end point, such as confirmed disease or death. Of note, it must always be used in the context of a comparator (i.e., the control group); it is not a measure of the effect of an intervention on its own.

answers.content: For every 100 cases of laboratory-confirmed influenza occurring in patients treated with the old vaccine, one case could have been prevented if they had received the new vaccine
answers.explanation_why: This is not a correct interpretation of the number needed to treat, which represents the number of participants who need to receive a given intervention to prevent one more adverse outcome than would have occurred in the control setting.

answers.content: If 100 participants were treated with the new vaccine, one additional participant would be immune to influenza
answers.explanation_why: The endpoint, in this case, is not a guarantee of immunity against influenza but rather the prevention of one more case of laboratory-confirmed influenza. Moreover, the number needed to treat must always be used in the context of a comparator (i.e., the control group); it is not a measure of the effect of an intervention on its own.

question_text: Researchers are studying a new diet and exercise intervention for weight loss. They randomly assign 150 patients to each of two study arms, an intervention arm and an arm representing the current standard-of-care approach, and follow them for one year. At the end of the follow-up period, the average weight loss ± SD (standard deviation) is 14.1 kg ± 5.2 kg (31 lb ± 11 lb) for the intervention group and 10.3 kg ± 2.3 kg (23 lb ± 5 lb) for the standard-of-care group. Which of the following statements is the best interpretation of these results and the standard deviation values given?
content_preview: Researchers are studying a new diet and exercise intervention for weight loss. They randomly assign 150 patients to each of two study arms, an intervention arm and an arm representing the current standard-of-care approach, and follow them for one year. At the end of the follow-up period, the average weight loss ± SD (standard deviation) is 14.1 kg ± 5.2 kg (31 lb ± 11 lb) for the intervention group and 10.3 kg ± 2.3 kg (23 lb ± 5 lb) for the standard-of-care group. Which of the following statements is the best interpretation of these results and the standard deviation values given?
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate measure of spread for continuous outcomes in a clinical trial.

answers.content: The maximum amount of weight loss in the intervention group was 19.3 kg (42 lb) after one year
answers.explanation_why: This statement does not represent a correct interpretation of standard deviation.

answers.content: Given a normal distribution of data, approximately 95% of participants in the intervention group had a weight loss between 3.7 kg (9 lb) and 24.5 kg (53 lb) after one year
answers.explanation_why: In a normal distribution, two SDs above and below the mean cover 95% of the sample. Using the data from the study, we can therefore determine the range of weight loss experienced by 95% of the participants in the intervention group during one year of follow-up. The lower end of the range is found by subtracting two SDs from the mean: 14.1 - 2(5.2) = 3.7 kg (31 - 2(11) = 9 lb). The upper end of the range is found by adding two SDs to the mean: 14.1 + 2(5.2) = 24.5 kg (31 + 2(11) = 53 lb). Hence, approximately 95% of participants in the intervention group had a one-year weight loss of between 3.7 kg and 24.5 kg (9 lb and 53 lb).

images.title: Bell curve and standard deviations
images.description:
Bell curve showing a normal distribution of values around a given mean value.Approx. 68% of values fall within the range of -1 SD to +1 SD from the mean.
Approx. 95% of values fall within the range of -2 SDs to +2 SDs from the mean.
Approx. 99.7% of values fall within the range of -3 SDs to +3 SDs from the mean.(SD = standard deviation)

answers.content: All participants in the standard-of-care group had a weight change between –8.0 kg (18 lb) and +12.6 kg (28 lb) after one year
answers.explanation_why: This statement does not represent a correct interpretation of standard deviation.

answers.content: Approximately 5.2% of participants in the intervention group had a weight loss greater than the average compared with 2.3% of participants in the standard-of-care group
answers.explanation_why: This statement does not represent a correct interpretation of standard deviation.

answers.content: Weight changes of greater than 2.3 kg (5 lb) or 5.2 kg (11 lb) after one year were considered significant in the standard-of-care and intervention groups, respectively
answers.explanation_why: This statement does not represent a correct interpretation of standard deviation.

question_text: A 40-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes and obesity presents for routine care. Despite nonpharmacologic and medical therapy, her weight and BMI have increased during the past 3 years. The physician is considering referring her for bariatric surgery to manage her weight. Before doing so, he reviews the literature and finds several studies with conflicting conclusions. Which of the following studies identified during the literature search would be the most informative for assessing the role of bariatric surgery in managing this patient’s weight?
content_preview: A 40-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes and obesity presents for routine care. Despite nonpharmacologic and medical therapy, her weight and BMI have increased during the past 3 years. The physician is considering referring her for bariatric surgery to manage her weight. Before doing so, he reviews the literature and finds several studies with conflicting conclusions. Which of the following studies identified during the literature search would be the most informative for assessing the role of bariatric surgery in managing this patient’s weight?
learning_objective: Compare the uses and limitations of systematic review and meta-analysis.

answers.content: A retrospective observational study describing the effects of bariatric surgery on weight loss
answers.explanation_why: An observational study does not benefit from the randomization process inherent in randomized controlled trials. Furthermore, a different type of study that involves the collection and analysis of data from multiple studies can provide a more accurate estimate of effect than a single study.

answers.content: The randomized controlled trial with the largest number of participants comparing the effects of bariatric surgery versus medical therapy on weight loss
answers.explanation_why: Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) are considered the gold standard for testing interventions. However, there is a different type of study design with higher statistical power that can provide an even more precise estimate of effect than a single, large RCT.

answers.content: A metaanalysis of randomized controlled trials comparing the effects of bariatric surgery versus medical therapy on weight loss
answers.explanation_why:
Metaanalysis is a method of collecting and analyzing data from multiple studies to create a numerical summary and estimate of effect. Metaanalysis provides evidence of reproducibility of results and, potentially, a more precise estimate of effect than a single study. It is therefore particularly useful when different studies yield different estimates of the overall effect of interest. Moreover, pooling studies together increases statistical power. Analyzing data from randomized controlled trials retains the benefits of randomization.

Metaanalysis is only as good as the data being analyzed, which is one of its main limitations. If a metaanalysis includes studies that were designed with a high risk of bias or studies that have slightly different end points, the results will be less reliable or informative than if the analysis included only higher-quality studies or studies with the same end points. Metaanalyses can also amplify publication bias because they only include published studies, and negative studies are less likely to be submitted or published.

answers.content: A systematic review of randomized controlled trials and observational studies describing the effect of gastric bypass surgery on weight loss
answers.explanation_why: A systematic review is a process to collect published evidence for a specific research question by following a prespecified protocol; it may serve as the basis of a metaanalysis if the types of outcome measurements in the gathered studies are similar enough to combine. However, a comparison of the effects of bariatric surgery versus medical therapy on weight loss would be the most informative for assessing the role of bariatric surgery in this patient.

answers.content: A metaanalysis of randomized controlled trials comparing the effects of bariatric surgery versus medical therapy on insulin sensitivity
answers.explanation_why: In this case scenario, the stated outcome of interest is weight loss; therefore, a metaanalysis with insulin sensitivity as the outcome of interest will be less relevant.

question_text: A 4-month-old boy is brought to the office by his parents because of a 1-month history of frequent regurgitation and irritability. He is diagnosed with infantile gastroesophageal reflux (GER). His parents ask about the prognosis of the condition. Which of the following study designs would be most likely to yield useful data on the long-term prognosis of a common condition such as infantile GER?
content_preview: A 4-month-old boy is brought to the office by his parents because of a 1-month history of frequent regurgitation and irritability. He is diagnosed with infantile gastroesophageal reflux (GER). His parents ask about the prognosis of the condition. Which of the following study designs would be most likely to yield useful data on the long-term prognosis of a common condition such as infantile GER?
learning_objective: Identify the study design most likely to yield valid information about the long-term prognosis of a commonly diagnosed condition.

answers.explanation_why: Prospective cohort studies represent the type of study best suited to elucidate the prognosis of a common disease process. At baseline, none of the subjects has developed the outcome of interest, but the assumption is that a sufficient number will develop it during the study to allow for useful statistical analysis. The data are collected prospectively to avoid recall bias. Disease conditions that have a low incidence are difficult to study with this design, because not many of the participants would develop the disease during the study.

answers.content: Long-term follow-up of participants in a randomized controlled trial
answers.explanation_why: In a long-term follow-up study of patients in a randomized controlled trial (i.e., experimental study), the outcome data may be unduly influenced by the intervention studied. In addition, the population of patients who meet the many criteria for enrollment in a clinical trial that focuses on a specific condition may not represent the broad population of patients with that condition.

A case series can provide data on patient outcomes, but it is hard to draw conclusions from this type of study because it often involves a small sample of patients selected in nonrandomized fashion (for example, a group of patients followed at a particular institution for a particular reason).

Case-control studies can offer valuable information about patients’ long-term outcomes, especially when the condition of interest is rare and may not be detected in a large cohort. However, the retrospective collection of data can bias the findings.
Cross-sectional studies evaluate disease characteristics at a specific point in time. This type of observational study does not adequately elucidate the prognosis of a condition.

question_text: During rounds with medical students, an attending physician examines a 33-year-old man in the intensive care unit who suffered second-degree burns over 24% of his body-surface area. One of the students asks whether checking the patient’s procalcitonin levels would be useful to detect early signs of sepsis. Which of the following study designs would be most useful in determining the predictive value of procalcitonin levels for detecting sepsis in a burn patient?
content_preview: During rounds with medical students, an attending physician examines a 33-year-old man in the intensive care unit who suffered second-degree burns over 24% of his body-surface area. One of the students asks whether checking the patient’s procalcitonin levels would be useful to detect early signs of sepsis. Which of the following study designs would be most useful in determining the predictive value of procalcitonin levels for detecting sepsis in a burn patient?
learning_objective: Select the study design that is highest in the hierarchy of evidence for answering a clinical question.

answers.content: Case-control study evaluating procalcitonin levels in hospitalized burn patients who developed sepsis and those who did not
answers.explanation_why: Case-control studies compare the characteristics of individuals who already have a particular disease (cases) with the characteristics of individuals who do not have that disease (controls). These studies are very useful for rare diseases, but the investigators do not follow patients over time and thus cannot calculate incidence. Although a case-control study comparing the procalcitonin levels among burn patients who developed sepsis with those who did not would be a valid design, it would be less informative and more prone to bias than study types that are higher on the hierarchy of evidence.

answers.content: An animal study in which procalcitonin levels are measured in mice with and without sepsis
answers.explanation_why: Animal studies are far less likely than observational human studies to provide clinically useful data.

answers.content: Prospective cohort study of hospitalized burn patients who had their daily procalcitonin levels checked while being observed for development of sepsis
answers.explanation_why: A prospective cohort study of hospitalized burn patients whose procalcitonin levels were tracked over time could quantify the incidence of sepsis among burn patients and describe how trends in procalcitonin did or did not predict the development of sepsis. However, a single study of this type is limited by its sample size, the number of institutions involved, and other factors that may make the study population different from the population of all hospitalized burn patients.

answers.content: Metaanalysis of prospective cohort studies of hospitalized burn patients who had their daily procalcitonin levels checked while being observed for development of sepsis
answers.explanation_why:
All clinical research studies are subject to both random and systematic error that can lead to incorrect conclusions about the answer to a research question. The hierarchy of evidence stipulates that different study designs have different inferential power and different likelihoods of systematic error. Randomized controlled trials are at the top of the hierarchy for most clinical questions, but are not always feasible. For observational studies, metaanalysis of cohort studies has the highest strength of evidence, followed by prospective cohort study, retrospective cohort study, case-control study, cross-sectional study, and case series.

A metaanalysis of prospective cohort studies has the advantage of effectively increasing the sample size (by including information from multiple studies or sources) and using statistical methods to pool the results. Although each study included in the metaanalysis may be subject to bias in one direction or another, the combination of study results is more likely to lead to an accurate approximation of a statistical association than any one study alone.

answers.content: Case series of 25 burn patients who developed sepsis, with graphs of daily procalcitonin levels for each patient
answers.explanation_why: A case series is a descriptive study about a group of patients with the same disease or condition who all have the exposure of interest (in this case, measurement of procalcitonin levels). Although this type of study can be used to generate hypotheses, it does not include a comparison group, which makes drawing conclusions about causality very difficult.

question_text: Researchers have postulated that intrauterine insults, possibly related to certain drugs taken during pregnancy, might be associated with a rare type of cancer that typically develops in the second decade of life. Which of the following types of studies is most appropriate and cost-effective for determining whether the postulated association is real?
content_preview: Researchers have postulated that intrauterine insults, possibly related to certain drugs taken during pregnancy, might be associated with a rare type of cancer that typically develops in the second decade of life. Which of the following types of studies is most appropriate and cost-effective for determining whether the postulated association is real?
learning_objective: Recognize the uses and limitations of case-control studies.

answers.explanation_why: Case-control studies are useful for evaluating relationships between rare outcomes and multiple past exposures during a long period of time. Given the retrospective study design and lack of intervention, case-control studies are relatively inexpensive to conduct compared with randomized controlled trials. The major challenges with conducting case-control studies are matching appropriate controls to the cases and preventing or minimizing recall bias.
Cross-sectional surveys are best for establishing the prevalence of a disorder at a particular moment in time.
In a crossover study, patients serve as their own controls to limit confounding. This type of study is typically used to study the treatment effects of drugs.

In a prospective cohort study, researchers define a cohort of patients and then follow them to see who develops the outcome of interest. This study design would not be suitable to answer the question at hand in a timely, cost-effective fashion.
Randomized controlled trials are not ideal for studying exposures for which the outcome of interest takes a long time to develop.
